PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CASS; EVERINGHAM; JENKINS; JOHNSON; JONES; KENT; KLUGMAN; MORRIS; MOUNTFORD; SCOTT
PETITION.TITLE: Trans-Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Trans-Australia Airlines
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans-Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans-Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in-
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Cass,Dr Everingham,Dr Jenkins,Mr Les Johnson,Mr Charles Jones,Mr Kent,Dr Klugman,Mr Morris,Mr Mountford and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) The financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary Institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(ii) The imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1974 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(iii) Those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the post-secondary education system would be most severely affected by the reintroduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(i) Post-secondary tuition fees not be reintroduced for any courses or for any category of students.
(ii) The imposition of visa charges upon private overseas students be ceased and desisted from immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duffy,Mr Jacobi,Mr Kent,Mr Milton and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) The financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(ii) The imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1971 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(iii) Those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the post-secondary education system would be most severely affected by the re-introduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. Post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students.
2. The visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
3. The Minister of Education immediately clarify the government's attitude to the re-introduction of post- secondary tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Jenkins and Mr Young.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersignd citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. the proposal to introduce fees for higher and second degrees will mean that access to post-graduate and recurrent education will be limited to the rich; Australian research and ability to cope with technological change will suffer; this proposal must be seen as a step in the direction of the introduction of fees for all tertiary students.

2. the proposed introduction of a loans scheme for students will mean graduating with a heavy debt or being denied a tertiary education if loans are refused because a student is seen as a 'poor risk' (particularly affecting women and those doing non-vocational courses); only the rich will be able to get a tertiary education without course restrictions and the burden of indebtedness.

3. in regard to the proposal to restrict eligibility for TEAS and the foreshadowing of reviewing TEAS levels only in the light of the availability of loans, it should be noted that any further downgrading of TEAS, which is already inadequate, can only further limit access to education.

4. the proposed restriction of adult secondary assistance to those needing qualifications for employment will severely restrict access to a full high school education and necessary bridging education to tertiary education for those who left school early.

5. the proposal not to fund 30 colleges of advanced education if they are not rationalised is an attack on teacher education. This attack will create teacher shortages in the mid 1980s, restrict access to education now and endanger the future quality of teaching available to Australian children.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(i) post-secondary tuition fees not be introduced for any courses or for any category of students;
(ii) that the TEAS scheme be extended so as to more fully meet the real financial needs of students.
(iii) that a comprehensive loans scheme not be introduced.
(iv) that there be no restriction of adult secondary assistance.
(v) that the proposal not to fund 30 CAEs unless they are rationalised be rescinded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The hotel industry in Australia is long-established and a valuable part of the community of this nation, providing places were the people may partake of the three basic needs of life: a place to eat, a place to drink, a place to sleep.
2. The hotel industry is accepted throughout the nation as occupying an important place in the social and economic activities of Australia.
3. The hotel industry is almost entirely within the private sector and makes a large contribution to the government in taxes of various kinds.
4. The hotel industry has a need to sustain an appropriate level of turnover and growth, to make profit, and to sustain and improve the level of employment.
5. The hotel industry of Australia is gravely concerned at published reports that the Government intends to increase excise charges on beer in the forthcoming Budget.
6. Sales of beer constitute the major source of income of most of the industry's 5811 hotels in Australia.
7. The very steep rises in beer excise in 1975 and 1978 severely retarded the growth of the Australian hotel industry.

8. Any further increases in excise on beer in the 1981 Budget would further retard the industry at a time when growth is essential to maintaining economic viability and the ability to serve the constantly growing needs of the community.
9. Such is its significance as a community requirement, beer occupies a place on the Consumer Price Index, and any alteration to its cost to the community would have an inflationary effect.
10. Any increase in excise would result in and force the hotel industry to pass on such increases to the consumer by way of higher prices for beer.

11. Higher excise would be only the starting point for an upward spiral in beer prices because of the presence of other factors, such as State Licence Fee taxes, which are directly linked to excise rates.
12. The hotel industry of Australia already is gravely handicapped by heavy excise and other tax imposts, its growth is at a standstill; and inevitably must decline if beer excise is increased.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives:
1. Recognise the importance and place of the Australian Hotel industry in the social and economic life of the nation.

2. Accept that the viability of the hotel industry is essential to the maintenance of employment opportunities and stability of the industry is essential to enable it to continue to provide for the hotel needs of the nation in this period of growing population and increasing tourism.
And further, that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives resist and reject any move to increase excise on beer.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite and Mr Lusher.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That public investment in tertiary education in the form of Federal Government funding is an investment in Australia's future and enables Australia to meet the demands of technological innovation;
That grave concern has been generated as a result of the Government's decisions to:
(a) Abolish the education research and development committee.
(b) Terminate special support for educational research.
(c) Scale down in-house and contracted research activities of the Department of Education.
(d) Scale down participation in international education activities, particularly UNESCO and OECD.
(e) Further tighten already restrictive eligibility guidelines for TEAS.
(f) Supplement TEAS assistance by means of a loan scheme.
(g) Phase in tuition fees for students undertaking degrees and diplomas subsequent to an initial tertiary qualification.
(h) Reduce grants to universities and colleges to take account of fee income,
(i) compeletely abolish 30 colleges of advanced education, and
(j) Scale down various engineering schools in colleges of advanced education around Australia:
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will rescind these regressive decisions and desist from obvious attempts to pave the way for a complete re-introduction of tertiary fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cross and Mrs Darling.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth: That currently discrimination in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs and in promotion exists in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy, sex and/or sexual preference; and
That currently discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits is exercised against particular groups of individuals-in particular, against married women.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of individuals under federal awards, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to sex and/or marital status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) the financial situation of students enrolled at Australian postsecondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties;
(ii) the imposition of tuition fees for second degrees and post graduate degrees will deter many able persons from enrolling-such courses and further preserve higher education for the rich;

(iii) the introduction of a loans scheme, subsequent review of the level of TEAS and the tightening of the eligibility criteria for TEAS will cause great financial hardship and will deter students from enrolling in tertiary institutions.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. Post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students.
2. The visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
3. The Government reverse its decision to introduce a loans scheme and instead increase and extend TEAS scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aborigines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the Federal Government has the power conferred on it by the 1967 Referendum to intervene on behalf of Aboriginal people in any conflict with any State or Territory Government.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Federal Government assumes its full responsibility for Aboriginal Affairs and use the powers conferred on it by the people of Australia in the 1967 Referendum to intervene on behalf of Aborigines in any conflict with any State or Territory Government;

That the Federal Government use those constitutional powers to intervene on behalf of the Aboriginal people in their dispute with the Government of Western Australia enacting special overlay legislation to make unlawful the entry of mining company agents onto Noonkanbah land without the express permission of the Aboriginal people and that it be done immediately for the benefit of the Noonkanbah people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we strongly condemn any action taken by the Federal Government which will lead to the destruction of the Free Hospital and Medical Services of the State of Queensland.
And your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Parliament reject the proposed health cost sharing arrangements between the Commonwealth and the State governments and guarantee the maintenance of the present scheme whereby all Queenslanders who wish to avail themselves of these services may do so.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rosemount Repatriation Hospital
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of undersigned Australian citizens showeth:

Rosemount Repatriation Hospital has been of inestimable value to eligible repatriation beneficiaries for many years, and the closure or dispersal of the facilities available at the hospital would be a retrograde step.

The proposed decision to close Rosemount Repatriation Hospital through active discouragement by departmental administrative officers of any further referrals by medical officers of patients for medically prescribed occupational therapy is objectionable.

Closure of Rosemount Repatriation Hospital would severely disadvantage veterans in Brisbane's northern suburbs, as well as their relatives and friends who would be required to travel a great distance in order to visit hospitalised veterans at either of the two alternative repatriation hospitals.
Closure of Rosemount repatriation hospital and transfer of patients to Greenslopes would greatly add to the administrative burden of that repatriation and general hospital.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will reverse its announced decision to close the Rosemount Repatriation Hospital.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That Australia, as an affluent and developed nation, should be able to expend more of its resources on the alleviation of human suffering and deprivation in other less developed countries.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth government will:
Increase overseas aid to 0.7 per cent of Australia's G.N.P.
Increase to 4 per cent the proportion of overseas aid channeled through recognised non-government organisations such as World Vision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the list of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the island.
3. That the Queensland Government has recently renewed a further mining lease against the advice of conservationists.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Migrant Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That serious concern has been generated in the migrant community following the Government's endorsement of decisions of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Government Functions to:

Restrict the role of the Commonwealth in adult migrant and refugee education program to the arrangement and co-ordination only of such programs and relinquish responsibility for the conduct of individual programs.
Terminate some and rationalise other information services provided by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
Terminate forthwith the migrant assisted passaged scheme.
Transfer the translation interpreting services to private agencies or withdraw altogether.
Reduce hours of operation of the telephone interpreting service.
Discontinue production of the National Groups Directory.

Reduce overseas based staff associated with the recruitment and selection of persons for permanent settlement in Australia, which will result in greater delays in the processing of immigration applications.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government respect the needs of Australia's migrants and accordingly rescind these decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef: Oil Exploration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens:

That the undersigned are of the opinion that the Great Barrier Reef and region must be protected in entirety from the potentially destructive effects of mining and respectfully demand that you ensure this by declaring a continuous marine park of the reef zone from Fraser Island to the Torres Strait in 1981, for which management plans of the type devised for the Capricornia Section can be prepared and discussed in due course.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy and Personal Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Paragraphs 107 and 108 of the Privacy and Personal Information discussion paper number 14, brought down by the Law Reform Commission in June 1980, undermines the family unit and the authority of parents, which is the Christian basis of our society, by proposing that 'between 12 and 16 years, a child should be entitled to object to disclosure of information to a parent'.
It is your petitioners sincere belief that:

(a) an adolescent between the ages of 12 and 16 is not at a mature enough stage of life to decide whether or not the disclosure of information to a parent will be in the best interests of the adolescent.
(b) as a record keeper has no responsibility for the child, and as his moral standards may be different to those of a parent, he should not be permitted to come between child and parent.

(c) a parent has a unique position which may enable him/her to perceive a situation that the record keeper does not. The parent must therefore be aware of the problem if remedial action is to be taken, and has the right to guide the child in the direction he/she feels fit.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Members of the House of Representatives will reject the recommendation of the Law Reform Commission and find some other means to protect children from the excessive abuse of some parents.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That Federal Government proposals to shift the cost of health insurance onto the individual has placed a disproportionate and unfair financial burden on lower income groups, but particularly on large families: single income families; the chronically ill; those with recurrent illnesses and those on fixed incomes

2. That an estimated 15-20 per cent of Australians will not be able to afford insurance and will be forced to undertake extensive travel to avail themselves of outpatient services, the quality of which will be drastically reduced because of staff cuts
3. That doctors, who at this moment are awaiting a fee increase, will inevitably become more and more expensive

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government (i) will re-examine the effects of health proposals and of the necessity for compulsory health insurance on lower income groups who do not presently meet the description of disadvantaged, and (ii) redefine the criteria determining the genuinely needy and disadvantaged to encompass the categories of persons mentioned in (1.) above.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Hospital Funding Arrangements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That the Federal Government's shifting of responsibility for funding of public hospitals onto the State Governments has placed a disproportionate and onerous burden onto lower income groups, but particularly on large families; single income families; the chronically ill; those with recurrent illnesses and those on fixed incomes.
2. That included in the undesirable effects on the public hospital system in Queensland will be-
(i) long waiting times for non-urgent surgery
(ii) long waiting periods in out-patients
(iii) services, e.g. X-ray and Pathology will be reduced
(iv) staff will be reduced
(v) possible abolition of teaching hospitals and centralisation of training facilities for doctors and nurses
(vi) closing down of small country hospitals

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will request the Government to re-examine its public hospital funding arrangments, the impact of these arrangements on lower income groups mentioned in (1.) above and increase funding to the States to ensure that the undesirable effects mentioned in (2.) above do not occur.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(i) that according to the latest ABS bulletin on child care, based on a June 1980 survey, it is estimated that nearly 50,000 Australian children do not have access to child care centres and may be receiving less than adequate attention in the homes of people other than their parents;
(ii) that the Federal Government has neglected to regularly review and update funding arrangements since the family day care schemes were introduced in 1973;
(iii) that due to rising annual costs and the shortfall in Government funding since 1973, family day care centres are stretched to the limit in even maintaining their usual amount of child care.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will review and increase in real terms, its funding of family day care schemes in the 1981-82 Budget to permit improved child care and to extend this facility to those 50,000 Australian children who do not now have access to child care centres.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Animal Welfare Organisations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That the way in which we treat the animals entrusted to our protection is a reflection of our concern for people.
(2) That charitable organisations which work in the area of animal welfare must have the funds to help them to pursue and promote a policy of more enlightened and humane treatment toward animals.
(3) That tax concessions for donors to animal welfare charities:
(i) would achieve much toward alleviating unnecessary suffering and cruelty toward animals;
(ii) would bring animal welfare charities onto a more equal footing with other charities.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will legislate to amend present taxation laws to enable the extension of tax concessions to people and organisations who donate funds to accredited animal welfare charities.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Soviet Passenger Cruise Vessels
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled, the petiton of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Owing to an overwhelming and continuous demand by the Australian people for a cruise service within the economic scope of the working man and his family, we request the Government to lift the ban placed on Soviet passenger cruise vessels entering Australian ports.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Women's Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should take action as it deems appropriate to ensure the continuing functioning of the Betsy Women's Refuge and the network of shelters in Australia.

We ask that the Federal Government acknowledge that 'Betsy' and its counterparts provide housing and care for women and children in violent situations, and the Government agree to meet the financial responsibilities for continued and effective refuge functioning.
The Federal Government should be informed that one in every five applicants are not accommodated at the Betsy Refuge due to overcrowding or full occupancy.
We therefore petition for full and adequate funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

(1) Interest rates, rather than falling by 2 per cent as promised by the Prime Minister in November, 1977, are now between 2 per cent and 5 per cent higher than when that promise was made, and are at historically higher levels.

(2) This prevents many potential home buyers from borrowing to purchase a house; causes severe hardship to many people who are paying off a housing loan, causing some to default and lose their home; prevents or restrains the establishment or expansion of many businesses; and is directly responsible for increasing numbers of bankruptcies.
Your petitioners, therefore, pray that:
Minimisation of interest rates be adopted as one of the aims of economic policy;
the money supply target be relaxed to accommodate income growth without forcing credit restrictions and exorbitant interest rates;
regulation of borrowing rates be reintroduced to prevent the financial institutions raising lending rates to compensate for higher borrowing rates; and
foreign investment be more rigorously controlled in order to prevent destabilising inflows of foreign funds.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament assembled in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Women's Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned residents of Tasmania showeth:
That your petitioners are concerned about the uncertain future funding for Women's Refuges in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Commonwealth Government maintain responsibility for the National Womens Programme by continuing to fund them on a 75-25 per cent Federal State basis.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa Research Association of Australia and their supporters respectfully showeth:

That funds for medical research into epidermolysis bullosa are no longer being made available from the Federal Government to the medical research team at the University of New South Wales, enabling them to continue medical research into epidermolysis bullosa.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that these signatures contained on these forms will serve to make it known that we expect these funds to be forthcoming in the very near future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Dog and Cat Fur
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned children of Lindisfarne Primary School, Tasmania respectfully showeth that:

Domestic pets are being stolen and killed for their fur by people intent on making money. Dog and cat fur are exported to Europe by the thousands. The Australian Government has not made this illegal and we think this is not fair to the animals or pet owners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the export of dog and cat fur to Europe be banned.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Staging of American B52 Bombers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned in the Northern Territory respectfully showeth:
That the proposed use of Darwin Airport as a refuelling and Rest and Recreation base for American B52 bombers:

Jeopardises the welfare of the citizens of Darwin and of all Australians, in that it establishes a stronger potential of Darwin being a nuclear target in any conflict between the USA and another power.
Impedes the sovereignty of the Australian nation in that Australian citizens would have neither control nor knowledge of whether B52s:
(a) Carried nuclear weapons
(b) Were engaged in bombing missions against another State.
Violates the Australian people's independence and links this nation irreconcilably with United States foreign policies thereby destroying the potential for independent Australian defence policy.

Violates democratic procedures in committing the Australian nation to participation in future wars without due consultation and informed assessment by Australian citizens and further increases the militarisation of the Indian Ocean thereby increasing the likelihood of super power conflict in this region.
Jeopardises the welfare of the citizens of Darwin, in that noise pollution and the threat of accidental radioactive fallout will increase substantially to the residents.
Negates the potential of the Australian nation to establish itself as a nation of Peace in the Pacific region and violates Australia's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Members of the House of Representatives will ensure that the Prime Minister withdraw the offer of Darwin, or any other location in Australia, as a base or depot for American B52 bombers. And that furthermore will ensure that any request of such usage by the US Government be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH AFRICAN RUGBY TOUR OF NEW ZEALAND

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I refer to reports that many Commonwealth countries are considering boycotting a meeting of Commonwealth finance Ministers to be held in New Zealand in September in view of the planned South African Springbok rugby tour of New Zealand, which I might add is a tour that the Opposition also opposes. Does the Australian Government intend to send a representative to the meeting of Commonwealth finance Ministers? If so, could it be interpreted as agreeing with New Zealand's acquiescence in the Springbok tour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his reaffirmation of the bipartisan policy in relation to apartheid in sport. I think it is terribly important that this Parliament maintain that approach for reasons that all honourable members will understand. I would also hope that everyone in this House, because of a long and an historic association of many different kinds, would not want Australia to get into the business of boycotting meetings with New Zealand, no matter what other countries might do. If we had a situation in which most countries were not going to that meeting I suppose that might throw into question the basis of the meeting itself and whether that meeting ought to be held.

ANSWER.PARA: I hope that the honourable gentleman would not be advocating that we should be talking of boycotting a meeting with our close friend and neighbour because whilst we disagree strongly in relation to the proposed Springbok tour, that is only one facet of a relationship which is important to New Zealand and very important to Australia. It is an important facet, but it also does need to be understood that New Zealand's Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Brian Talboys, have in strong terms condemned the fact that that tour is taking place. So to that extent, that in itself is not a disagreement between governments. The difference is, of course, that in Australia we would not allow visas to be given for that sort of tour to take place whereas in New Zealand the onus has been placed on the sporting body to make its own particular decisions. It has made that decision against the advice of the New Zealand Government. So we do need to keep these matters in perspective. I have noticed the reports about this finance meeting. I hope that the honourable gentleman will take note of what I have said in the spirit in which it is offered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the Gallery this morning a delegation from the House of Representatives of Morocco led by His Excellency Mr Ahmed Osman. On behalf of the House I extend a very warm welcome to the members of the delegation.
—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. What steps will the Government be taking to increase competition and improve consumer choice within domestic aviation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the assumption that the legislation is finally passed-there are certain important aspects of that legislation which the honourable gentleman will be aware of and which the Government believes must stand as they have been introduced into the Parliament-the first additional step to which we are committed is an examination of the practicality and, if practical, the means whereby some or all of the shares of Trans-Australia Airlines could be passed into public hands. The move towards making TAA a public company will, of course, proceed. In the initial instance it has been said that the Government will own all the shares, but that does not constitute a decision to sell or not to sell. We will immediately establish an independent examination of the practicality in the Australian environment of selling some or all of the shares and, at the same time, if practical, the best means of moving into private ownership.

ANSWER.PARA: A deregulation inquiry will be established. We expect that inquiry to report to government in the fifth year. There is a deliberate reason for that time scale. It will take two and a half to three years before all the new aircraft are operating in Australia. If the advice we have had is correct, those aircraft, because of the differences between the airlines, will break parallel sheduling and establish a much greater degree of competition on Australia's air routes. A deregulation inquiry to make a proper judgment of circumstances in Australia will need to be able to make judgments based on the experience of those new equipments operating. In any case, the present agreement will run for five years with the possibility thereafter of a three-year period of notice being given, whether in the fifth, sixth or any other year. The report of the deregulation inquiry will plainly need to be published and debated. The Government will plainly need to state its views in relation to it. It will do so.

I cannot prejudge whether what will come out of that examination will be for or against deregulation. All I can say is that the Government will be publishing that report. We will be making a statement about it and will have to justify to our own parties and to Parliament whatever stance we take at that time. Clearly, if events were moving in that direction and if the substance of examinations were moving in that direction, it would enable us to give notice in the fifth year if we wanted to and, at the same time, to indicate what would be taking place once notice had been given and what legislative changes and whatever would be required. These are all firm commitments of the Government. In addition, the present legislation establishes an air fares committee. On the deregulation inquiry and in the examination of matters relating to TAA as a public corporation we clearly need people of fair and independent mind who can make their own judgments about what will be in the best interests of Australia's travelling public.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TAX CONCESSIONS FOR THE AUSTRALIAN FILM INDUSTRY

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to reports of the Treasurer's latest and embarrassing contortion in relation to tax concessions for the Australian film industry whereby apparently the Government will now honour its initial undertaking to the industry. Are those reports correct? If so, is it a fact that the total cost of this undertaking is nearly $120m? Is it a fact that it is possible for an individual on the marginal personal tax rate of 60 per cent to rig a $1m outlay to arrange a return that merely breaks even and thereby achieve a handsome saving on tax, at the expense of the rest of the community, of some $600,000? Is it further a fact that because of his latest undertaking these sorts of benefits will be available even where films fail to reach the production stage? Is it a fact that the Government is refusing to divulge the beneficiaries of these extraordinarily generous arrangements and that among the major beneficiaries eligible to draw on the benefits of these arrangements are the large commercial television corporations? Finally, will he state the justification for this undesirable secrecy in view of the opportunity it offers for huge and expensive tax avoidance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very odd circumstance that the thrust of the question of the Leader of the Opposition on this matter concerns the very proper refusal of my colleague, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, to divulge the identity of the companies that have lodged applications. The reason for the ambivalence of the Leader of the Opposition is that the Labor Party cannot make up its mind where it stands on the concession. No doubt the shadow Treasurer will have a few things to say about the taxation aspects. Yet last week the Labor Party spokeswoman on these matters in another place was critical of the fact that the generous concessions that the Leader of the Opposition now, by implication, impugns were not fully met, in her view, by the announcement I made last week. So the Labor Party's ambivalence on this issue is underlined very clearly by the nature of the question of the Leader of the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: I will deal with each element of the question. The effect of the statement that I made yesterday is that people who made investments prior to 27 May-that is, the date the legislation was introduced last week-will have those investments treated for tax purposes fully in the manner outlined in the statement made by the then Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and me on 18 December. That was the intent of the decision that I announced yesterday. An amendment to give effect to that announcement will be introduced in the Committee stage of the debate on the legislation in this place tomorrow. So the Leader of the Opposition and everybody else will be able to see the legislative effect which that decision is given. I stress, in answer to the Leader of the Opposition, that the change I announced last Wednesday will continue to apply in respect of all investments made after 27 May. That change was designed to remove some of the potential for abuse that may have existed had the full effect of the original announcement been maintained.

I have never denied that this is a very generous concession. It is a concession which is, to a particular industry, probably without precedent in our taxation laws. Against that background, I stress that the complaints of some people in the film industry are in fact without substance. So far as the example cited by the Leader of the Opposition-a 150 per cent write-off being available and up to 50 per cent of the amount of the original contribution being exempt from taxation-there can be no argument about that. If a person invests $500,000 in a movie-providing the conditions of the legislation are fulfilled; these involve a number of very important safeguards, particularly in respect of those who made investments prior to 27 May-to qualify for the concession the money must be fully expended on the production of the movie before the end of the financial year following the year in which the investment was made. If the Leader of the Opposition seeks to establish--

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that include the pre-shooting stage?
—It includes all eligible expenditure which is defined both in the Ellicott- Howard statement and in the legislation.
—Prior to shooting?

—If the honourable gentleman will look at the legislation we will be able to save the time of the House by his knowing what the legislation provides. I conclude by saying that I believe the refusal of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to disclose the names of companies that have lodged applications is an entirely proper stance. It involves a question of confidentiality of commercial information between the Government and the people who have sought certification from the Minister under the legislation. When this Bill comes on for debate it will be very interesting to find out where the Labor Party stands on the concession in the legislation.
—I ask the Prime Minister: What is the Government's policy as to overseas aid? Does the Government have a particular percentage of gross domestic product as a target for overseas aid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has had, and Australia has had, a best endeavours policy of reaching 0.7 per cent of gross domestic product by a certain period. In recent years a number of countries, especially because of economic difficulties within their economies, have been providing a lesser percentage than they earlier had. This is one of the matters which has sharpened the North-South debate, the debate between the wealthier and the poorer countries. It is one of the matters that has cast doubts on the credibility of wealthier countries about their real intentions in these matters.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is worth noting that because of financial stringency and even though, by and large, the real value of the aid dollar has been maintained over the past several years, as a proportion of GDP in 1974-75, when the level was 0.56 per cent, the figure has fallen to an estimated level of 0.42 per cent or 0.43 per cent for 1980-81. Whilst by and large the actual real value of the aid vote has been maintained, there has been a relative fall in the proportion of gross domestic product that Australia provides. This trend becomes more marked when our economy is growing strongly. We know the growth figures for the six months to December. We know the estimates of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which place Australia above all other OECD countries in terms of estimated growth throughout this year. There are additional reasons, perhaps, why Australia should seek to set some kind of example in this area.

We need to understand that there are many reasons for aid being provided. There are moral and humanitarian reasons which for many people are sufficient in themselves. There is also, as I believe, a very substantial self-interest reason in helping to promote higher standards of living in many countries-self-interest in terms of promotion of peace and stability but also in terms of encouraging greater growth of economic markets. As a result of the removal of Australia's access to the European Economic Community, if it were not for the newly industrialising countries of Asia and the Pacific we would have been in great difficulty in terms of our own trade. It is those newly industrialising countries that have provided great opportunities for trade. As there is greater economic advancement in more of the developing countries, so those opportunities will be broadened. I believe that there are economic benefits for everyone in relation to that.

There was a report in one of the journals this morning which was, in fact, jumping far ahead of itself. The Minister for Foreign Affairs will have his aid submissions dealt with in the Budget context. I expect that any decisions being made about aid would be largely Budget decisions, although I do not rule out the prospect of some aspects of decisions being made in relation to the Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting in October. Basically, these are Budget matters. They need to be looked at against the total overall context of Australia's requirements and Australia's interests. At the same time, I think we need to understand that this is a serious matter, that the North-South debate has been stalled, and that there is a very real need to promote greater opportunities amongst developing nations, and especially amongst the least developed nations. There is an obligation on all countries, especially relatively wealthy countries such as Australia, not just on a moral and humanitarian basis but also on a self-interest basis. I hope that this might be another matter on which the Australian Labor Party will agree with what I have been saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. In view of the report that the extremely high tides experienced in the upper reaches of Spencer Gulf in South Australia last Monday breached the walls of the tailings dam containing radioactive wastes from the former uranium processing plant at Port Pirie, can the Minister give any information on whether any radioactive material was released into Spencer Gulf? If so, what steps have been taken to eliminate any dangers created by the release of these radioactive materials?

—I do not have available to me today any information on the matter raised by the honourable member. I will investigate it as a matter of urgency and communicate with him to see whether there is any cause for concern about the matters which he has raised.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MALAYSIA: WITHDRAWAL OF ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE AIRCRAFT

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to statements made by the Minister for Defence in Malaysia and Singapore concerning the withdrawal of Royal Australian Air Force aircraft and personnel from Butterworth, Malaysia and Tengah, Singapore, by 1987 at the latest. What information can the Acting Minister for Defence give to the House about the proposed changes in our Butterworth deployment? Will the Government give full consideration to the interests of the 1,200 locally engaged civilians who are employed by the RAAF and other personal domestic staff who are employed by Australian servicemen and who are dependent upon that employment? Can the Minister explain the implications of our changed deployment for the Five-Power Defence Arrangements and the Integrated Air Defence system?

—It is true that my colleague the Minister for Defence is presently in Malaysia and Singapore having discussions on the subject of Mirage squadrons. He has completed discussions with the Malaysian authorities and yesterday he had discussions with the Singaporeans. He is due back in Australia today. The honourable member has raised very important questions-questions which I am sure the Minister has been discussing. I think it would be best for this matter to wait until he can answer it properly. I will make sure that the question is referred to him so that he can give the honourable member a complete answer.

—In answer to a question yesterday the Treasurer indicated that the Government did not intend to honour its commitment to introduce legislation to deal with the matter of rent vis-a-vis taxation in remote areas, which would leave the law as it was when it was interpreted to the disadvantage of miners and caused serious problems in Australia last year. I ask: Does the agreement between the Treasurer and the Commissioner of Taxation to ignore the law as interpreted constitute a satisfactory means of dealing with a government promise in an area as sensitive as taxation? Would such an agreement by the Taxation Commissioner be open to challenge as a breach of the taxation Acts? Will the Treasurer as a matter of urgency bring in legislation to deal with the matter so that there can be no suggestion of the Taxation Commissioner's position being compromised and no suggestion that the tax will be applied? The Commissioner has been compromised by being asked to ignore the law.

—With great respect, the honourable member for Corio is wrong. I did not say yesterday that we would not meet the arrangement that was concluded last October. I said that that legislation would not be introduced during this session of the Parliament. It is the intention of the Government, and always has been, to legislate to give effect to the arrangement that was made last October when that unfortunate dispute was settled. We would expect that when the legislation is introduced it will have the total support of the Opposition in putting it through the Parliament. In response to the honourable member for Griffith I indicated yesterday that the Commissioner of Taxation had informed me that the taxation law, pending the introduction of the legislation, would be administered in a common sense fashion and it would be patently ridiculous for it to be administered contrary to the understanding which the honourable gentleman is aware of and which is patently in opposition to the expressed wishes of everybody in this House.

—Can the Minister for the Capital Territory inform the House who will be the next permanent head of the Department of the Capital Territory? Further, will the Minister and the new permanent head ensure that the interests of Queanbeyan are fully considered in all policy decisions affecting the Australian Capital Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Eden-Monaro for the question. It gives me very great pleasure to inform the House, the people of the Australian Capital Territory and, indeed, the people of Australia that the next permanent head of the Department of the Capital Territory will be Mr Tony Blunn. He will succeed that very great Australian and most distinguished Commonwealth public servant, Mr Laurie Daniels, C.B., O.B.E., who retires on 10 August next. I have every confidence and, I believe, this would be accepted on all sides of politics, that Mr Blunn will be a most worthy successor to Mr Daniels.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the second part of the honourable member's question, I draw attention to the fact that I do recognise, as a result of strong representations by the honourable member, that the interests of Queanbeyan are very closely interrelated to the interests of the Australian Capital Territory. A very substantial number of people reside in Queanbeyan but work in the national capital. It is impossible to consider the future of the Australian Capital Territory without having regard to the interests of Queanbeyan. The interests are identical economically, socially and in many other ways. I am somewhat surprised that members of the Australian Labor Party do not regard this matter seriously. I assure them that I do. I assure the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, the Mayor of Queanbeyan and others living in that area that while I have had the honour to be the Minister for the Capital Territory I have accepted the point that, economically, what is good for Canberra will be good for Queanbeyan. In every decision that I am called upon to make relating to the Australian Capital Territory I will respond to representations which are made by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, who has been a most assiduous worker for the welfare of the citizens of the City of Queanbeyan.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister will end his answer.
—I only regret that the Labor Party does not regard Queanbeyan as importantly as do the honourable member and I.
—I direct my question to the Minister for Housing and Construction.
—Order! The House will come to order. Does the honourable member for Capricornia wish to reconsider?

—It has taken me a long time to get up the courage. Can the Minister for Housing and Construction confirm a statement made by Mr Barry Carlton of the Permanent Building Societies Association Ltd that some societies have put a freeze on lending and have imposed tough eligibility conditions such as a constant deposit level of at least $5,000? Does he accept the view of Mr Carlton that the building societies have been hard hit by the deregulation of bank interest rates and are unable to compete with finance companies offering 15.5 per cent? If so, what measures does the Government intend to take to ensure availability of housing finance at a reasonable price for low and middle income earners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Capricornia is jittery I will treat him like a lamb. The fact is, as he said, that there is a problem of permanent building societies in New South Wales and Queensland attracting sufficient funds. The problem, of course, stems from the decisions of the respective State governments to control lending and borrowing rates by the building societies. I suggest, therefore, that those States give consideration to adopting the policies which are relevant in other States. Yesterday I said to the House that we have to look at the total amount of finance available for home borrowers. There was a slight decrease of 3 per cent in the March quarter of this year compared with the March quarter of last year.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member asked about loan funds being made available to medium income and low income families. I hope that the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, which is a very generous agreement, will be piloted through the Senate today. I hope that the States will take up the challenge given to them by the Commonwealth to be responsible for the development of initiatives. Never before have they had the opportunity to prove that they are interested in welfare housing.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BEEF SALES TO THE REPUBLIC OF KOREA

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minster for Trade and Resources inform the House of the latest developments in the Korean beef market and the extent to which Australian beef exporters have been successful in gaining re-entry to the Korean market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to say that the Republic of Korea has re-entered the Australian meat trade after being out of it for the last two years. Korea was a significant market in the 1976, 1977 and 1978 period but because of domestic meat marketing problems and a very tight balance of payments situation Korea cut out any importation of meat from Australia. In March this year it issued tenders for meat and an Australian company won the contract for 4,500 tonnes. Korea issued another tender in April and Australia won a contract for a further 4,000 tonnes. A tender is now out for another 4,000 tonnes and I am very hopeful that the Australian industry will be able to get the contract. The Government, of course, was working closely with the Korean Government during the period that we were not able to get access. It is now a very valuable market because the international market for meat is soft; the American market has been very slack, and the Japanese market also has been cutting back on the importation of chilled meat. This additional sale to Korea is very welcome.

—Does the Minister for Foreign Affairs still maintain the correctness of his Government's policy of unequivocal support for President Reagan's policy of providing armaments and military advisers to the present military junta in El Salvador? Is he not concerned that Australia is one of the few Western nations publicly to endorse all aspects of President Reagan's policy? Does he believe that Australia's policy should be modified at least to give support to the recommendations of the United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the United States House of Representatives Foreign Affairs Committee, which latter Committee voted 11 to one to cut off United States aid and to withdraw United States advisers from El Salvador unless President Duarte certifies in writing that his Government can control its armed forces, observes basic human rights and is making progress on political reform? If Australia's present policy in respect of United States intervention in El Salvador is not modified, is he not concerned that Australia's general standing on human rights issues will be seriously undermined both in the United Nations and in other world assemblies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point I want to make is that Australia has made known its opposition to violations of human rights in El Salvador to the United Nations and, in particular, the United Nations Commission for Human Rights. As long as the present situation exists we will continue to make our views known. The second point I want to make is that the honourable gentleman is not correct in referring to Australia's unequivocal support for the policies of the United States of America in El Salvador. What we have said is that we understand completely the view of the United States Administration that externally supplied military aid should be cut off; that it is a source of instability in Central America. We have said further that we believe the problems of El Salvador have to be attacked at two levels. One is to cut off supplies of foreign-supplied military aid, to which I have referred, and the other is to support social and economic reform. So long as a situation of terrorism and violence prevails, it is extremely difficult to get the social and economic reform that is needed.

ANSWER.PARA: It was made clear to me in my discussions with Vice-President Bush in Washington a few months ago that the United States Administration shares the view that the problem has to be tackled at two levels. In fact, quite recently the United States Administration made a gift of civil aid to El Salvador of about $US126m. Until the acts of terrorism and violence are contained it will be very difficult to make the social and economic progress we would all wish to see in that violence-ravaged country. The United States Government by its recent gift of civil aid, clearly recognises that there is a dual problem.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW ZEALAND: IMPORTATION OF AUSTRALIAN WINE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister, refers to his recent trip to New Zealand and his discussions on matters involving a closer economic relationship. Does he regard the current New Zealand attitude on the possible increase in importation of Australian white wines as being quite extraordinary? Does he see any chance of a change in the New Zealand attitude?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of my recent discussions in New Zealand on the closer economic relationship, the recent decision by the equivalent New Zealand body to the Industries Assistance Commission to increase protection for New Zealand's wine industry was a matter of concern. Certainly it has been an impediment in the development of that market, particularly for the cheaper casket and pack wines. The increases in duty levels are of several hundred per cent, and that will make the sale of that wine very difficult. However, New Zealand does argue strongly that it has increased the import licences from $6m to $10m a year, which will mean that the Australian wine industry will be able to penetrate the market with the higher quality wines and should make more extensive sales in terms of value than had previously been the case. However, because of the irritation and because of the difficulties that have been created, I have arranged for the two wine industry bodies to meet and discuss the issue to see whether they cannot work out what might be a suitable accommodation of both industries' points of view.

—I draw the Prime Minister's attention to the various bans and limitations that were placed on shipping, trade and personal exchange visits with the Soviet Union following that nation's invasion of Afghanistan some 18 months ago. One of the bans affected the operation of Russian cruise ships out of Australian ports, which until that time had been providing reasonably priced cruises through the CTC travel organisation for Australian travellers. In view of the fact that other shipping and trade bans imposed on the Soviet Union at that time have been lifted, will the Government now give approval for Soviet cruise ships to operate again from Australian ports?

—The decisions the Government took in relation to this matter followed decisions taken in the United States and Canada which made it quite plain that the continuation of some aspects of Australia's earlier position were no longer tenable. Going beyond that, no further decisions remain; the position is as it was. It is worth reminding the House that the Soviet invasion and occupation of Afghanistan continues. There is still a very great degree of continued fighting, with the Soviet Union having great difficulty establishing its own order in that area. The decisions taken were taken as a consequence of decisions in Canada and the United States of America which would have made quite futile the maintenance of Australia's earlier position.

—I direct my question to the Acting Minister for Primary Industry. What additional costs are likely to result firstly to the Government, secondly to the Australian Wool Corporation, thirdly to wool growers and fourthly to wool users because of the disposal of the Australian Wool Testing Authority? In particular, will the Minister comment on the recent statement by Mr David Asimus, the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, that all alternatives would result in an increase in costs to the industry with no discernible benefit to it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice, and certainly I have had only telephone discussions with the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, is that the basis of sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority and its intended operation will result in very little net increase, if any, in costs to growers. The terms and conditions of the sale and the arrangements by which the body to continue the responsibilities of the Australian Wool Testing Authority are to be constituted are still to be concluded. Indeed, the Government's objective, as a result of discussions that have been held between my colleague the Minister for Primary Industry and, I believe, the Prime Minister with representatives of the Australian Wool Council, resulted in an agreement that there would be consultations with the industry throughout the period to determine just what alternative body would be constituted.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's objective is to ensure that what is essentially a body operating in a market place should do just that, that funds presently used for that purpose through the Australian Wool Corporation should, if possible, be freed for growers' benefit within the Corporation and that the private enterprise operation which in many respects is the responsibility of the Australian Wool Testing Authority be reconstituted in such a way that without net additional cost the growers can receive the same service and the body itself can be constituted independently altogether from the Australian Wool Corporation but with an association with it.

I believe the discussions have not yet reached the point where the final structure of that body can be defined, but I have little doubt that the net benefit will be that the body itself will certainly retain the stature, reputation and service now maintained by the Australian Wool Testing Authority but with little additional cost, if any, to the Australian wool growing community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. Is there any provision for immunity from the law for cadets at the Royal Military College, Duntroon, who commit offences against citizens in the Australian Capital Territory? Is the Minister aware that in May 1978 cadets detonated a bomb within one of the halls of residence at the Australian National University; that in a Canberra suburb in Easter 1980 three cadets shot up a car belonging to a civilian who was a former cadet; and that recently on Sunday, May--

—Order! I cannot allow a request for information, which is a question, to amount to a recitation of allegations about a group in the community. That is not the purpose of Question Time. The honourable gentleman should rephrase his question.
—I will. I have asked the Minister whether he is aware of these facts.
—The honourable member asserts they are facts. I have no knowledge that they are facts.

—Well, last Sunday six cadets raided the camp of anti-uranium protesters outside Parliament House and stole their banners. Will the Minister indicate whether any police charges were laid in connection with any of these offences? If not, why not? Does the Minister agree that detonating bombs, shooting up cars and stealing private property should be regarded as high spirited pranks, as some of the authorities do?

—I am trying to restrain my temper. The purpose of the honourable member in asking the question escapes me. If it is to defame an honourable institution and the cadets in it, it does him no credit at all.

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. With respect, very serious matters have been raised implying breaches of criminal law. I suggest that they ought to be treated seriously and investigated instead of the Minister's seeking to impugn the character of the honourable member for Fraser. They are very serious matters. The Minister is behaving like a clown.
—There is no point of order.

—I intended to come to the question that the honourable member asked. I have no knowledge of the acts that the honourable member asked about except the allegations that were made in regard to the prank that was carried out against the people who were demonstrating opposite Parliament House. The facts as I have been advised are that no charges were laid by the police in regard to this prank. I have also been advised that the Commandant of the Royal Military College--
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The honourable member for Fraser has outlined what he considers to be rather serious criminal matters. The Minister keeps referring to them as pranks.
—There is no point of order.

—I am also advised that the Commandant of the Royal Military College has investigated the prank that occurred outside this House and took appropriate action under the Royal Military College standing orders against the cadets concerned.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Is it a fact that police commissioners in Australia have expressed concern at the ease with which machine guns and military-type weapons are available in this country? What action, if any, has been taken to allay that concern?

—It is true that the police commissioners have expressed concern about the availability of military-type automatic weapons to people in this country. The Government shares that concern. I do not think there is any threat of danger--
—The police think-
—The honourable member for Grayndler will cease interjecting.
—Because he is a ratbag.
—Order! It does not contribute to the conduct of the House if a person whom I do not identify by his voice uses a term like that.
—Mr Speaker, I said it and I apologise.

—I was saying that the Government shares the concern of the police commissioners. The threat of the continued importation of weapons of a high-powered automatic nature for sale to and use by private individuals is not desirable. I mentioned in the House, in answer to a previous question, that I intended to raise this matter at the Police Ministers Council. I did so at the conference that was held last Friday. I report to the House that there is general agreement amongst the Ministers that there is a need to take a common approach in the management of firearms in Australia, and they will be taking this matter back to their respective governments. I also report to the House that I told the Police Ministers Council that the Commonwealth Government intended to act to ban the importation of automatic and semi-automatic weapons of a military nature. My colleague, the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, will be taking action under his Customs powers to carry out that ban on those weapons. This is a controversial subject. I took the opportunity of speaking to national representatives of the Sporting Shooters Association of Australia. I think that in those discussions there was general agreement that there was a need for the Government to take this action against military-type automatic weapons.

—For the information of honourable members, I present the report of the Administrative Review Council on the Defence Force Ombudsman. The Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) will be making a statement later outlining the Government's proposals to implement the recommendations contained in the report. The Government is in this case taking the unusual step of tabling the report in manuscript form prior to printing. This is being done to ensure that there will be an opportunity for honourable members and all other interested parties to peruse the recommendations made by the Administrative Review Council in conjunction with the Government's proposals in relation to those recommendations. Limited copies of the report will be available in the Bills and Papers Office, the Senate Records Office and in the Parliamentary Library. I hope to be able to make printed copies available shortly.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Hayden-Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a short statement.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable gentleman I remind him that he has not indicated the nature of the statement he wishes to make. The honourable gentleman should identify the subject of the statement.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Hayden-Mr Speaker, I want to refer to the extraordinary casual response of the Minister for Administrative Services to the question asked by the honourable member for Fraser. Very serious allegations were implicit in that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—Leave is not granted. The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.

—For the information of honourable members I present the third annual report of the Department of the Parliamentary Library for the calendar year 1980. The report makes it clear that this Parliament has library and research services which serve it in an excellent manner and which rank amongst the best of their kind to be found in any parliament. Much attention is given by the Library to forward planning, taking into account the need of modern democratic institutions for reliable, accurate and prompt information services, free of bias or partisan views and accessible beyond the limits of this or the proposed new building or even this city. Recently, other parliamentary libraries have started to explore with our Library ways in which they could share resources through computerised network systems. Such an arrangement would benefit all participants and greatly enhance the amount of relevant information available. I am sure that all honourable members would wish me to thank the Library Committee for its services and progressive approach and to congratulate the Parliamentary Library staff on their achievements during the past year.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH EDUCATION POLICY AND FINANCIAL GUIDELINES TO THE COMMONWEALTH EDUCATION COMMISSIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-The purpose of this statement is to announce the Government's decisions on guidelines for its major education programs in 1982 and, as appropriate for the triennium 1982-84, against the background of the recent triennial reports of the Tertiary Education Commission and the School Commission and of the Government's decisions on the Review of Commonwealth Functions. In that context, we have given further consideration to the report of the National Inquiry into Teacher Education and have undertaken a review of education and training opportunities for youth.

SPEECH.PARA: The overall financial outcome for 1982 for Commonwealth programs administered by the education commissions is that total spending will be maintained at the 1981 level in real terms with the cost of election initiatives provided as an addition. There will, however, be some reallocation of resources between areas reflecting the Commonwealth's approach to priorities. The total sums to be made available for 1982, in out-turn prices, will be $1,867.6m for tertiary programs and $1,003.6m for schools programs-an overall total of $2,871.2m and an increase over 1981 of 1.5 per cent in real terms. The present practice under which programs are supplemented retrospectively for cost increases will be changed so that a prospective allowance is built into the figures in advance to take account of cost increases.
Commonwealth's Role in Education

The States have the primary responsibility for the administration and delivery of educational services, particularly at the schools level. The Commonwealth provides full funding for universities and colleges of advanced education and supplementary funds for quality improvement, for general development and for priority areas in schools and colleges of technical and further education. The Commonwealth believes it has a particular role in identifying and bringing resources to bear on educational issues of national importance. We have been reviewing our priorities across the range of tertiary and schools programs and have taken some decisions on the reallocation of resources. As set out in our 1980 election policy, we will continue our extensive support for education with increased emphasis on vocational and technical training. We will give greater priority to the school to work transition program, to the education of migrants, and to the handicapped.
Review of Commonwealth Functions

In the application of its policy of maximum expenditure restraint, the Government has already announced a number of decisions on education arising from the Review of Commonwealth Functions, and action to put these into effect is proceeding. Tuition fees will not be reintroduced for the majority of students-those taking first qualifications or recognised combined degrees and diplomas-in universities and colleges of advanced education.
