Fees will apply for second and higher degree students; this is in practice a very limited basis and reflects the Government's view that the principle of free tertiary education should be restricted to a basic qualification. Beyond that, those who wish to further their tertiary studies should pay fees, which in any event will represent only a minor proportion of the full costs of that tertiary study. The arrangements will be phased in, so that students already on course will be exempt. The Government plans a new initiative to assist tertiary students; it proposes to introduce, from the beginning of 1982, a loans scheme which will be in addition to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and not in substitution for it. Details of both these decisions will be announced as soon as possible.

The Curriculum Development Centre is to be abolished unless State governments agree to meet 50 per cent of the cost of the Centre's operations. I have sought the views of State education Ministers, and several have requested further clarification of what is proposed. I have proposed a meeting of officers to discuss funding, management and other implications if the CDC were to continue as a joint responsibility of the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory. Whatever the final decision on the future of the CDC, I want to reiterate that the Commonwealth will continue to be prepared to share in the costs of curriculum projects sponsored by the Australian Education Council and in any projects it assesses as being of national significance that are not so regarded by the AEC. Whilst the Government has decided to abolish the Education Research and Development Committee and its special research program, some funds for education research will be available under co-ordinated arrangements across the education portfolio. Projects currently supported under ERDC grants will be maintained until the end of 1981 and further funding will be available to meet contractual obligations during a phasing-out period.

The Government also announced in the context of its Review of Commonwealth Functions that it was concerned at the proliferation of separate tertiary institutions, and it has taken prompt action to provide for more efficient use of resources. Both this and the Government's decision to reduce the involvement of the Commonwealth Schools Commission in program administration will be discussed later in this statement. Consistent with the Government's approach to seek greater identification of its very considerable support for education, we have decided to include the word 'Commonwealth' in the titles of the Schools Commission and the Tertiary Education Commission. This change is provided for in the Statute Law Revision Bill 1981 recently introduced.
Review of Opportunities for Youth and Transition Program

The review of education and training opportunities for young people, announced on 16 January 1981 by the then Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and myself, has been considered by the Government in the context of deciding on guidelines for the education commissions for 1982 programs. The review was undertaken because of concern to find alternative approaches for those young people who leave school ill prepared for work and with inadequate educational standards. The Schools Commission in its recent report 'Schooling for 15 and 16 Year Olds' concluded that 'in their general orientation, most schools lag in their adjustment to the needs of the full range of students'. The report goes on to comment that secondary schools seem preoccupied with preparation for tertiary study.

Against this background, the Government wishes to accelerate the development of appropriate transition courses in secondary schools, with emphasis on basic changes in curricula relevant particularly to the needs of low achievers. We will be pursuing this through the Australian Education Council. With a view to encouraging more early school leavers to continue their education, we will also promote in TAFE colleges the development of courses to meet a wider range of vocational needs. In addition to the trades area, it is particularly important to expand vocational education relevant to occupations which require skill but are not apprenticeable trades. These two initiatives together represent the first step in improving the prospects of young people 'at risk', including both those in school who are tempted to leave early and those who have already tried unsuccessfully to obtain work.

The review of education and training opportunities was undertaken against the background of the announcement by the Commonwealth in November 1979 of the introduction of the school to work transition program for young people aged 15 to 19 who were likely to be 'at risk' in the transition process. At that time the Commonwealth and States had agreed that concerted action should be taken from both quarters. The Commonwealth undertook to provide a total of $150m in real terms over five years from 1980 for the program and asked the States to match this expenditure dollar for dollar for government schools and TAFE colleges from 1982 onwards. This was designed to provide a total additional effort costing $250m over the five-year period. The program commenced in 1980, and the Commonwealth continued it in 1981 without a State contribution for that year. Although the program is still being developed, all State Ministers have reported an excellent response to it. A large number of transition courses and activities have been initiated or expanded in government and non-government secondary schools and in TAFE colleges.

It is expected that approximately 5,900 young people will undertake full time TAFE courses of up to one year's duration under the program in 1981. At least 8,000 students in secondary schools are undertaking alternative courses receiving significant financial support under the program. In addition, many thousands of young people are being assisted through improvement and expansion of such activities as vocational guidance and counselling services, work experience schemes, link courses and alternative course curriculum development. However, to date the States have not been prepared to indicate their readiness to make additional contributions to match the Commonwealth's expenditure, which was $15.7m in 1980 and is estimated at $25m in 1981 for government schools and TAFE. This has meant that the transition program has not helped as many young people as the Government envisaged when it was introduced.

Accordingly, we feel compelled to take special action to increase significantly the resources devoted to transition activities. Up to $75.4m will now be allocated in 1982. Specifically, we have decided to earmark up to $27m within Commonwealth general recurrent grants to the States for government schools in 1982 for expenditure on the transition program in secondary schools. The Commonwealth's direct expenditure of $27m on the transition program in 1982 will then be directed to TAFE. If, however, the States increase their own expenditure on transition, this will be offset against the sum to be earmarked. Whatever the States decide, the total recurrent expenditure on transition in the government sector in the States and the Northern Territory in 1982 will be brought up to $54m, the level originally envisaged in the Commonwealth's November 1979 statement. Non-government schools will continue to receive grants from the Commonwealth under the program as originally intended. These will amount to $2.4m in 1982.

Within the total of $27m to be earmarked from the Commonwealth Schools Commission general recurrent program for expenditure on transition activities, a component of about $9m will be set aside for cash grants to government secondary schools boards or committees at the rate of $10 per pupil-$500 minimum per school. These funds will be able to be spent on a wide range of activities in the transition area subject to guidelines to be developed in consultation with the States. The Government's purpose here is to ensure that all government secondary schools have an opportunity to participate in the transition program and to encourage school communities to take an active interest in the program. Similar provisions for the Australian Capital Territory will be considered in the Budget context.

As a further indication of the Commonwealth's commitment to this priority area, we propose to earmark 15 per cent, about $19m, of the government schools capital program for equipment and facilities for transition education in secondary schools in 1982. We shall also ask the Commonwealth Schools Commission to consult with non-government schools and to consider ways, within current allocations and commitments, of ensuring that the activities of these schools in the transition area are given high priority. The net effect of these measures will be to more than double the resources to be devoted to the transition program in 1982 as compared with 1981. The capacity of TAFE and of secondary schools to admit students to transition courses will be very greatly enlarged as was foreshadowed in the 16 January announcement of the review of education and training opportunities.

Through these changes the Commonwealth hopes to see more young people who may be at risk in the transition process staying on to complete their secondary education and/or pursuing further study in TAFE. In all of this we are endeavouring to assist the education system to do a better job in serving the needs of all children and in maintaining their interest in formal education. The objective is to improve the basic skills and employment prospects of young people as they leave the education system, particularly in the face of a decline in the number of unskilled jobs in the community. A second step in alleviating the problems faced by young people is to ensure that there is an adequate system of financial support for those undertaking education and training.

The Government is also very concerned about young people who have already left school and are having difficulty in finding work. Improved training subsidies were introduced following the announcement of the Government's commitment to youth policy in October 1980. These have made an immediate impact in meeting the needs of the longer term young unemployed. The Government will continue to pursue the program and promote it vigorously so that as many young people as possible can be assisted. The Commonwealth has recently introduced a new transition allowance-at the level of unemployment benefit plus $6 per week-to encourage young people who have been unemployed for some time to take up transition or other TAFE courses. This allowance has been paid from the beginning of the current academic year.

Among the young unemployed there are those who are severely disadvantaged and for whom further education or work experience would be insufficient. These young people may need other forms of assistance. The reasons for their disadvantage are numerous, but generally include a range of physical, mental or social handicaps that combine to deny them the ability to compete on the open labour market. My colleagues, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) will be giving further consideration to this issue. The Government is particularly concerned to ensure the adequacy of allowances for low income families and other disadvantaged groups. Young people should not be forced into unemployment benefit, or prematurely into the work force, because their families are unable to support them. We will be giving further consideration to the range of allowances for young people in the Budget context. The Government also has under review the payment of unemployment benefit to 16 and 17-year-olds. The Government restates its position that no adverse changes to unemployment benefit will be made unless better alternatives are available to the young people affected and the Government is satisfied that the interests of low income families and other disadvantaged groups would be protected.

The Government will be giving further consideration to the development of more comprehensive arrangements for young people as they make the transition from school to work or further education and training. Our objective is to bring about a substantial shift of emphasis within schools. We will co-operate with the States, through the Australian Education Council, in efforts in this direction and will invite the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to share in this endeavour. The Government has noted and will give careful consideration to the report which has just been handed down by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts entitled 'Preparation for the Work Force'.
National Inquiry into Teacher Education

As part of its review of policy directions the Government has consulted the States on the report of the national inquiry into teacher education. The Australian Education Council has accepted that, since the quality of school education is in turn dependent on the quality of teachers, teacher development should be a continuous process of pre-service education, induction and in-service activities. Implementation of most of the report's recommendations will be the responsibility of employing authorities and tertiary institutions. The Commonwealth has examined its direct financial contributions in these areas as part of its consideration of the forward programs for the education commissions. Specifically, the Commonwealth will continue to provide for professional development programs for teachers in 1982, including grants to education centres within the Schools Commission's program, at the level of $17.5m in 1982. The Commonwealth does, however, see in-service education as the responsibility of the employing authorities.
Programs Administered by the Education Commissions

The guidelines set out the total funding levels to be made available for the programs administered by the Commonwealth education commissions, which will report back in the forthcoming Budget sittings of Parliament on the detailed allocation of these funds. The decisions on the commissions' reports have been taken in the context of Commonwealth policies as outlined previously. They also reflect the advent of stabilised enrolments in higher education. Despite the Government's hopes for greater retention in secondary schools and the enrolment pressures in the non-government sector, we expect that there will be a continued decline in overall school enrolments due to demographic factors. I will seek leave at the conclusion of my statement to have the guidelines and other attachments incorporated in Hansard.
Cost Adjustment Procedures

The Government has decided to adopt a new method of cost adjustment for the programs administered by the Commonwealth education commissions. From the beginning of 1982 a prospective allowance will be made to take account of forecast cost increases in substitution for the previous arrangement whereby costs have been adjusted on a retrospective basis. In adopting this new arrangement, the Government has taken a more rigorous approach towards cost adjustment which in the past has provided additional funds automatically and has had a tendency to insulate educational institutions from the effects of inflation and from the need to contain excessive wage claims. It is designed also to encourage greater efficiency in institutions. The new arrangements will reduce the need for frequent amendments to legislation which were necessary under the previous retrospective cost adjustment arrangements. The following amounts, which include a prospective allowance for cost adjustment, will be provided in 1982, in comparison with 1981. I seek leave to have a table detailing these amounts incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Tertiary Programs

When it announced its decisions on the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Government stated that it had been concerned at the proliferation of separate higher education institutions and proposed immediate action to reverse this trend and to provide for more efficient use of resources. The Government announced that, arising from the recommendations of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, it would promote a major rationalisation and reallocation of resources in higher education. This will involve: Consolidation into larger units of 30 colleges of advanced education for which teacher education is the main activity by their incorporation into multi-purpose or multi-campus colleges with a single governing body or by integration with neighbouring universities; redirection of effort in advanced education from teacher education to the technologies and business studies and reallocation of resources to occur in and between universities, as necessary; the provision of additional resources for colleges of advanced education which are able to expand their effort in the technologies and business studies-having regard to the recommendations of the Commission, an amount of $5m has been earmarked within the general recurrent grants for advanced education in the years 1982 and 1983 for this purpose; phasing out of the engineering schools at Deakin University, Bendigo College of Advanced Education and Preston Institute of Technology, with no new students admitted after 1981-the future role of the engineering school at Caulfield Institute of Technology is to be examined; and the assessment of grants for the University of Western Australia and Murdoch University to be based on a greater sharing of resources and collaboration between these two institutions.

In connection with the consolidation of colleges of advanced education, the Government announced its intention to reach agreement with each State concerning rationalisation measures by the end of 1981. If this could not be done, the Commonwealth would not be prepared to continue recurrent funding for the colleges concerned after the end of 1981. If a State government wished these colleges to continue as separate entities it would have to make its own separate financial provision. The list of the 30 colleges concerned is part of attachment I. The Government intends that the consolidation of institutions should result in genuine amalgamations with one governing body and a real saving of resources. In determining the level of recurrent funds for 1982-84 the Government has taken account of such savings in respect of institutions which have been or will be consolidated during the triennium. The Government will expect the Commission to continue to promote the most efficient use of resources available for tertiary education and requests it to consider the opportunities for greater efficiency and savings by reducing unnecessary duplication of effort among faculties and schools. The Government will continue to look to the Commission to provide on-going advice on the relationship of manpower supply to demand in areas which are critical for education planning.

When the Government announced its Review of Commonwealth Functions decisions, it noted that some action has already been taken in the States on consolidation. Since that announcement, further steps have been announced by some States. In view of the progress which has been made towards consolidation and the need for the changes to be taken into account in legislation during the 1981 Budget sittings, the Commission is asked to provide me with a progress report on consolidation by 30 June. I should add that whilst the principle of rationalisation and the timetable are not negotiable from the Commonwealth's viewpoint, the Government is willing to discuss with the States particular arrangements in relation to individual institutions. Funds have been provided for the Government's 1980 election commitments for the establishment of research centres of excellence in universities; the development of community language courses in universities and/or colleges of advanced education and the provision of 350 additional basic nurse training places in colleges of advanced education, including the establishment of new pilot courses in Tasmania and Queensland.

The Government has reviewed the existing scheme of assistance under which teacher education courses in certain non-government teachers colleges receive up to 50 per cent of the recurrent costs of teacher education courses in colleges of advanced education and has decided that from 1982 these will be fully supported. Provision has been made in the total allocation for this purpose. The Government also considers that non-government teachers' colleges should be eligible for consideration for capital grants within the total funds available. The Commission is asked to advise on the implementation of this decision after consultation with State authorities and the institutions concerned. The Government asks that, within the level of funds available, the Commission should give consideration to the establishment of a national school of fisheries. The Commission is requested in particular to advise on the desirability of locating the school in Tasmania.

The Government has announced in the Review of Commonwealth Functions context that it does not see a need for a university in the Northern Territory at this time and will not be providing funds for this purpose in the forthcoming triennium. The Government has asked the Tertiary Education Commission for a detailed report and expects to receive and release this shortly. Special provision has been made for the Australian Maritime College which is still in its developmental stage. For equipment expenditure in universities and colleges of advanced education, the allocations for 1982 include an additional $4.2m to assist institutions in replacing outdated equipment and in responding to needs arising from technological change. While the total grants for capital programs for these institutions will decline by $5.6m, there will be some provision for high priority projects to commence in 1982 as a result of a lower expenditure commitment to ongoing projects.

The Government has noted the Commission's recommendation that additional funds be provided in 1983 and 1984 to higher education institutions for superannuation purposes. This matter requires special consideration and is being examined separately by the Government. The Government has confirmed its commitment to the triennial principle which it reintroduced at the beginning of the present triennium. Recurrent programs for universities and colleges of advanced education will be funded on a fixed triennial basis for the 1982-84 triennium so that base recurrent programs will be maintained at the 1982 level. The Commission's recommendation that triennial funding be extended to include TAFE recurrent programs and all equipment programs has not been taken up, as it would be inappropriate in view of the Government's policy of minimising forward commitments into future budgets in the interests of maximising budgetary flexibility.

The Government has allocated $206.8m for TAFE in 1982. This represents an increase of $11.7m and emphasises the importance the Government places on vocational and technical education. The 1982 allocation for TAFE recurrent programs consists of $59.4m for general recurrent and $25.2m for specific purpose recurrent programs. The increase for these latter programs will enable the Commission to develop programs for quality improvement in TAFE as advocated by the Williams report and by the Commission. The Government agrees that the Commission's recommendations on the distribution of these funds should take account of the record of individual States' own efforts for quality improvement in TAFE and for equipment and capital in TAFE. The TAFE Council undertook a review of the equipment needs in TAFE and recommended the establishment of a TAFE equipment program in 1982. The Government has allocated $10.1m for this purpose. These funds will assist the States in meeting the need for updated equipment, particularly in the technologies.

For 1982, $112.1m has been provided for capital programs. Of this amount, $21.4m represents the final instalment under the Government's original supplementary '$50m' grant over the period 1979 to 1982. Although the total allocation is slightly less than in 1981 it will enable expenditure of about $37m on new projects in 1982. The cost of the election commitments in the tertiary area in 1982 is being provided as an addition to the overall 1981 level of expenditure in real terms. However, there has been a reassessment of priorities within the program. Additional funds are to be made available in 1982 for general and special purpose recurrent grants and for equipment in the TAFE sector and also for equipment and certain non-government teachers colleges and the Australian Maritime College in the higher education sector. This has required a reduction in capital allocations for both sectors and in the basic recurrent grants for universities and colleges of advanced education.
Schools Programs

As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, there will be a reduction in the School Commission's direct involvement in program administration and information collection and the activities of its State offices will be scaled down. The buildings unit in the central office has been disbanded. The Commission is asked to achieve these objectives through modifications to the administration of its special purpose programs, including reductions in the requirements presently placed on State and non-government school authorities. Measures to be adopted will include a substantial relaxation of the program guidelines and the abolition or consolidation of some committees.

At the same time, the Commonwealth will continue its involvement in the determination of priorities in a number of program areas through the Schools Commission and will retain educational and financial accountability requirements for all programs. Further details of these measures are set out in Attachment V. The Schools Commission will continue in its role of advising the Government on the needs of both government and non-government schools. Against the background of overall financial restraint the Commonwealth has been reveiwing its priorities while maintaining its total schools spending in real terms. As indicated earlier, we have decided to direct more resources into the transition area, to migrant education, the country areas program and special education in non-government schools. A small reduction has been made in the government schools capital program and savings will accrue from the termination of the innovations program from the end of 1981.

In the Review of Commonwealth Functions, we decided that both government and non-government school building projects being supported with Commonwealth funds should not exceed certain standards developed in a co-operative Commonwealth-State school building standards study. The Commonwealth Schools Commission is being asked to give effect to this decision from the beginning of 1982. In the funding of government schools, the Commonwealth will continue to determine its contribution in the Budget context each year and will not be tying its grants to a fixed standard of services, as proposed by the Commission. It has maintained the real level of these grants for 1982 notwithstanding the expected further decline in enrolments. In making its recommendations on the distribution of general resources funds, the Commission should note that the Government has decided to discontinue the present arrangement which permits States to seek transfers of amounts between general recurrent and capital allocations. These amounts have been determined by the Commonwealth in the light of its assessment of needs and priorities for those programs and therefore should not be redistributed on any other basis.

For non-government schools the Government will meet its election commitments to maintain the percentage link between its general recurrent grants and average government schools standard costs and to compress the existing six subsidy levels to three. The latter will be achieved by combining the existing levels 1 to 3 into a new group 1, levels 4 and 5 into a new group 2, and level 6 will become the new group 3. The 1982 per capita rates for the new group 1, 2 and 3 schools will be 20 per cent, 30 per cent, and 38 per cent respectively of average government schools standard costs. Per capita subsidies for group 3 schools will be raised to 40 per cent of average government schools costs in 1983. The estimated additional cost of these provisions will be $25.9m in 1982, subject to actual enrolments. The Government has accepted a number of the Commonwealth Schools Commission's recommendations for changes in the per capita grants scheme for non-government schools to the extent that these do not conflict with the Government's basic policies. These are detailed in the attached guidelines.

In recognition of the fact that some non-systemic non-government schools would be reclassified to a lower subsidy level as a result of the approved changes, the Minister, on the advice of the Schools Commission and its State planning and finance committees, will permit those schools to remain at a higher subsidy level for up to two years until they adapt their resources to the new arrangements. The Government will review any cases where this is not achievable within two years. The Commission, through its State planning and finance committees, is to give consideration to school income as well as expenditure in the assessment of subsidy levels but the assessment will continue to be based primarily on recurrent expenditure. Principles to be used for this change will be approved by the Minister following consultation by the Commission with non-government school authorities. Any subsequent changes in schools' subsidy levels will continue to be subject to ministerial approval following advice from the Commission.

The present provisions for new non-systemic schools will be varied so that they receive supplementary establishment grants over and above the general recurrent subsidy for the first four years at the rates of 10 per cent, 7.5 per cent, 5 per cent and 2.5 per cent respectively of government schools' standard costs. The Government has not accepted the proposal to base its grants on a fixed standard based on the Commission's proposed 'basket of services'. This would represent a fundamental departure from the Government's long-standing policy of linking its grants to non-government schools to movements in average government school running costs. Similarly the proposal to assess non-government school systems for funding purposes by aggregating individual schools' entitlements rather than by averaging the system as a whole, is not accepted.

The Government is also anxious to ensure that non-government schools continue to adapt their facilities to the special transition needs of students who are in secondary schools. The Commission is asked to give particular consideration to transition needs in developing the capital program for non-government schools. In addition, the Government expects that non-government schools will continue to give special attention to the allocation of their recurrent resources to help meet the needs of transition students. The Commission is asked to monitor closely through its State planning and finance committees progress in this direction. The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation that basic per capita grants at the rate of 20 per cent of government primary schools' standard costs be provided for non-government special schools. This arrangement will mean that special schools in both the government and non-government sectors will receive basic per capita Commonwealth funds in addition to grants from the special education programs.

The Government's allocation to the non-government capital program includes its election commitment to provide an additional $25m over the three years 1981, 1982 and 1983 to assist non-government schools with the provision of new places; $8m will be allocated for this purpose in 1982. In addition to the reallocation of resources within the general purpose programs, the Government has decided to redirect its effort among and within a number of special purpose programs in the light of Commission advice and the Government's own priorities. An additional $6.6m has been allocated for the migrant education program. As proposed by the Commission, the program will be retitled 'English as a Second Language'. It will also incorporate an element from the former contingency program for refugee children which has been transferred from the Department of Education. This latter element will be redesignated as being for new arrivals and will be widened to provide intensive English language instruction for non-refugees. In view of the significant restructuring of these programs, the Commission should review arrangements, in consultation with State and non-government school authorities, at the first opportunity.

The Commonwealth's programs for the handicapped will also be restructured in 1982. The joint program for integration of handicapped children into regular schools will be more closely related to the special education programs for government and non-government schools by incorporating the former as an element of these programs. Again, the Commission should enter into early negotiations with State and non-government school authorities to ensure that the restructuring can be effected without disruption. As proposed by the Commission, the former disadvantaged country areas program will be increased by $1.5m in 1982 and retitled as the country areas program to reflect the approved new criteria for allocation of funds in terms of relative isolation and size of settlements. In the context of the policies underlying the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Government is not prepared at this time to consider commencing any further programs. Whilst the proposed school improvement program will not be implemented, the joint program for professional development will be retained at its existing level of funding.

An amount of $1.4m, equivalent to the 1981 grant, will be allocated to the special projects program in 1982 for projects of national significance. The Commission is asked to advise on the proposed distribution of these funds between particular projects. The Commission is asked to consider its proposals for new initiatives in respect of gifted children and students and the community within the context of the total level of funds available. The Government has accepted the Commission's advice that schools in the Australian Capital Territory be eligible to participate in an extended range of programs for disadvantaged schools, special education, and services and development, and will consider the extent of funding in the 1981-82 Budget.
Priorities in Education

The Government believes that Commonwealth grants for the accelerated advancement of education in the past decade and a half have made possible a very great development of facilities and opportunities. We are now going through a process of consolidation in education which, in substantial part, is a reflection of the adjustment to changing demographic patterns being experienced in Australia as a whole. We are now at a stage when it is necessary to take stock of the real gains that have been made and to assess future needs. I have convened a meeting of State and Northern Territory Education Ministers next week to discuss the decisions announced recently as a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions and those I am announcing today.

The Government is mindful of the stabilisation of enrolments that has taken place in universities and colleges of advanced education after a decade of steady growth and the reduced level of enrolments which is being experienced in government schools. These elements indicate the changing needs that have to be taken into account in determining the future shape of our education commitment. On the basis of current assessments, the Commonwealth will continue to give priority to the areas of technical and further education, vocational education, and transition education. The Commonwealth will maintain its overall commitment to education as a priority area of direct Commonwealth endeavour. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the attachments to which I have referred.
Leave granted.

no provision of funds to establish a University in Northern Territory.

In connection with the consolidation of colleges of advanced education, the Government announced its intention to reach agreement with each State concerning rationalisation measures by the end of 1981. If this cannot be done, the Commonwealth will not be prepared to continue recurrent funding for the colleges concerned after the end of 1981, and if the State Governments wish these colleges to continue as separate entities they will have to make their own separate financial provision. The list of the 30 colleges concerned is attached.

The Government intends that the consolidation of institutions should result in genuine amalgamations with one governing body and a real saving of resources. In determining the level of recurrent funds for 1982-84, the Government has assumed such savings in respect of institutions which have been or will be consolidated during the triennium. The Government will expect the Commission to continue to promote the most efficient use of resources available for tertiary education and requests it to consider the opportunities for greater efficiency and savings by reducing unnecessary duplication of effort among faculties and schools. The Government will continue to look to the Commission to provide ongoing advice on the relationship of manpower supply to demand in areas which are critical for education planning.

When the Government announced its Review of Commonwealth Functions decisions, it noted that some action had already been taken in the States on consolidation. Since that announcement, further steps have been taken by some States. In view of the progress which has been made towards consolidation and the need for the changes to be taken into account in legislation during the 1981 Budget Sittings, the Commission is asked to provide me with a progress report on consolidation by 30 June.

In accordance with the policies outlined above, and the Government's commitment to maximum expenditure restraint, a total of $1,558.4m has been allocated for recurrent programs for universities and colleges of advanced education in 1982.
Specific Provisions

The Government has reviewed the existing scheme of assistance under which teacher education courses in certain non-government teachers colleges receive up to 50 per cent of the recurrent costs of teacher education courses in CAEs and has decided that from 1982 these will be fully supported. Provision has been made in the total allocation for this purpose. The Government also considers that non-government teachers colleges should be eligible for consideration for capital grants within the total funds available. The Commission is asked to advise on the implementation of this decision after consultation with State authorities and the institutions concerned.

Funds have been provided for the Government's 1980 election commitments for the establishment of research centres of excellence in universities; the development of community language courses in universities and/or CAEs; and, the provision of 350 additional basic nurse training places in CAEs, including the establishment of new pilot courses in Tasmania and Queensland.
An additional $50,000 will be provided for evaluation programs with the special objective of expanding the evaluation of basic nurse training.
Special provision has been made for the Australian Maritime College which is still in its developmental stage.

The Government asks that within the level of funds available, the Commission give consideration to the establishment of a national school of fisheries. The Commission is requested in particular to advise on the desirability of locating the school in Tasmania.

The Government has previously announced its intention to introduce tuition fees from 1982 in universities and CAEs for students newly enrolled in degrees and diplomas subsequent to an initial tertiary qualification. The scale of fees will be announced in the Budget context and universities and colleges will be advised on the manner in which adjustments will be made to the levels of recurrent grants.

For equipment expenditure, the allocations for 1982 include an additional $4.2m to assist institutions in replacing outdated equipment and in responding to needs arising from technological change. While the total grants for capital programs will decline by $5.6m, there will be some provision for high priority projects to commence in 1982 as a result of a lower expenditure commitment to on-going projects.
Technical and Further Education
The Government has allocated $206.8m for TAFE in 1982. This represents an increase of $11.7m and emphasises the importance the Government places on vocational and technical education.

The 1982 allocation for recurrent programs consists of $59.4m for general recurrent and $25.2m for specific purpose recurrent programs. The increase for these latter programs will enable the Commission to develop programs for quality improvement in TAFE as advocated by the Williams Report and by the Commission. The Commission's recommendations on the distribution of these funds should take account of the record of individual States in using their own funds to bring about improvements in TAFE.

An amount of $10.1m has been allocated for the establishment of a TAFE equipment program in 1982. These funds will assist the States in meeting the needs for updated equipment particularly in the technologies.

For 1982 $112.1m has been provided for capital programs. Of this amount, $21.4m represents the final instalment under the Government's original supplementary ''$50m'' grant over the period 1979-82. Although the total allocation is slightly less than 1981 it will enable expenditure of about $37m on new projects in 1982.
Tertiary Education

The table which follows sets out the funds which will be provided for individual programs for 1982 compared with the funds for 1981, in the same price terms. The Government has decided that from 1982 the cost adjustment will be made on a prospective basis. As has been the case for previous retrospective adjustments, the prospective allowance will take account of cost increases in all programs up to the beginning of the program year; during the program year the allowance will be in respect of estimated increases in the wages and salaries components of recurrent grants. In adopting this new arrangement, the Government has taken a more rigorous approach toward cost adjustment which in the past has provided additional funds automatically and has had a tendency to insulate educational insitutions from the effects of inflation and from the need to contain excessive wage claims.

SCHOOLS COMMISSION GUIDELINES1982

A total of $1,003.6m will be provided for the programs of the Schools Commission in the States and the Northern Territory in 1982. All amounts in this statement for 1982 are expressed on an outturn basis, while for the purposes of comparison those for 1981 are expressed in the same price terms. As grants for non-government schools and part-time ethnic schools are made on a per capita basis, the final level of grants will be varied in accordance with the actual levels of enrolments in these schools. The Schools Commission is asked to prepare recommendations on the distribution of these funds in accordance with these guidelines.
General Resources Programs
Government Schools

The level of the general recurrent program will be maintained at $269.2m while the capital program will be reduced by $6.3m to $124.7m. This reduction reflects the continuing overall decline in government school enrolments projected for 1982. Within these substantial amounts for general resources in government schools, the Commonwealth has decided to earmark some funds to pursue two policy objectives: greater emphasis by schools on meeting the needs of young people who are especially disadvantaged by lack of skills and who leave school prematurely; and the need to achieve maximum involvement from parents and local school communities in planning and providing educational opportunities for young people.

Accordingly, up to $27m is to be earmarked from the general recurrent grants for programs to assist students effectively to make the transition from school to work. The Government seeks the co-operation of the States in developing programs which concentrate on the broad range of needs of these students. Within that earmarked sum, provision will be made for cash grants to secondary school boards or committees at the rate of $10 per student with a minimum cash grant of $500 per school. These cash grants are designed to provide school communities with discretionary funds and a degree of autonomy to develop transition programs. Such programs should be especially adapted to needs in local communities.

The Commission, which has recommended that general cash grants be made available for government schools, is asked to hold discussions with the States and with parent and teacher groups to develop procedures for the implementation of these transition cash grants in 1982. If a State increases transition expenditure from its own resources, including the provision of cash grants to schools, an equivalent amount from within the Commonwealth's earmarked grant will be made available for general recurrent purposes at the discretion of the State.

Furthermore, the Commonwealth requests the Commission to earmark 15 per cent ($18.7m) of government school capital grants as a specific element for the provision of equipment and facilities for transition education in secondary schools. The types of capital expenditure to be approved under this provision are to be the subject of consultation between the Commission and the States. It is the Government's intention that as a result of this provision, schools should make significant progress towards adapting their facilities to the changing curriculum needs of students preparing for the transition from school to work. The needs of students in schools whose facilities and equipment are old or outdated, or which are primarily oriented towards academic courses, should benefit especially from these funds.

In making its recommendations on the distribution of general resources funds, the Commission should note that the Government has decided to discontinue the present arrangement which permits States to seek transfers of amounts between general recurrent and capital allocations. These amounts have been determined by the Commonwealth in the light of its assessment of needs and priorities for those programs and should not therefore be redistributed on any other basis.
Non-government Schools

The Government will meet its election commitments to maintain the percentage link between its general recurrent grants and average government schools standard costs and to compress the existing six subsidy levels to three. The latter will be achieved by combining the existing Levels 1-3 to a new Group 1, Levels 4-5 to a new Group 2 and Level 6 to become the new Group 3. The 1982 per capita rates for the new Group 1, 2 and 3 schools will be 20, 30 and 38 per cent respectively of average government schools standard costs. Per capita subsidies for Group 3 schools will be raised to 40 per cent of average government schools costs in 1983.

The Government asks the Commission to implement a number of changes to the procedures for assessing non-government schools' subsidy categories from the beginning of 1982, as recommended in the Commission's Report, on the following bases:
First, the initial classification of non-government schools subsidies will be as follows:
Group 1: Schools whose expenditure from private sources is equal to or above 51 per cent of government schools standard costs.
Group 2: Schools whose expenditure from private sources lies in the range of 31-50 per cent of government schools standard costs.
Group 3: Schools whose expenditure from private sources is 30 per cent or less of government schools standard costs.

Second, the Government recognises that some non-systemic non-government schools would be reclassified to a lower subsidy level as a result of the above changes. The Minister, on the advice of the Schools Commission and its State Planning and Finance Committees, will permit those schools to remain at a higher subsidy level for up to two years until they adapt their resources to the new arrangements. The Governments will review any cases where this is not achievable within two years.

Third, the Commission, through its State Planning and Finance Committees, is to give consideration to school income as well as expenditure in the assessment of subsidy levels. However, this assessment will continue to be based primarily on recurrent expenditure. Principles to be developed for including disposable income in the assessment procedure will be approved by the Minister following consultation by the Commission with non-government school authorities. Any subsequent changes in schools' subsidy levels will continue to be subject to Ministerial approval following advice from the Commission.

Fourth, the provisions for new non-systemic schools will be varied so that they receive supplementary establishment grants for the first four years, over and above the general recurrent subsidy. The respective rate for each year will be 10 per cent, 7.5 per cent, 5 per cent and 2.5 per cent of government schools standard costs.

The Government is also anxious to ensure that non-government schools continue to adapt their facilities to the special transition needs of students who are in secondary schools. The Commission is asked to give particular consideration to transition needs in developing the capital program for non-government schools. In addition, the Government expects that non-government schools will continue to give special attention to the allocation of their recurrent resources to help meet the needs of transition students. The Commission is asked to monitor closely progress in this direction, through its State Planning and Finance Committees.

For non-government special schools, the Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation that basic per capita grants at the rate of 20 per cent of government primary schools standard costs be provided. This arrangement will mean that special schools in both the government and non-government sectors will receive basic per capita Commonwealth funds in addition to grants from the special education programs.

The Government's allocation to the capital program includes its election commitment to provide an additional $25m over the three years 1981-83 to assist non-government schools with the provision of new places; $8m will be allocated for this purpose in 1982.
Special Purpose Programs

In addition to the reallocation of resources within the general purpose programs, the Government has decided to redirect its effort between and within a number of special purpose programs in the light of Commission advice and the Government's own priorities.

An additional $6.6m has been allocated for the migrant education program. As proposed by the Commission, the program will be retitled 'English as a second language'. It will also incorporate an element for the former contingency program for refugee children which has been transferred from the Department of Education. This latter element will be redesignated as being for new arrivals and will be widened to provide intensive English language instruction for non-refugees. In view of the significant restructuring of these programs, the Commission should review arrangements, in consultation with State and non-government school authorities, at the first opportunity.

The Commonwealth's programs for the handicapped will also be restructured in 1982. The joint program for integration of handicapped children into regular schools will be more closely related to the special education programs for government and non-government schools by incorporating the former as an element of these programs. Again, the Commission should enter into early negotiations with State and non-government school authorities to ensure that the restructuring can be effected without disruption.

As proposed by the Commission, the former disadvantaged country areas program will be increased by $1.5m in 1982 and retitled as the country areas program to reflect the approved new criteria for allocation of funds in terms of relative isolation and size of settlements.

In the context of the policies underlying the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Government is not prepared at this time to consider commencing any further programs. While the proposed school improvement program will not be implemented and the school level innovations program will be discontinued, the joint program for professional development will be retained at its existing level of funding. In so doing, the Government has had regard to the proposals of the Schools Commission and the National Inquiry into Teacher Education.

An amount of $1.4m will be allocated to the special projects program in 1982 for projects of national significance. The Commission is asked to advise on the proposed distribution of these funds among particular projects and to consider its proposed initiatives for gifted children and for students and the community within the total available level of funds.
The Government will also continue in 1982 the programs for severely handicapped children and for part-time ethnic schools commenced in 1981 as part of its election commitments.

The Government has accepted the Commission's advice that schools in the Australian Capital Territory be eligible to participate in an extended range of programs for disadvantaged schools, special education and professional development and will consider the extent of funding in the 1981-82 Budget.
All Programs

The table which follows sets out the funds which will be provided for individual programs for 1982, compared with the funds for 1981 in the same price terms. The Government has decided that from 1982 the cost adjustment will be made on a prospective basis. As has been the case for previous retrospective adjustments, the prospective allowance will take account of cost increases in all programs up to the beginning of the program year; during the program year the allowance will be in respect of estimated increases in the wages and salaries components of recurrent grants. In adopting this new arrangement, the Government has taken a more rigorous approach toward cost adjustment which in the past has provided additional funds automatically and has had a tendency to insulate educational institutions from the effects of inflation and from the need to contain excessive wage claims.

The Commission is asked to report on the detailed distribution of the 1982 allocations by 31 August 1981 to permit time for consideration of its recommendations and passage of the necessary legislation during the Budget sittings of the Parliament.

Attachment IV
SOME POLICY ISSUES RAISED BY THE EDUCATION COMMISSIONS' REPORTS

In addition to giving consideration to those recommendations put forward by the Commissions which have specific financial implications, the Government also has considered a number of other policy issues raised in their Reports.
Tertiary Education
The Government has specifically endorsed the following matters raised by the Tertiary Education Commission:

that universities should be recognised as having a special institutional commitment to scholarship and research and to training scholars and research workers-the Government's commitment to the establishment of research centres of excellence in universities is evidence of its support;

that special funds not be provided for research in advanced education but individual members of academic staff with appropriate expertise be encouraged to seek outside support for tactical problem-oriented research;

the Commission's revised policy guidelines for masters degrees in CAEs be implemented. These include the requirements that such programs have an applied nature; be provided by CAEs as designated by the Commission, with the appropriate capacity in terms of staffing and facilities; and should not duplicate activities in universities or other colleges;
that the advanced education sector should maintain its vocational objectives and not provide for significant enrolments in liberal studies courses;

that continuing education is an important function of higher education institutions and should be regarded as part of the normal duties of teaching staff. Costs of continuing education programs should be met in the manner proposed by the Commission;
that groups seeking assistance for child care centres should do so from agencies with specific responsibilities in this field.

The Government has noted that the Commission's Report made no separate provision for the proposed Northern Territory University or for university level studies in the Territory. This matter has been examined separately by the Commission and the Government will respond to its findings when the Commission's special report is available in June.

The Government has noted the Commission's concern that proliferation of external studies courses may have led to a degree of duplication in higher education. It asks the Commission to report further on this matter during the course of the forthcoming triennium.
Schools

In regard to the Schools Commission's proposal to participate in a review of youth training and support programs, the Government has agreed that the Commission will participate in the administration of Commonwealth transition programs and will provide advice to the Government on appropriate policy developments.

The Government has decided not to accept the Commission's recommendation that the funding levels for government and non-government schools' general recurrent grants be linked to the fixed standard cost of a revised basket of educational services. To do so would be contrary to Government policy and, in the case of non-government schools, would be an abrogation of its election commitments. The Government is not able to agree to the proposed 'aggregation' of systemic non-government schools' subsidy level entitlements. It is the Government's view that such an approach would reduce the flexibility of non-government school systems in making provision for those schools most in need; the existing 'averaging' approach to entitlements will therefore continue.
The Government is unable to accept the recommendation that the level of capital grants for government schools be determined, and maintained, on a triennial basis.

The Government endorses the proposals that the notional funds for the disadvantaged schools element of the government and non-government schools' capital programs be based on the proposed updated index of disadvantage and that these funds be applicable to minor refurbishing and upgrading projects as well as other works.

The Government does not wish to impose further restrictions on the States and non-government school authorities and is therefore unable to agree to the proposal that notional library development funds be directed only towards the provision of book and non-book materials, library equipment and library furniture.

The recommendation that non-government capital grants be available to enable new non-government schools to lease facilities over a period of up to three years is endorsed, while a decision on the proposed use of these grants for assistance to privately run student hostels is deferred for further consultation. The Government accepts the Commission's advice that provision be included in the legislation for the Minister to reallocate the grants specified for new enrolments in non-government schools should that prove desirable.
The Government has endorsed a number of other policy recommendations put forward by the Commission in relation to special purpose programs. These include:
that funds for special education be available to engage professional services other than those of teachers, when appropriate;
that the allocation of funds for the recurrent elements of the government and non-government disadvantaged schools programs be based on a revised index of disadvantage;
that twenty per cent of the funds for the Professional Development program be allocated in accordance with an index reflecting the geographical dispersion of teachers in each State and Territory.
Attachment V
MODIFICATIONS TO PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION OF THE SCHOOLS COMMISSION

The following modifications to the administrative arrangements for various Schools Commission programs are in response to the Review of Commonwealth Functions. These measures are designed to improve administrative efficiency and reduce unnecessary entanglement in the operation of State and non-government schools.

The Commonwealth, with the assistance of the Commission, will define the aims of programs and set out indicative rather than prescriptive guidelines on the activities which might be supported. Educational and financial accountability statements will then be provided by State and non-government school authorities to indicate the level and purposes and, if possible, the effects of expenditure of Commonwealth funds. The Commission will have regard to these accountability statements in drawing up its triennial reports. The Commission is asked to consult with State and non-government authorities in the development of educational and financial accountability arrangements. The revised arrangements will be settled between the Minister and State Ministers and authorities representing non-government schools.
1. Severely Handicapped Children
(i) The Commission (subject to Ministerial endorsement) to issue detailed statements on the aims of the program and a suggested range of activities which might be undertaken.
(ii) State and non-government authorities to proceed to implement programs as they see fit according to local needs and circumstances.
(iii) States to provide assurances to the Commonwealth that oversight committees are constituted in accordance with the joint nature of the program.

(iv) State and non-government authorities to provide detailed educational and financial accountability statements to the Commission at the end of each year of the program's operation. Format of accountability statements to be decided following consultation between the Commission and the States.
2. Integration of Handicapped Children into Regular Schools
(i) Withdraw prescriptive guidelines for this program.
(ii) The Commission (subject to Ministerial endorsement) to issue a detailed statement on the aims of the program and a suggested range of activities which might be undertaken.
(iii) State and non-government authorities to proceed to implement programs as they see fit according to local needs and circumstances.

(iv) State and non-government authorities to provide detailed educational and financial accountability statements to the Commission at the end of each year of the program's operation. Format of accountability statements to be decided following consultation.
3. Special Education Program

(i) Removal of requirement for State Ministers to notify Commonwealth Minister of deletions and additions to lists of special schools. Consideration (following discussions with States) to be given to elimination of lists completely.

(ii) Investigation of possibility of non-government school program being administered by Committees representative of non-government schools (perhaps as sub-committees of State Planning and Finance Committees).
4. Multicultural Education Program
(i) Abolish regular national meetings of State co-ordinators. Meetings to be called on an ad hoc basis when necessary.
(ii) Abolish production of separate reports on the program. All such reporting to be encompassed within the Commission's regular triennial reports.
5. New Arrivals Program

(i) Detailed guidelines for the new arrivals program, including refugees, to be presented as indicative rather than prescriptive. No requirement for States or non-government schools to adhere to precise parameters.

(ii) State and non-government school authorities, in first year of program, to be asked to provide the Commission with broad outlines of implementation proposals, including the extension of the funds to groups previously not covered and indication of how the proposals dovetail with the general ESL program.
(iii) Educational and financial accountability arrangements to be established following consultation.
(iv) Funds to be allocated to States by Commonwealth on a per capita rather than detailed request basis.
6. Services and Professional Development Program

(i) Eliminate requirement that between 40 and 60 per cent of funds be spent on the replacement and remuneration cost of teachers attending courses of 10 days or more duration. No prescriptive guidelines to be issued for this program. Commission to issue broad statement of aims and suggested range of activities. Implementation (including involvement of tertiary institutions) a matter for State authorities.
(ii) Abolish National Advisory Group (which meets 2-3 times per year). Where necessary functions can be met by calling together on an ad hoc basis State co-ordinators of the program.
(iii) States to provide assurance that oversight committees are constituted in accordance with joint nature of the program.
(iv) Educational and financial accountability statements to be provided but annual reviews to be eliminated. Reviews to be confined to Commission triennial reports.
7. Disadvantaged Schools Program

(i) Retain the current Commonwealth determination of the numbers of students in the program and the school as the unit of funding. States to continue to provide Commonwealth Minister with annual list of declared disadvantaged schools.

(ii) Remove current administrative guidelines on the rate of turnover of schools on the list and the requirement that each school remain on the list for three years. Such matters to be left to discretion of States on advice from oversight committees.
(iii) Eliminate annual reviews of the program. Reviews to be confined to triennial reports of the Commission.
(iv) Eliminate regular meetings of State co-ordinators of program. Meetings to be called on an ad hoc basis as necessary.
(v) Commonwealth Minister to continue to declare disadvantaged non-government schools.

(vi) Maintain other main features of the program, including parent/community participation requirements. States and non-government authorities to provide assurances to Commonwealth Minister regarding parent, teacher and community representation on oversight committees.
8. Country Areas Program
(i) Eliminate present requirement that regions be 'turned over' on a regular basis. Such matters to be left to State authorities.
(ii) Delete present rule that States receive Commonwealth approval to add to or delete from list of declared regions. This is to be at State discretion. State Ministers to declare regions.
(iii) Delete the requirement that the funds be confined to a restricted number of regions in each State. If States wish, all country regions may participate.

(iv) States to provide assurances to the Commonwealth that oversight committees are constituted in accordance with the joint and community nature of the program and that funded activities have parent and teacher support.
9. Innovations Program

Grants for school level innovations projects will be terminated at the end of 1981, although it will take perhaps two years beyond that to complete accountability and reporting requirements. The activities of the consultants and the national and State committees involved in the administration of the program will be wound up this year.
10. Program Consolidation

Some consolidation will take place within the general framework of Commission programs. The New Arrivals Program will become an element of the English as a Second Language Program, rather than operating as a separate joint entity. The program which supports integration of handicapped children in regular schools will become an element of the Special Education Program. This should ensure a more coherent relationship between funding arrangements and policy development in these areas.
