SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I am bound to do is protest at the way in which this matter has been handled. In the first instance, these guidelines come in response to the reports of the Tertiary Education Commission and the Schools Commission which were tabled in this Parliament months ago. No opportunity for debate was provided at that time, and there will be little or no debate in relation to the discussion of the Government's response to those reports. The other point I make is that now is the time usually set aside for private members' business. It is a matter of great regret that most of the time available for private members will be taken up with this discussion on the Government's guidelines for the Schools Commission and the Tertiary Education Commission. We have to insist always that private members have an opportunity to bring forward matters to this Parliament and not simply have their time expropriated by the Government in this way. Because of that, because of the exigencies of time, and for other reasons, I do not intend to take the full time available to me. I think it is important that some time be available for discussion of the matter which will be brought forward by the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi). Another point is that this is a very detailed document, running to some 25 pages, with several attachments. I obtained a copy, under the normal arrangements, only a couple of hours before the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) presented it to the Parliament. Therefore it will not be possible for me to respond in great detail, which makes it all the more important that time be set aside before this Parliament rises for a full discussion of the matters that have been raised.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a serious and deeply disturbing document. It represents another tragic instalment of the Government's determination to disparage and finally destroy the system of education in this country. Not only is it an attack on the quality of education but also it is predicated on a drop in enrolments in government schools and in the tertiary sector. The Government seems to approach with total equanimity the fact that enrolments in government schools are declining and that, in the Minister's terms, there is a stabilisation of enrolments in the tertiary sector which will almost certainly be followed by a reduction in enrolments in that sector. I do not think it is acceptable for us to contemplate the development of a decline in enrolments in the schools and a forthcoming decline in enrolments in the tertiary sector at a time when we ought to be encouraging more of our young people to be involved in full time education. Anyone would think that the record in Australia was something about which we could be blase. In fact, we all know that that is not the case. We all know that in a comparison with other countries we fare very badly in terms of the number of people involved in full time education. What is worse, not only do we compare badly with other countries, but also we are getting worse at a time when those other countries with which we like to compare ourselves are getting better in terms of the number of people who are in and continuing in full time education.

It is not just a matter of demographic changes, as the Minister has stated, which have led to a decline in the number of enrolments in schools. We have seen an actual decline in the proportion of people remaining in school from the first year to the last year. That decline has been from 27 per cent to 35 per cent in the 10-year period 1969 to 1979. In addition, of those who do complete secondary education, the number who go on to tertiary education is falling. Faced with those very worrying statistics, this statement by the Minister is entirely inadequate. It does not address itself to any of those sorts of problems. It does not indicate what action the Government intends to take to reverse those very dislturbing trends in which a turnaround has taken place following a 25-year period of increasing participation rates and increasing enrolments in our education system.

The other problem with the Minister's statement is that it sets about to blame the education system for the fact that there is an enormous and unacceptable level of youth unemployment. The Government has been trying to maintain this position for some time. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) dreamed up this view as he searched for further villians to excuse this Government for its total failure to do anything about the appalling economic situation in this country and particularly the appalling situation as it affects young people. He set about to blame the schools, the teachers and the education system for the fact that young people take a very long time to find employment when they leave school. This flies in the face of all the professional advice which the Government has before it.

The Government continues to quote from the Schools Commission report on 15 and 16-year-olds, but the Government always quotes that document selectively in terms of what the Commission had to say about some of the shortcomings of some of the schools in relation to some of the students in those schools. What the Schools Commission has said-it said this in its most recent report-is that it is not the failure of the schools because many young people are adequately prepared, are keen to find work but simply cannot do so because there is not enough work available for them.

Only yesterday the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts confirmed this approach. That Committee said that the education system has very little to do with whether people are able to find jobs. It is true that the education system has much to do with whether young people find the sorts of jobs they want or whether people have the appropriate skills for the jobs which are available, but it has very little to do with the overall problem of reducing the level of youth unemployment. The Senate Committee, which of course is dominated by Government senators, says that it is economic factors and not education factors which determine how many young people find work and how many remain out of work.

The Government pretends that it is increasing its commitment to the school-to-work transition program. It has decided that this program will make the difference in terms of the number of young people who find work. However, it is worth having a very close look at that claim. The Government first started funding the school-to-work transition program last year. It was agreed that the Commonwealth should provide the total funding for the first year for 1981. It was always intended that, from 1982 to the end of the five-year school-to-work transition program, the States would take up some of the funding. In fact, the States have said that they will not. As a result, the Government is trying to find other ways of filling the gap which the States have left because of their failure or their reluctance to get involved with or commit themselves financially to this program.

It is very interesting that the only endorsement that the Minister has in relation to the school-to-work transition program comes from the State Ministers. The Minister said at the last meeting of State and Commonwealth Ministers for Education there was ringing endorsement of the school-to-work transition program and that great enthusiasm was expressed by State Ministers at that time. What sort of support is it that forces them to the decision that they are unable to back up their enthusiasm and commitment with the necessary funds to keep the program going? The Government has said: 'Well, if the States will not contribute to it as a result of the persuasive powers of the Commonwealth Minister for Education, we will pinch it off them in other ways'. The Government has said that because of the State governments' failure to provide financial support for the school-to-work transition program it will deduct an amount of $27m from the amount which would otherwise have been made available in recurrent funding for government schools which are run by State governments.

The point is that this does not represent an increased commitment by the Commonwealth. That $27m is expropriated from the amount which would otherwise have been made available to government schools. That is an amount which presumably will have to be made up by the States. The Commonwealth has said: 'You were not prepared to join with us in the school-to-work transition program, you were unable to see the virtues which we see in the program; therefore we are going to ensure that you fund it indirectly by reducing the amount which we would otherwise have provided for recurrent expenditure in schools and earmark it for the school-to-work transition program'. The amount involved is not small. It represents something like a reduction of 10 per cent in recurrent expenditure which this Government is making available to government schools throughout the country.

The reason the State governments have not been sufficiently impressed with the school-to-work transition program to the extent that they are prepared to fund it is that they are aware of its great shortcomings. Any success in the school-to-work transition program has come about largely by accident. It has come about because a number of enthusiastic teachers out in the schools, given some small additional resources, have been able to devise extra courses and new approaches within the schools to suit the needs of some students within those schools. There is no central philosophy underlying this scheme. The Government's own statements when introducing the school-to-work transition program were totally confusing and almost verging on the incomprehensible. The Government did not know what it wanted to do. All it wanted to do was to demonstrate that it was making some response, that it was engaged in some frenzied activity in assisting those kids who were leaving school and going straight onto the dole. The Government did not know what it was doing, but it had to demonstrate that it was committing funds and that it was therefore concerned about the problems of young people. The State governments do not know what the philosophy is that lies behind the school-to-work transition program. It is true that the States are enthusiastic about the program to the extent that it has worked, but they do not know what it is really supposed to be doing. There has been no evaluation of the success of the program. There has been no philosophical basis to it whatsoever.

I would like to refer again to the report of the Senate Committee, which, I repeat, is dominated by Government senators. Interestingly, the Senate report emphasises the need to distinguish between the problems of transition and the problems of unemployment. The Senate Committee heard many of the sorts of submissions from employers which have so influenced the Government in relation to this program. It was largely the Confederation of Australian Industry, which came stumbling into the education debate a year or so ago, which so influenced the Government in its determination to make funds available for the school-to-work transition program. The Senate Committee, having heard the evidence which came forward from employers and industry, rejected that evidence. It said the evidence was far too simplistic and that it was not its view that the primary aim of schools was to concentrate on vocational education. The Government has said that it will give consideration to the Senate Committee's report. However, I can imagine the sort of cursory examination the report will get in view of the fact that the Committee disputes and in fact rejects the Government's approach in this area.

The worst thing about this whole approach, this preoccupation with the school-to-work transition program-as if the program held the key to the problems of education in our country-is that it ignores the real problems in our schools, universities and colleges.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! And in science and technology.

—And in science and technology, as the shadow Minister for Science and Technology points out. The point is that the Government does not address itself to the fact that there is now an increasing drop-out rate in our schools. There has to be some explanation for that. We cannot simply say that that is happening because the kids who were dropping out are unimpressed with what they are getting at school, that they are unexcited by the courses being offered by those schools.

SPEECH.PARA: There should be a number of explanations. I invite the Minister to consider for a moment that one of the explanations for the early and increasing drop-out rate after the years of compulsory education could be the fact that the brighter students are dropping out and getting the jobs which are available. They know that they will at least get some job. It will not be a job that is appropriate to their abilities but at least it will be a job. They decide to drop out of school when they have an opportunity to out-compete the other people looking for jobs rather than staying on at school and going on to a university or college of advanced education and taking the risk of not being able to find the sort of job for which they trained during that process. There is some evidence that this is one of the factors influencing the dropout rate. That is something that cannot be overcome simply by patching it up with a crash school-to-work transition program.

This analysis, of course, neatly matches the evidence concerning the fall in the number of people going from secondary to tertiary education. We know that in the last few years there has been a massive drop in the number of people going straight from school to tertiary education. That seems to me to be a very worrying statistic. The Government has said that it is concerned to prepare for Australia's future, particularly in relation to technological change. How can it do so if an increasing number of young people turn away from higher education, whether it be colleges of advanced education or universities? Surely there is a need for the Government to encourage more of those people to go on rather than turn away from the problem and concentrate the predominate part of its effort on this patchwork of school-to-work transition programs. If the Government is really serious about the school-to-work transition program being an appropriate remedy for our problems, why does it not insist that this program be extended to the non-government sector? There are no requirements on the non-government sector to ensure that it partakes in this program. A lot of jaw boning is directed towards the non-government sector. The Government tells it that it would be pleased if it spent more of its time or concentrated more of its effort on this sort of approach. But there is no threat of withdrawal of $27m or 10 per cent of its recurrent expenditure to ensure that it follows this course.

What is the reason for the double standard in this approach? Why is it that only the government schools are being forced to follow the approach which the Government has decided upon? One of the problems is that the reduction in the amount of the current expenditure available to government schools will inevitably lead to an increase in the contribution that parents have to make to the education of their children in government schools. We have seen that the Government has already cut back funds to the States. The States' ability to make up the shortfall in recurrent expenditure in their own schools will be limited to that extent. There is no question whatsoever that, as a result of this statement today, the Government's preoccupation with the transition program and the Government's thieving of $27m from recurrent expenditure of government schools, fees in government schools will be increased enormously as the States try to make up the $27m which they will need in order to maintain the sort of standards in their normal program.

This stance will have extraordinarily worrying consequences for all children in Australia. This brings me to the way in which the Government, in its preoccupation with this approach, has ignored the advice and recommendations of the Schools Commission. Let us have a look at some of the figures in the broad. The Schools Commission recommended that the overall expenditure on government schools should increase by 8 per cent. In fact, there has been a drop of 0.5 per cent. For the non-government schools an 11 per cent hike was suggested. This displays the way in which the Government has a punitive approach to the government schools because it has very nearly complied with the recommendations of the Schools Commission and provided a 10 per cent increase to the non-government sector. This reveals again the way in which this Government has a very selective approach to education. It is determined to penalise the government school sector at a time when the government school sector is in need of very great and increased support.

The Schools Commission has reported on a billion dollar backlog in capital expenditure in the government sector. It was calling for a 10 per cent increase in government funding. What did the Government provide? It provided for a 5 per cent cut in the capital expenditure for the government sector. As well as that, the Government has approved the abolition of the innovations program but has not taken the advice of the Schools Commission and replaced or extended it with the Schools Improvement program which would have provided $15m extra in a specialised program of school improvement. The Government is overlooking the real problem which has been demonstrated by the Schools Commission in order to pursue its preoccupations with the school-to-work transition program which is untested and badly based and remains unevaluated. Criticism of this approach of the school-to-work transition program comes from a number of sectors. Let me refer to a small section from the most recent report of the Curriculum Development Centre which reads:

The conclusion we draw from the lengthy debates and excited activity under the heading 'school-to-work transition' is that they are no answer to our dilemmas. This remark need not be a signal to resume a complacent attitude about what may be the school's role in preparing youth for working life. There is indeed a crucial role for the school in this respect but it is more basic and long-term and cannot be accommodated by crash programmes.

I wish that the Minister for Education would take that advice to heart and go back to a sensible consideration of the real problems that exist in our schools rather than pursuing this madness which is simply a seat of the pants response on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) as he surveys the horror of youth unemployment in this country.

The abolition of the CDC is particularly mad-headed. If ever there was a time when we needed imaginative approaches to the curriculum in our schools it is now. The Government has said that it will close the CDC unless the State governments come to the party. Let me read to the Minister a letter which I have received from the Office of the Catholic Education Commission of Western Australia. The last paragraph, in which the Commission indicates the value of the CDC and the work it does in the non-government sector, reads:

I would also raise with you the question of the value of that statutory body to the school community generally (including parents and parent groups) and to the total non-government school sector. The latter stands to lose more, with the demise of the CDC, than the government school sector because it does not have access to the financial resources from within the state to promote by itself programs and projects of curriculum development, including the production of materials. I sense that it is these community and non-government school sector voices that are not being heard in much of the debate about the future of CDC.

The Government cannot just wash its hands in relation to the CDC because its impact has been felt throughout the community. It is not just a matter of the State governments taking this aspect up. If the State governments had the $70m which this Government withheld, maybe there would be some argument in asking them to contribute to the cost of the CDC. In these circumstances the Government seems to me to be extremely short sighted and ignoring the real problems it faces.

I wish to refer to a couple of issues that were raised by the Minister in relation to the tertiary sector. One of the most disappointing aspects of the Minister's statement today is that it tells us nothing more about the decisions, most of them foolish, that arose from the Review of Commonwealth Functions. There is still no estimate of the likely income which the CAEs and universities will derive from the fees which they will be forced to impose for second and higher degree students next year. There is no indication of that whatsoever, although one senses that someone has made an estimate of their likely income and has built this estimate into the amounts of money which the Government has approved for expenditure on the college and university sector.

There are still no details in relation to the student loan scheme. I recognise that the Government has serious problems. A number of universities around this country have said that they will not administer a student loan scheme. Obviously the Government is having a great problem in devising a scheme which will be acceptable to universities, let alone acceptable to the students. Of course whatever scheme the Government devises, it will not appropriately meet the real financial problems facing students, particularly those from lower and middle income families. A loans scheme is no answer to the inadequate financial assistance available to students today, particularly when bearing in mind that the Government intends to reduce the real level of benefits available under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme.

In the statement the Government is simply re- stating its position in relation to the 30 CAE's which it has threatened to close. There is still no justification for the closures. We know how the decision was made. The Government simply took out of the TEC report a list of 30 CAEs which was drawn up to demonstrate the 30 CAEs predominantly involved in teacher education. It was not a list of colleges which the TEC said should be merged. Whilst the TEC did indicate that it thought some mergers and some rationalisation should proceed during the next triennium, that list of colleges was not identified by the TEC for that purpose. The Minister has been verging on the dishonest in saying that the decision to close colleges or to force their merging has been based on advice from the TEC. There is one small change involved in what the Minister said before and what he is saying now in relation to those CAEs. I quote from page 15 of the statement, which reads:

I should add that whilst the principle of rationalisation and the timetable are not negotiable from the Commonwealth's viewpoint, the Government is willing to discuss with the States particular arrangements in relation to individual institutions.

I find that statement entirely breathtaking. What on earth does it mean? The statement starts off by saying that the principle is not negotiable but then says that the Government is prepared to discuss with the States particular arrangements. Does that really mean that the Government is prepared to reconsider some of the colleges on the list? Is it prepared to reconsider some of the colleges on the list? Is it prepared to reconsider the timetable? If not, what is the Government prepared to discuss with the States? Some of the States will put to the Minister very powerful arguments as to why some of those colleges should not, in fact, be merged. People from the CAE and, indeed, the university at Armidale will say that it is inappropriate for those two institutions to merge. They are saying that already there has been a saving in resources as a result of co-operation between the two institutions. They say they have both gone about as far as they can go in terms of sharing resources and therefore saving money which is expended by them.

The Newcastle College of Advanced Education will also put up very powerful arguments as to why it should be allowed to continue. It will point out to the Minister that the College serves a rapidly growing area, the Hunter Valley region, and that it has already taken substantial steps towards diversifying its activities away from solely teacher education into other areas. I think that the mystery of this decision and the lack of justification for it can lead us to really only one conclusion. That is that the Government is determined, by way of forcing the closure or merging of some of these colleges, to reduce the number of student places which are available in those colleges. That is what the Government is really interested in; it wishes to reduce the number of student places and enrolments as a way of reducing expenditure on the college and university sector.

The Government has not told us in the ministerial statement what it really means when it insists that there will be a saving of resources as a result of the mergers or closures or whatever. Similarly, in relation to the University of Western Australia and Murdoch University the Government still refuses to explain what in fact it means and what it is demanding in relation to a saving of resources by those two institutions. At the same time the Government says that it has built into the guidelines given to the TEC an estimate of the amount involved in these imagined savings of resources. The point is that the Government said in the statement that it has reduced the amount recommended by the TEC for expenditure on the college sector because it has taken into account what it believes should be the savings in resources and expenditure as a result of the rationalisation and mergers of CAEs. The Government has not told us how much it imagines these colleges should or could save as a result of these forced mergers and closures.

I repeat that the Government's action is taken only with a view to reducing the number of enrolments in colleges and in universities in this country. The Minister particularly has pointed in the past to the fact that enrolments have increased substantially-I think he said by 14 per cent over the last five years. What he apparently does not understand, or alternatively ignores, is the enormous change which has occurred in the pattern of enrolments in universities and CAEs. It has been mainly in the area of mature age and part time enrolments that the great increases have taken place. There simply has not been an increase recently in the number of enrolments of young people going from schools to colleges and universities. An extra problem involved in this area, when taking into account the decision to impose fees for second and higher qualifications, is that a large number of older people will now be turned away from the colleges and universities and we will have a further reduction in the number of places available in those institutions at a time when we really ought to be encouraging more people to get involved in full time education of one kind or another.

In summing up, I think that the response of the Government to the TEC is really extraordinary. The Government has sought to ignore the advice of the bodies available to make recommendations in relation to education expenditure. It seems much more interested in the change of name of the Schools Commission to the Commonwealth Schools Commission and of the TEC to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission than it does in taking those bodies' advice. It really does not matter much what these bodies are called; it is what they do that is important. If the Government continues to ignore their advice then those bodies, which contain of some of the best educational minds in the country, will be of declining value not only to this Government but also to the community as a whole. Both those commissions have put in years of careful and painstaking work in preparing recommendations for the Government on education funding for the next three years. I am sure they will be extraordinarily disappointed and discouraged at the way in which the Government has ignored their advice and instead heeded the obsession and preoccupation of the Prime Minister as to what he thinks is correct for education in this country. I do not know why the Prime Minister has such contempt for education and for people involved in education in this country. I can only assume that it is based on his own third rate education and particularly his antipodean and antediluvian experience.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was no good at school.
—The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) said that the Prime Minister was no good at school. That comes as no surprise. After all, he got a third class honours degree at Oxford.
—Really?

—He did. This Government's response to the pressing problems that face the education system is totally inappropriate. It does not face up to the great challenges of the future in relation to what this country ought to be demanding of its education system. It certainly does not face up to the real requirements of the education system and those people who work in it. The education of the people of this country has been put in the hands of people who despise schools, teachers, students and academics. Their only wish is to demonise the education system as a way of disguising their own inadequacies, particularly in relation to youth unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's action represents, most disappointingly, a further departure from the approach which the Liberal Party has had, an approach which was initiated by Menzies. Menzies had a very great interest in the education system of this country. He established a number of very important programs; he carried on with some programs which were suggested by the Chifley Labor Government. The Menzies Government involved the Commonwealth in the education system in entirely new ways. I guess that it is just a matter of very great regret that this Liberal Government is turning its back on the approach of the Menzies era and trying to withdraw the Commonwealth from education and demolish many of the fine programs which the Menzies Government established and which were continued and expanded by the Labor Government during the 1972-75 period. After six years this Government still has no idea what it is doing or where it is going. The statement of the Minister is riddled with indications of promises to review particular approaches, to review particular allowances, to review the question of support for youth, and to have a look at reports from the Senate and other reports. The Government has no idea. It has no philosophy. Its response in the Minister's statement is entirely inadequate.

The Schools Commission pointed to the total inadequacies of the policies, the total shambles in relation to the problems facing young people, the total inadequacy of the programs which are provided to support young people in this country. There is no response to this part of the Commissions report. This document is a deeply dispiriting one. It is bad news for the kids at school, three-quarters of whom are in government schools. It is bad news for their parents. It is bad news for Australia, and eventually it will be very bad news for this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable member claims to have been misrepresented?

—Yes. I claim to have been misrepresented both by Mr Speaker and by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman). In Question Time this morning I asked the Minister whether he was aware that in Easter 1980 three cadets had shot up a car belonging to a civilian in a Canberra suburb. While I was asking that question Mr Speaker interrupted me and said:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot allow a request for information, which is a question, to amount to a recitation of allegations about a group in the community.

I point out that in December I asked a number of questions of the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen), including whether three cadets had been dismissed or asked to resign from the Royal Military College following the shooting up of a car; if so, where and when the shooting took place; and whether military or police charges were laid in relation to the incident. The Minister replied that three cadets were discharged, that the incident took place at Easter 1980 in a Canberra suburb, and that no charges were made.

My question was based on the information supplied by the Minister in response to a question on notice. It quite misrepresents me to say that I was making unsubstantiated allegations. It is very disturbing that both Mr Speaker and the Minister should seek to defend the situation when the Minister for Defence supplied the information on the subject about which I asked my question. These are certainly not allegations. It is very disturbing that they should defend a situation where these events take place--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Fraser has established his point. The misrepresentation tends to be somewhat vague in nature, though important to the honourable member. I feel that he has taken the time of the House to accommodate his requirement.
