PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Jacobi, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The frequent calls for a national approach to solve the problems of the River Murray and the steadfast refusal of the national Government to become involved in interstate arguments about the river's management, exemplify the fact that water resources management in Australia to achieve national objectives at the highest and broadest levels is virtually non-existent. This is undeniable and has been noted by every commentator on water resources management in Australia. It is not surprising that such deficiencies should exist when the Australian Constitution omits water management as a specific responsibility of the national Government. But national governments have almost invariably attempted to adopt the narrowest interpretation of their residual responsibilities and powers with respect to water management.

The Bill I am introducing today provides for the establishment of an Australian Institute of Freshwater Studies to upgrade and extend the research and planning of freshwater resources; in short, to provide the framework for better management of the most basic of resources in a dry continent-water. The establishment of such a national institute will not, of itself, solve the problems of the River Murray or similar national problems. It would, however, greatly assist by providing impartial information whereby the claims and requirements of the various managing State authorities could be investigated and evaluated, whereby the problems could be better defined and whereby optimal solutions are most likely to be derived in the national interest. The manner in which the Institute can play its envisaged role can be assessed from the wording of the Bill itself. It should be noted, however, that the charter of the Institute itself would not be settled until an interim council had been established by the Government to examine the situation more closely.
Overseas Experience

The establishment of an Institute of Freshwater Studies is by no means a unique proposal. Similar institutes exist in many developed countries including, for example, Canada, the United Kingdom, South Africa, New Zealand and Israel. Indeed, it is quite anomalous that the driest continent, Australia, presently lacks such an institute. The charters of these overseas institutes indicate the importance placed on water research by the countries in which they are located. The high priority given such institutes by Israel and South Africa, where, like Australia, water is a basic resource in short supply, is, of course, no coincidence.

These countries have recognised the vital role of water research, investigation and management to their national well-being. These countries have recognised that the problems of water management are extricably tied to the nature and complexity of their localised geography; that is, their soils, topography, industries, agriculture and water demands. These countries have clearly seen that the problems of one country are inevitably individual to that country and cannot necessarily be solved by taking results from elsewhere. That feature, above all, applies in Australia. For example, the irrigation problems along the River Murray, which has mainly sodium salinity, require a quite different solution to those of irrigation areas of the United States of America or Israel where salinity is mainly of the calcium type. We require a solution which can be found only in Australia, by using our own brains and resources.
The Situation in Australia

In comparison with other countries we can ask what organisations does Australia have and what level of effort Australia applies to the solution of its problems. Firstly, the level of funding of freshwater research in Australia is totally inadequate. The allocation to the Australian Water Resources Council for research purposes in the last Budget was a mere $450,000. Let us compare this figure with that received by just one freshwater research laboratory in the United Kingdom in 1980-$2,500,000. With this limited level of funding for the AWRC, even the best organisation in the world would be hard pressed to make any impression on the growing water problems of this vast and largely arid nation. But worse than that, the organisations we do have are woefully fragmented or inappropriate to the tasks.

Firstly, the Department of National Development and Energy, of which the Australian Water Resources Council is part, is involved only in administrative and policy areas. Neither organisation directly undertakes investigation or research, although they do have some limited control or influence on these activities by their funding powers. Nor do they make decisions or recommendations on specific or contentious management issues.

Secondly, there are the bureaucratic State water authorities which are the main centres of water management responsibility in Australia. These bodies attempt to allocate fairly the waters within their areas of responsibility and to keep them free from pollution. But their areas of responsibility, especially State boundaries, do not coincide with catchment boundaries and squabbles inevitably arise over interstate rivers. In general, senior officers of water authorities are competent and dedicated engineers, but the problems of water management are becoming increasingly associated with chemistry and biology. It is not surprising then that such officers are finding it ever-harder to keep abreast of the nature of the problems, let alone the solutions. The water authorities do not generally undertake fundamental research; that is, work of a basic type and of national application. Whilst they do carry out many investigations, these invariably only cover areas within their State boundaries and therefore cannot address the allocation or pollution of waters of interstate rivers.

The third organisation is the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. The CSIRO undertakes some water research, but it is scattered among 14 different sections of the organisation. The Senate standing committee on National Resources recommended in 1978 that there be a separate water resources division within CSIRO. I concede that this could be an alternative to an independent institute. However, the CSIRO has generally not taken up research or investigations where social, legal or cultural values have to be evaluated. But these questions are of vital concern to water management, as also is the development of new technologies from previous research. Unless the CSIRO were to be significantly changed, given enlarged responsibilities and a greatly increased budget, the responsibility and activities of the proposed Institute could not be incorporated.

Fourthly, the universities perform considerable and valuable research and several have on-going interests in water subjects. However, none are adequately funded or manned to carry out the level and type of research and investigation envisaged. The last of the water organisations are the commissions specifically set up to manage interstate rivers. The best known of these is the River Murray Commission. Its deficiencies are numerous. Its powers relate only to the quantity of water in the main stream of the River Murray, plus certain off-river storages. Consequently, it has no control over the quality of water in the river, nor over adjacent land practices, nor over activities on the tributaries of the Murray which might lead to a deterioration in quality.

The Commission has a staff of only 10 to manage thousands of miles of river and, like the State water authorities that it serves, has little real expertise in the biological questions which are increasingly important in determining water quality. Consequently, engineering works along the Murray have often been constructed by and on behalf of the Commission, without proper study of their impacts on the river ecology. The Commission does not undertake research, and it does not include Queensland under whose jurisdiction much of the headwaters of the Darling lie. Like all federalist co-operative bodies, the Commission produces lowest common denominator decisions and takes an enormous amount of time to reach them. There is much labouring to bring forth a gnat. In relation to the River Murray Commission, Professor Sandford Clark, a recognised expert on international water legislation and rivers, pointed out that 'a commission must have considerable independence and autonomy if it is to be effective' and that 'there is an inconsistency in creating an organisation and then denying it the powers to undertake its tasks'.

My criticisms of the River Murray Commission should not be taken in any way as a reflection on its staff, nor do they suggest that there is no need for such a body. The point is that the River Murray Commission and similar commissions are not institutionally structured effectively to solve many of the pressing problems of interstate rivers let alone other problems of a national nature in water resource management. Whilst changes have been proposed to widen the scope of the Commission's operation, there are fundamental limitations which these changes will not and cannot overcome. The expanded River Murray Commission is to have responsibility for mainstream water quality but, at best, will be able to make recommendations only with respect to water quality in tributary streams. It is not possible to control river pollution without control over what enters the river. It is nonsense to think otherwise. In any case, the Commission has effectively had the power, if it can be called that, over water quality under an informal agreement made by the States and the Commonwealth five years ago. One government expert who is reported in a recent article in the Australian summed up the real barrier to resolve the mounting issues facing this river system in these terms:

If we can get rid of the need for unanimity we would have travelled a long way to solving the problems. The ability to make majority decisions will give the Commission real power to censure not just to recommend, any government which bucked a three-to-one vote against it would have to stand up and be counted.

However only South Australia is prepared to do so. Further, most legal experts agree that it will be impossible to convince, or even force, New South Wales and Victoria to surrender their rights over the Murray, its tributaries and the lands adjoining them, which would be necessary if the Commission were given the power envisaged by South Australia and other organisations such as the River Murray Valley League.

Finally, if the river's problems are to be solved, it will be necessary to conduct research and adopt a new approach towards them. Biologists and other scientists need to be considerably more involved in management of the river.
Problems of the Murray

Much has been said about salinity, silting, pollution and other river problems, but it is quite extraordinary and scandalous that so little research into the cause, nature and effects of these problems is undertaken. After 100 years of thoughtless exploitation, the viability of the River Murray system as a resource is in jeopardy. Honourable members will recall that recently it even ceased flowing to the sea. If present trends continue, it is only a matter of years-or less if there is prolonged drought-before this river and its tributaries, which supply most of South Australia and many thousands of people in New South Wales and Victoria with domestic water, become not merely unpleasant, but quite undrinkable, and practically useless for irrigation. Without the expenditure of enormous sums of money on moves to rectify past and present poor practice the river is now at crisis point. Six features of this unique system have lead to this crisis. They are:
1. the aridity of the region;
2. the enormous extent to which existing water resources are exploited;
3. the frightening rate of salinity increase from source to sea, greatly exacerbated by irrigation and clearing;
4. the pathetic infighting between states bordering the resource, all behind the smoke screen of sovereign rights;
5. the almost total lack of knowledge of the way in which the system functions ecologically; and
6. the lack of effective management based on sound knowledge.

The Institute to be established by this Bill can overcome the problem of lack of knowledge, can investigate different and improved management options and can provide impartial arbitration between States. It is the only reasonable hope we have for better management of the river system. By investigation of options before, rather than after, a decision is taken, much of the cause for conflict will be reduced. By adopting a national viewpoint in its investigations, the mutual concern and possible distrust between the upstream and downstream interests can be largely dispelled at the early stages. The institute would look at the river system from a much broader perspective than can be achieved by the separate State bureaucracies responsible for management of the river. As consumers of water, we ask our river to dilute and carry away our sewage, cool and supply our industries, remove our industrial effluents-heavy metals, chemicals, oils and so on-act as a means of transport and recreation, irrigate our crops, water our stock, carry away fertilisers and pesticides, cook our foods, clean us and provide drinking water. Yet we know next to nothing of the way in which rivers operate to carry out this multiplicity of functions, particularly those involving waste material processing.

There is no current, co-ordinated research on river systems as a whole. There is only one river laboratory in the entire River Murray Basin, which is a small one associated with the development of Albury-Wodonga. Salinity is increasing at an alarming rate in many river systems throughout Australia. Numerous examples of rivers which have become unusable can be cited in western and south-eastern Australia due to unthinking land use practices. We do not know how long it will be before citrus and viticulture fails along the Murray but we can be sure that it will happen in our lifetimes. We do not know how many more upstream irrigation licences will be granted before the lower Murray irrigation industries totally collapse. We have only sketchy ideas of the current cost of salinification to industry, home consumption, the motor trade and to agriculture. We can only guess at how much it might cost to desalinate Murray water if it reaches unacceptable salt levels, or to find alternative sources of water. The total cost to the public and industry would be astronomical, and is probably already unacceptable.

Because the River Murray catchment does not conform to State boundaries, the information and research on which effective management is based must be national in character. What is done to one part of the river clearly affects conditions elsewhere, yet this elementary fact has been ignored by State and local authorities for more than 100 years. The rapid decline of the river in its lower reaches after 80 years of federation is testimony to the failure to understand the interactions of the river on a basin-wide basis. However, the River Murray is only one of Australia's interstate rivers.
The Problem of Interstate Rivers

Because of the mismatch between natural catchment boundaries and State boundaries, surface run-off in rivers covering 40 per cent of the area of Australia where rivers and streams exist-that is, excluding the central and western deserts-are involved in interstate transfers. These rivers are generally the interior flowing rivers with low flows. Thus competing demands of the different States and demands within the States are less likely to be readily satisfied and interstate conflicts will arise more readily with these rivers. No agreement exists for any of the interstate river systems, except for the border rivers of New South Wales, and Queensland, and for the River Murray. I suggest that all honourable members should look at the River Murray agreement. It is larger than the whole of the Canada Water Act.

One can imagine the stalemate which would exist if Queensland wished to build a large dam on the headwaters of the Cooper or Diamantina, thus diminishing the flows essential to the livelihood of some South Australian pastoralists. Such a conflict did, in fact, take place in the 1960s concerning a proposal to divert part of the Cooper into Lake Yamma Yamma. The proposal was dropped after objections by South Australia. The Institute could carry out studies into possible ways of allocating interstate waters well before conflict arose over specific issues. Parties from the various States could be brought together in an informed manner, free from political pressure, to discuss the implications of various allocations and regulations and to make sure that all their interests and concerns were fully identified and accounted for.

A national institute is also needed to co-ordinate other water research which must necessarily be of a national character. One such example is the Australian Representative Basins Program, a boldly conceived project which was to have been a showpiece of Australian national hydrology. Unfortunately, the project has failed, and failed miserably, because at the fundamental level the States and the Commonwealth were unable to co-ordinate their efforts. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document detailing this program, including the reasons for its failure.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN REPRESENTATIVE BASINS PROGRAM

In 1964 following the introduction of the International Hydrological Decade, and as part of Australia's contribution to the decade, the concept of a national program of hydrological investigation of some 100 medium to small river basins throughout Australia was adopted. The program was known as the Australian Representative Basins Program. The aim of the program was to study the hydrological response of these 100 basins, which were chosen to be distinctive, but representative of the larger region surrounding them, and thus to be able to explain why and to what extent the hydrological response of the catchments differed. Success in this program would have enabled the data collected from these catchments to be used to solve water problems arising on the many other catchments where either no data existed, or where date could not be quickly or economically collected. In other words it was a far sighted plan which attempted to anticipate a whole range of problems the nation might face in the management of its many thousands of such catchments, to collect data on an efficient scale, and to perform analyses which would extend the understanding of scientists and engineers and enable them to solve these problems with a greatly improved efficiency. The program was enthusiastically adopted by most parties and was to be jointly operated by the States and Commonwealth Authorities.

However, within a short period, the whole program ran into problems. One very severe problem was the imbalance between the commitment of the various parties to the data collection operation. The rainfall data was, in general, to be collected and processed by the Commonwealth Bureau of Meteorology. The streamflow data was to be collected by the various State authorities.

The States undertook their commitment with varying success, but the Bureau of Meteorology consistently failed to undertake its commitment to collect rainfall data. Despite repeated calls by the AWRC, the Bureau was never funded or manned at the appropriate level by the Commonwealth Government to enable it to meet its commitment.
Since the main objective of the program was to study the relationship between rainfall and subsequent streamflow, the absence of adequate rainfall data meant the effective ruin of the whole program.

CSIRO spent many man years in attempting to set up a mathematical hydrological model of the catchment processes under their part of the program, but without sufficient co-ordinated rainfall and streamflow data the model could not be effectively directed or improved.
In total 6 million dollars were spent on the program over the period (including CSIRO component).
A review of the program is currently underway by the AWRC. These problems with the program have been noted and it is almost certain that the program will be severely curtailed, if not scrapped.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The problems of management faced by this program are typical of the problems any national approach to water management in Australia faces. Had an institute existed-I say this to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) in all sincerity-adequate centralised management and representation could have been arranged. Better co-ordination of the involved organisations could have been provided and technical studies undertaken to ensure that the national importance and benefit of the study was fully appreciated by all concerned. The AWRC still suffers from the lack of ability to have technical studies of a national venture undertaken. The AWRC secretariat is not staffed to the appropriate level, not adequately qualified in a sufficiently wide range of areas to undertake a whole range of investigations required to enable the AWRC to reach its policy decisions on an informed basis. I suggest that the proposed institute could fill this gap.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a natural conservatism in the State authorities to use new technologies. Australian scientists have been amongst world leaders in the development of isotope usage in hydrological studies and pilot studies have shown the effective and cheap use of these techniques. The role of adapting new technical developments for use by water authorities is a task which is well catered for in the water industries of many developed countries. Again, Australia has no such national facility. The Institute could fulfil such a role.
The Legal Position

With the nature of existing and potential water resource problems, there should be no doubt that the Commonwealth has a clear obligation in the national interest to investigate the proper use and management of our inland water resources and to move towards a more rational position. The so-called 'national implied powers' of the Commonwealth provide it with the power to establish a body which would investigate and make recommendations on the problems which bedevil our River Murray system. This power has been described by a number of justices, in particular in the recent Australian Assistance Plan case. Although the scope of this inherent power has yet to be exhaustively defined, a number of justices indicate that the power would be sufficient to extend the involvement of the Commonwealth in research activity, into management investigations particularly when it is appropriate that there must be planning and research at a national level. However, I stress forcibly that the creation of such a national body would by no means pre-empt the responsibility for management which the States undoubtedly have. The Institute could, in fact, create an opportunity to make use of the expertise available in the States and allow this to be extended in an appropriate manner. The operation of the Australian Institute of Freshwater Studies, properly constituted, could complement the work of the States.
The reasoning behind the need for an increased Commonwealth role was best summed up by Mr Justice Mason in the AAP case, to which I have referred. He said:

The functions appropriate and adapted to a national Government will vary from time to time. As time unfolds, as circumstances and conditions alter, it will transpire that particular enterprises and activities will be undertaken, if they are to be undertaken at all, by the national Government.
With respect to the River Murray, this comment could be paraphrased as follows: Solutions to the problems of the River Murray will be found, if they are to be found at all, by the Federal Government.
Previous Proposals

In considering the role of the Federal Government it is opportune to review the important work of Senate committees which have examined water matters. The Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution found, amongst other things:
There are large gaps in the documentation of our water resources and there is no pragmatic program of research into the causes and consequences of water pollution, or into its economics.

The Committee also recommended that the Commonwealth should take urgent steps to establish a national water commission. Predictably, this body was objected to by States because of the threat to their bureaucratic empires. In 1978 the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources released a report which recommended a national approach to water resources and supported the establishment of an independent bureau of water resources to undertake all the Commonwealth's non-policy, co-ordination, technical and information activities. In response the Government stated: 'This recommendation would signify a considerable broadening of the Commonwealth's role in water resource matters, but the Government does not believe that such a step is justified at this time. This recommendation will be reviewed if warranted by changed circumstances at some later stage'. I suggest that a considerable broadening of the Commonwealth's role is urgently required and that circumstances relating to the river's management have indeed changed-for the worse.
In June 1979 the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment released a progress report which found:

. . . many people along the river are obviously frustrated by the apparent inability of any one department, Commonwealth or State, to take responsibility for providing responses to views and grievances.

An Institute of Freshwater Studies that was available to the Commonwealth and States for research into specific matters affecting water management decisions, or that was able to initiate its own research into such questions, would clearly not conflict with the recommendation of these three committees and it would bring many advantages. Firstly, research by the Institute would view the river system as a whole. The evaluation of benefits and costs for proposed river works could be assessed by the Institute from a national viewpoint, rather than from a local or regional perspective.

Secondly, the Institute would be free of governmental interference so that it could bring impartiality and objectivity to the consideration of such matters. Whilst final decisions on water resource matters will lie with the States, at least the information on which those decisions are made would be the best available. As I have previously shown, much key information is presently not available at all. Thirdly, the Institute would examine the environmental and biological aspects of water quality. It has become increasing well understood that salinity and other problems cannot be tackled effectively if they are divorced from changes to the river's ecology. The River Murray Commission has in recent years formed sub-committees to look at some of these problems but there is no evidence of any meaningful progress in these areas over the past five years. In any case, the expertise available to the States in this area is minimal. By contrast I would expect that the Institute of Freshwater Studies would be staffed by prominent biologists, hydrologists, chemists, microbiologists and medical researchers, with support from economists and engineers.

Fourthly, the Institute could play a role in the more rapid introduction of improved technologies and practices which are so vital if many of the poor, present methods are to be avoided. Issues associated with the River Murray are the most vexed and most important questions facing us today in the water field. However, there are many other areas where the Institute could undertake useful research for Federal, State and local bodies. The recent and tragic death of a child in South Australia from amoebic meningoencephalitis, a water-borne disease, is a case in point. The South Australian Government decided after the death of this child that some research was needed and accordingly voted funds amounting to $150,000 for that purpose. However this is a national problem and research should have commenced beforehand. The need for such research was recognised several years ago.
Conclusions

Any proposal to establish a new statutory body at this time of unprecedented demands for Commonwealth funds is not a step to be taken lightly. However, there are several points in relation to the cost of the proposed Institute which should be considered. Firstly, the value of the industries and communities at risk from water problems must run into billions of dollars. The cost of protecting these industries and communities is already growing rapidly. In this context the work of the proposed Institute could save taxpayers many millions of dollars by examining ways to improve the management of our threatened waterways.

Secondly, if the Institute were available for contract research it could earn substantial income both from government and industry. There is evidence that sections of industry would welcome the services of a top-rate water research body. The problems posed to water supply by certain mining operations are a case in point. A statutory body would be welcomed in such situations, both for its impartiality and reputation, and also for the absence of comparable bodies in the private sector.

Thirdly, there is the question of priorities. We already have an Australian Institute of Marine Science which is housed in a multi-million dollar modern complex near Townsville, and which was given $5.5m in 1980-81 to expand its research into marine biology. We will spend $24.5m on the Antarctic this year, including $1.2m specifically to build up marine research. In addition, a grant of $2.3m is made through the Australian Marine Science and Technologies Advisory Committee for research into marine science. That is a total of $9m. By contrast, research into inland waters, and particularly into such a vital economic asset as the Murray-Darling system, has been almost completely neglected. Are our inland waters that much less important to us than those around our coast and in the Antarctic? (Extension of time granted).

Finally, I will briefly outline the mechanics of this Bill and the procedure to be followed in the establishment of the Australian Institute of Freshwater Studies. The procedure is similar to that used to set up the Australian Institute of Marine Science in 1970. Firstly, an interim council for the Institute will be appointed by the Minister for Science and Technology. The interim council will consist of five members, including two persons with appropriate qualifications. This body will make recommendations to the Minister concerning the functions and powers of the Institute, its constitution, the site of the seat of the Institute, how it should co-operate with Commonwealth and State authorities and other research institutions and, finally, the interim council will estimate the capital and recurrent costs of the Institute. The scope of the interim council's investigations is set out in section 7 (2) of the Bill. After the recommendations of the interim council have been received by the Minister, the Institute will be given such functions and powers as the Parliament then determines.

As I said at the beginning of this speech, the measures proposed in this Bill will not by themselves solve all the major water resource problems facing Australia. However, this Bill provides a challenge to the national Parliament to assume its responsibilities and take the first steps to correct past failures. It is politicians who have failed to manage properly our water resources, and squabbles over power and empires have put at risk our most precious resource. It is time that parochial and vested interests were swept aside and that effective, impartial and national approaches were taken to our water resources. As the first step in that direction, I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. I fully support my colleague, the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi), in putting forward his proposition for the establishment of an Australian Institute of Freshwater Studies, and I congratulate him for the speech he has made and the arguments he has used. The case he has made is one that deliberately avoids party politics and wrangling and seeks a solution to one of Australia's most important problems. He has explained the reasons why the existing bodies are inadequate and has been honest in stating that the Institute will be a means whereby objective knowledge will be put forward so that no single government will be able to take recourse to the arguments of States' rights as an excuse for not doing anything or acting irresponsibly, particularly with respect to the River Murray system. But, of course, an institute such as that proposed would not just be concerned with the River Murray system, although that system is our most important fresh water problem today.

SPEECH.PARA: My brief comments will refer to the Murray River system from an agricultural resource point of view. I am not complacent or sanguine about the future of Australia's greatest natural resource. It is my firm belief that the problems of the Murray River system will not be solved until the five governments concerned institute a single control body for the system, with effective regulatory powers to control water quality as well as quantity. I believe that in the interim the allocation of additional-I mean net additional-irrigation licences should be made with great caution and that the Commonwealth Government should get more fully involved in the provision of funds for rehabilitative work. I believe also that the proposed Institute should be set up.

The twin questions of saline water tables in many irrigation areas and rising levels of salinity in the River Murray and some of its tributaries are well comprehended. But, there has been a history of inaction at governmental level. The reasons for the inaction have been threefold: Firstly, a lack of a comprehensive and co-ordinated approach; secondly, the failure to regard the Murray River system as a natural living system and to manage it as such; and, thirdly, in-fighting and adherence by State authorities to the letter of agreements reached by compromise, or the lowest common denominator approach, as outlined by the honourable member for Hawker.

The Murray River system has provided a source of development and wealth for three States and indeed the nation for a considerable part of our history. This, together with its recreational and conservation value, makes it a priceless national asset and an important part of our national heritage. But it is also an extremely complex and fragile natural resource and as such very real limits exist as to how far it can be exploited. Sadly, lack of adequate knowledge and careless improper management have brought the Murray to its knees. Unless substantial action is undertaken now the quality of our most important water resource will be destroyed, with costly consequences for future generations of Australians.

There are two separately identifiable, though interrelated, problems threatening the viability of agricultural areas along the Murray and its tributaries-rising watertables and associated salinisation, and high salinity levels in the river itself. Together, they are responsible for significant drops in yield and the degradation of huge tracts of farmland. To understand how this crisis situation has come about it is necessary to go back to when the land was first being utilised for cropping and grazing. The actions of the early settlers and their descendants had a profound effect on the management problems of today. Mistakes in land use and management-such as widespread clearing, disruption of natural drainage systems and introduction of exotic weeds-were made. What could have been valuable renewable resources were squandered in the quest for a quick return. However, there is little point now in engaging in recriminations with our ancestors. Their priorities cannot be evaluated properly now. They were also acting with a defective body of information on soils, water, vegetation and, most importantly, how natural systems operate. We have learned a great deal in the last century about management of agricultural lands; unfortunately, the problems seems more to be our inability to implement what we have learned.

Two features of the natural environment in particular have caused substantial problems for irrigators. Firstly, the hydrological systems which evolved, whether surface or subsurface, under natural conditions largely did so in an arid environment; that is, they evolved to cope with relatively low inputs of water. Irrigation has resulted in massive increases in the amounts of water these drainage systems have to handle. One of the results is that in areas where subsurface flow characteristics have not been able to adjust, watertables have been forced to rise. When the watertable reaches the root zone waterlogging occurs and yields decrease. Often the watertable rises through soil containing high concentrates of salt. When this occurs the salt is mobilised in solution and carried to the root zone where it harms vegetation. Eventually this salt may enter the river, adding to salinity levels in the mainstream itself. The second feature is that much of the underlying sediment and groundwater, particularly along the lower reaches, is naturally very salty. This is because for millions of years the sea extended as far east as Swan Hill. This natural saltiness has been mobilised by land clearing, river structures and irrigation drainage. The resulting high levels of salinity in the river itself reduces crop yields and limits the choice of crops which can be grown by irrigation relying on river water.

When discussing water quality and drainage problems in relation to agricultural production along the Murray System it is helpful to perceive the area in terms of two distinct zones with the dividing line running approximately through Swan Hill. To the east is what is generally known as the Riverina Plains zone and to the west the Mallee zone. These zones can be differentiated not only in relation to geographical factors but also in that farmers in each face different salinity problems. The Riverina Plains zone produces mainly livestock, although other things are grown also. Irrigation is used to grow pastures and supporting fodder crops. Horticulture is important around Shepparton whilst rice is an important crop in the Deniliquin region. The production levels of those areas are very much threatened by rising watertables and associated movement of salt into the root zone. If the Shepparton region has a very wet winter, the problem with pear trees becomes crucial. Downstream in the Sunraysia and Riverland regions of the Mallee zone the predominant land use, horticulture, suffers from high salinity levels in the river water used for irrigation.

The important thing to realise is that the two problems are related with salinity levels in the Murray being affected by mobilisation of salt by rising watertables. The fact that the effects of irrigation in the Riverina Plains are felt by those many miles downstream has been the cause of long bitter arguments between the States. The effects of rising watertables and increasing salinity are not always physically noticeable to the passer by or even farmers themselves. Degradation occurs over a period and marginal decreases in yield often occur long before vegetation dies or salt appears at the surface. Further, salinity levels in irrigation water fluctuate markedly with changes in the volume of flow. Drought conditions can lead to much higher concentrations. Therefore, the situation is considerably worse than may be indicated by the extent of land that has become completely unproductive. In addition, production on some salt affected farms may have been maintained, but only by costly increases in labour and capital.

On a regional basis the seriousness of the problem is highly variable, dependent on land use and location. For instance only 1 per cent of the Deniliquin region is at present affected by shallow watertables and the underlying sediments appear to have a relatively low salt content. Yet, on the opposite banks of the river, in the Kerang region, many farms have been put out of production and on others farmers are struggling to make a living on properties badly affected by salt. Two-thirds of this region is underlain by a highly saline watertable within 2 metres of the surface. Barr Creek, which drains the region, adds about 150,000 tonnes of salt a year to the Murray. Obviously for the 3,500 people who live in the region a very real crisis exists.

Other regions have also had their social and economic wellbeing seriously dislocated. The prime fruit producing areas around Shepparton have symptoms of salinity in more than half of the region's famous pear trees. Unless something is done here the area of land affected by saline watertables is expected to increase threefold by the year 2000. If this is allowed to happen it could spell the end for this rich, intensively irrigated district presently supporting 70,000 people. The Wakool region has also been seriously affected, although here the problem is less widespread. However, the situation is expected to worsen in the next few years.

Downstream in the horticultural areas of Sunraysia and the South Australian Riverland irrigation farmers have to battle against lost markets, inadequate farm size and insufficient resources as well as salty irrigation water. The threat of a high concentration of salt is greatest in years of reduced flow. Therefore during most years salinity levels are not high enough to affect crops directly. However, evidence suggests that when damage does occur it may remain evident for two to three years; further, if internal drainage is not good salty soils will develop. The towns and irrigation settlements along the arid lower reaches of the system are almost totally dependent on irrigated agriculture for their existence; there is very little else they can turn to.

Obviously the twin problems of rising watertables and salinisation pose serious threats to the continued socio-economic viability of irrigation dependent areas along the Murray system. Further, they pose a serious environmental threat and impose considerable costs, including health costs, on domestic users. A quick examination of relevant available material shows that there has been no shortage of research carried out into the problem. Nor has this situation suddenly appeared. Rather, the seriousness of the problem has been realised by governments for at least the past 12 years. Indeed, water quality has been the source of infighting between the four governments directly concerned for just as long. If bitter words and so-called protection of sovereign rights could improve salinity levels the rivers waters would be crystal clear by now. I have already given the reasons why there has been inaction.

Managing a complex resource system like the Murray for each of the many differing and often conflicting possible uses is a daunting enough task, but when the management policies must satisfy four separate governments it becomes impossible. The fragmented approach that has existed to date has proven to be woefully inadequate. Bitter infighting has been going on between the States over the Murray since before Federation. Implementation of the River Murray Water Agreement in 1915 solved many of the problems regarding water quantity. This provided for the appointment of the River Murray Commission to give effect to the agreement and authorised the construction of works and the apportionment of water between the States. However, the Commission was given no responsibility for water quality. As a result, any attempts to deal with problems of salinity have been on a State by State basis. This has proven to be both costly and unsuccessful.

Steps were first undertaken to have water quality brought under the auspices of the River Murray Commission early in 1973. Amendments to the River Murray Water Agreement were finally decided on in 1975. As of yet the necessary legislation has not been formally implemented. The worst of all this is not that it has taken eight years to decide on and implement amendments concerning water quality, but that the amendments will make little real difference to the situation. They will enable the River Murray Commission to monitor salinity levels, co-ordinate research, recommend standards, and advise the States on control measures with relation to water quality. In other words, all they do is make the Commission an advisory body to the States. It still will not have effective powers directly to control salinity and its associated problems along the river. Further, and most importantly, the agreed upon changes to the agreement will only allow the River Murray Commission to become involved with quality in the main stream; they do not include tributaries. It is absolute nonsense that we do not involve tributaries. Obviously the success of these changes depends almost entirely on the extent to which the States are prepared to co-operate.

Almost every independent body that has had anything to do with the water quality problems of the Murray System has pointed out how formal and informal institutional constraints have effectively limited mitigation of the effects of shallow watertables and salinisation. Similarly, there is a general concensus that a comprehensive and co-ordinated approach is required to deal with the problems both in the short and long term. As pointed out by Maunsell and Partners in their Murray Valley salinity and drainage report:
It is often not physically possible or economically desirable to deal with these problems on a State by State basis.

The answer lies in control being empowered with a single body which is the sole source of administrative and regulatory power. Inarguably the Murray River system is a resource of national importance. As such it is up to the Federal Government to become more involved before it is too late and this important part of our national heritage is lost not only to the present generation but also to all future generations of Australians.

The second fundamental management issue that I see as being of central importance to the survival of the Murray is that to date there has been a failure to recognise the Murray system as a single renewable natural resource governed essentially by laws of nature. It is a geographic and ecological unit; therefore changes in any part of it will be felt throughout. Thus, having one body to manage soil conservation, another irrigation, another recreation, yet another conservation and then duplicating the whole arrangement every time the river croses State boundaries reflects a thorough disregard or ignorance of the interdependence and complexity of the Murray as a renewable resource.

The present situation of decreasing yields and loss of tracts of agricultural land is basically due to a failure to understand the ecological implications of wide-spread clearing and disruption of natural drainage systems. Surely we have learned enough from our mistakes to realise the importance of ecological guidelines to land use management. Our overall goal for the management of the Murray should be to utilise it in such a way that in the long term it remains a viable renewable resource capable of sustained output. Yet it is well recognised that the Murray will be able to provide sustained agricultural yields provided sound conservation practices are adopted.

A positive relationship exists between maintaining as much as possible, natural processes and sustained rural incomes, because once land and water start to degrade it becomes more and more costly to maintain production, and eventually it must decline. Many of the measures likely to result in a significant long term improvement in water quality are on farm and as such require farmer acceptance rather than large scale capital works. Here I could point to the impact of laser grading in helping farmers. Some examples include improved methods of water application, improved farm layout, changes in crop types and in some cases perhaps even land retirement.

Further, planners when attempting to formulate strategies for dealing with drainage and salinity should realise that these are only some of the problems facing farmers in the Murray Valley. Farmers particularly in the horticultural industries are simultaneously trying to cope with other major social and economic problems. Solutions to salinity and drainage problems need to be integrated where appropriate with other government policies and programs relating to agriculture. The situation for thousands of farmers and their families living along the Murray and for towns along the Murray is grave. This area, once commonly known as Australia's 'food basket', is steadily losing ground to the advance of rising watertables of salt. Effective action needs to be taken now if the viability of this national resource is to be maintained for future generations. In my few brief remarks I have tried to stress the agricultural aspects of the problems being faced by the Murray and the whole Murray River system. I have stressed the fact that it is a living natural resource. What we need is some means whereby the States and the Commonwealth can get together with objective information and do something about the greatest natural resource that Australians possess. I fully back the Bill introduced by the honourable member for Hawker which calls for the establishment of an Institute of Fresh Water Studies. Once again I congratulate him. I am sure that most members of this House and people in the Riverland and irrigation areas of this country would thank the honourable member for the initiative he has taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted to proceed with the debate forthwith? There being no objection, leave is granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Mr G.O'H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was surprised that the seconder of the motion that the Bill be now read a second time, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), spoke. I understood the agreement was that one member from each side would speak. I guess I will have to confine my remarks more than I wished to do. The honourable member for Werriwa did not say anything particularly new. On the other hand, the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi), produced a challenging document that deserves to be taken seriously by the House. Therefore, I will not comment on the remarks of the honourable member for Werriwa except to remind the House that the previous honourable member for Werriwa, the former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, succeeded in delaying the construction of the Dartmouth Dam for two years. I do not wish to carry on that line or to get too political but I make the comment that if the Hume Dam and the Dartmouth Dam had been filled a year or two ago the parlous position of South Australia today would be markedly improved. I will get on to the remarks made by the honourable member for Hawker. To help set the scene and save me some time I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard a chart showing percentages of current demands on the River Murray system in both an average year and a dry year. I have shown the chart to the honourable member for Hawker.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Werriwa and the House. Personally, I am quite relaxed about the Institute of Freshwater Studies Bill brought down by the honourable member for Hawker. I congratulate him on his initiative. I am probably forced by lack of time to comment critically as best I can on what he put forward. In doing so I acknowledge that he has done something that is badly needed at this time, that is to try to rethink the shibboleths of the past and try to cope with the problem in the essence which he has put down in this Bill this afternoon. As I see it, the problem is not so much in the research area as it is in the area of proper statistical analysis and management of the role of the River Murray Commission. Added to that, the problem relates to politics and the Constitution. I have given one small example. No doubt Opposition members can give others in return at a later time when the issue is more fully debated.

SPEECH.PARA: As a member representing a vast mileage of the River Murray in South Australia I have had to deal constantly with the problems of the quality and flow of water to South Australia over a long period. From 1964 to 1970 we made quite a deal of progress in small ways. That must not be forgotten. Then along came the new shining star of the moment, Prime Minister Whitlam. I remember leading for the Opposition in a debate on a Bill. I was at the table where the honourable member for Werriwa now is. I was then the member for Angas. The honourable member for Maribyrnong, (Dr Cass), the then Prime Minister and I had a great meeting of minds. I have in my file several speeches by the Prime Minister of that time saying what needed to be done and how he intended to do it. I will not weary the House by going over every aspect of those speeches. I think it is sufficient to say that at the end of three years as Prime Minister he must have been wholesomely disenchanted with the system. He achieved very little. We will have achieved considerably more at the point when the New South Wales Government agrees-I hope it will not be too far off now-on the last sticking point, being whether it will provide statistics on industrial pollution. A Bill empowering the River Murray Commission much more fully will then be brought into this House. I think it is important to think back to those days. Although Prime Minister Whitlam was not able to achieve nearly as much as he wanted to, another member now in this House, an ex-Premier of South Australia, the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), achieved more for South Australia. This highlights the question of whether this matter can be partially cured by the States or whether it must be wholly cured by the Commonwealth. Mr Steele Hall increased the water allocation from 1.254 million acre feet to 1.5 million acre feet. In modern parlance that is 1,850 gigalitres. It represented a 37 per cent increase in the disposable water available to South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that in acre feet?

—I can do acre feet only in relation to gallons, not gigalitres. I noticed that the Parliamentary Library involved me in, I think, 13 speeches and repeated questions during the 1970s. Of course, many other members in this place and in another place have also taken a great interest in these matters. Over that period, the Commonwealth Government found there was very little it could do. Let us face it, that is the first lesson that this House has to understand. A senator of a political colour other than mine recently argued in the other place along the same lines as I intend to argue now. We can legislate in this House until we are blue in the face but unless we have agreement by all the parties to the River Murray Commission we may be left with nothing. Nothing can be considerably worse than what we have now. This argument, of course, can apply not only to a Senate committee recommendation setting up a foundation to cover a broader base area but also, no doubt to an Australian institute of freshwater studies. It can apply to an advisory board on water resources with no teeth, which others are seeking. The word 'teeth' is terribly important. As soon as we give any of these bodies teeth, we run into a constitutional problem. Section 100 of the Constitution, which I do not think I have heard used in this House before, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth shall not, by any law or regulation of trade or commerce, abridge the right of a State or of the residents therein to the reasonable use of the waters of rivers for conservation or irrigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No one is suggesting they do that.

—When the High Court looks at this problem, as it always will when any State government objects to overriding federal legislation, I imagine it will apply its mind to that section. Further, I imagine, without being a lawyer, that it will direct its mind towards the overriding powers of the States unless such powers are spelled out in the Constitution. Honourable members must remember that unless the whole tune of the High Court changes, which for all I know it might, it must-up to now it has-bring down decisions in favour of the Constitution. The Constitution, as I read it, gives the powers over waters to the States. All we can do in this House is to try to adopt a rational, national view and try to convince other State governments by argument, worthy reports and a plethora of other things.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there is a great unanimity of view from one side of the House to the other on this matter. We must impress on the States that our view is the correct one. I comment in passing that this is precisely the stage we are at now, in consultation with the other parties to the agreement in relation to, firstly, further powers for the River Murray Commission which are being held up by one State and, secondly, the future role of the River Murray Commission. Believe it or not, another consultants' report is to be brought down which will enable proper statistical surveys to be taken in any circumstance. As I understand it, the way the Government is currently thinking the next step is terribly important. Once the study is completed, by a flick of the computer finger we will be able to say what will happen if 500 more irrigation licences are granted on the Darling. We will be able to say what will happen if the New South Wales Government grants 100 more water licences on tributaries affecting the River Murray. In other words, at that time-I think it is still probably 2 1/2 years hence-we will be better empowered to know what we are talking about instead of giving opinions.

Let us look at some of the opinions that have been trotted around. I think they are of some interest. Even the honourable member for Hawker, who is most moderate in his views-and others, particularly from the State area-is saying that over the last year salinity has soared in the River Murray system. Quite frankly such a statement, depending on where the figures are taken from, can be taken as a complete lot of nonsense. For example, I refer to the two years 1967 and 1968 in the dry period prior to this one. The quantity of water flowing across the border to South Australia is now considerably greater than it was in those two historically very dry years. Graphs made available by the River Murray Commission show the salinity content at three points from Merbein upriver to Waikerie.

One of the points a lot of people do not realise is that as we move towards achieving 500 parts per million top quality drinking water-I think the present standard is about 800 electrical conductivity units; taking into account that the safe drinking level is about 2,500 EC units-in this year of drought the salinity level of the River Murray as it enters South Australia is lower than it has been in any dry year for quite a period. In fact, due to the influence of Dartmouth Dam, which is built in an area where water quality is good, and due to the fact the Hume Weir-also with fairly good quality water-is being drained during the 1980-81 season, the quality of the water, measured for salinity and not turbidity, has been line ball, up and down only a little bit from the desired quality of excellence in the River Murray system. I have not heard that point of view put. Instead of that view we get glaring headlines 'Politicians sit and do nothing while River Murray dies'. What a lot of rot that is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you support Peter Arnold?

—I was not referring to the speech of the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin). But if he goes on much longer, I will. The River Murray system is not dying. The system cannot be compared with the Colorado system which has dam upon dam until the total output at the end is no larger than a trickle in a dry year and everything from that point up is completely saline. For sure the mouth of the River Murray is closed, but it is still a viable system and is not over-managed. In terms of over-management South Australia, the State that I represent, has a real problem. What happens next?
—If you get another two bad winters you will really know it.

—Oh, yes. But I am not debating that point at present. If there is a move on the part of the Water Resources Council or any one else to build another dam to cope with even more irrigation in New South Wales and to cope with the appalling pull in mid-winter by the Victorian Government for power generation from the Snowy Mountains Scheme, what will South Australia do? Albury-Wodonga will harness more water from the River Murray system. Any further use of water will ultimately affect the downstream areas and the downstream irrigators, as the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) and the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) well know. This sets a very great problem for South Australia as to whether to advise that there should be another upstream storage. If there were it would cut back on the number of floods or freshes that come down which enter the billabongs clearing out the salt and taking the salinity through the main stream, so ensuring that future supplies of water are purer. I do not know the answer to this question but the problem must exercise the minds of those in the South Australian Government very much indeed. If any dam is built upstream in future we will badly need another honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) to negotiate an increase in the share of water from the system. Without that it might well be that South Australia would have to advise against the building of any further storage on the basis that the River Murray must not be too harnessed.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are seeing is a set of circumstances that have occurred in the third driest year in the last 15 years. Of course that sort of drought situation raises a great deal of emotion. If honourable members look at the number of questions I have asked over 17 years as a representative of the area involved they will find there is a great peak in the number of questions asked around the time of droughts. The same situation applies to the number of speeches made. The reason for this is that the community will not get excited unless it is suddenly posed with a problem.

I give full credit to the Sunraysia and Riverland Committee on Salanity. I give full credit to the Save the Murray group in South Australia. The membership of this group is headed by the retiring Senator Gordon Davidson and includes the erstwhile member for Hindmarsh. I commend Senator Jessop and the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, which he chairs, the honourable member for Mallee, the honourable member for Murray and honourable members on the Opposition side who have taken a great deal of interest in the matter. The real purpose of all these groups is to save the Murray in the long term. People downstream, particularly in Adelaide, have a lot of refuse put on them whether it be in terms of nutrients, turbidity or salinity. I give credit to those groups and to other honourable members who are concerning themselves with this problem. On another occasion when I have more time I would like to deal more fully with the implication of the graphs and new statistics published by the River Murray Commission.

I will finish on one point. I refer to South Australia's new water volume entitlement. In dry years the additional waters from the Darling River have no impact at all on the volume received. The entitlement exists without the microscopic volume of water supplied in dry years by the Darling.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact Darling water is part of the problem.

—Exactly; I was just going to mention that. I thank the honourable member for Murray for his comment. I do not believe this totally, but one can argue from that point that South Australia would be better off if New South Wales harnessed the Darling and if no water from the Darling entered South Australia. It is at the times that the water enters the Murray from the Darling that the situation is critical; and the critical time is in dry seasons. It does nothing but add pollution and difficulty, particularly from turbidity and salinity during dry years. Where it is still of course of grave importance to South Australia-this a folk lore belief in my State-is in providing the freshet that comes down the Darling periodically. It saves our lives. It helps to flush in good years. I think that people should recognise that though the Darling and its tributaries are important, in dry seasons they are a positive disadvantage to irrigators and to the quality of water for much of South Australia's capital city and many of its towns. I will finish on this note. I am sorry that this is not a suitable occasion to go into a mathematical analysis of this problem. I congratulate the honourable member for Hawker for his attempt to bring before this House what he sees as a rational way of proceeding. I am not quite so sure myself. The honourable member rattled off a lot of different subjects related to the salinity problem. I noted down quite a few more matters such as engineering, dams, channels, locks, hydro, zoology, biology, fish, ducks, water hyacinths, medicine which we have not really mentioned during this debate. That is a very important aspect.
—Who is handling them now?

—If the honourable member would just put a cork in his mouth I will mention other topics of concern such as rural-mentioned by the honourable member for Werriwa-tourism, decentralisation, economics, environment and River Red Gums which particularly concern my friend, the honourable member for Murray. I ponder whether the honourable member for Hawker is not trying to bureaucratise an enormous series of interests whereby everything would be bogged down and a minimum of action could evolve. Certainly, the River Murray Water Resources Council at this stage would not go along with the idea expressed by the honourable member for Hawker.

—The Minister is showing nervousness of amateurism. I move:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to adopt a code of conduct for Ministers and for Members of Parliament despite the lapse of over three years since the establishment of the Committee of Inquiry into Public Duty and Private Interest.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —For some years now this Parliament has been waiting for a code of conduct that will regulate the propriety of conduct of Ministers and members of this Parliament. It beggars belief-I have to recite this fact-that this matter has been under discussion for some six years, since the inception of the Gordan committee. In 1977 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced in a Press statement that he proposed to set up a committee. This committee became known as the Bowen Committee of Inquiry into Public Duty and Private Interest. I emphasise that it was in December 1977 that that announcement was made. It is significant that at the time the Prime Minister was having a number of difficulties with one of his Ministers because of allegations about profits being made from land speculation because the Minister held a position in public office. On that occasion the Prime Minister said that it was important that there be a whole new approach to a solution of the problem. He further said that he intended to appoint a commission to establish procedures whereby any breach of the high standards demanded of those in public office could be dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: Next in this chronological table, in February 1978, the right honourable gentleman was saying: 'I have now announced the creation of a commission which will comprise Sir Nigel Bowen, Sir Cecil Looker and Sir Edward Cain. I have given them terms of reference.' Those terms of reference seemed to be rather weak in that reference was made to a statement of principles to be drawn upon concerning the question of private interest, whether pecuniary or otherwise. As I said, a report was commissioned in February 1978. It must startle the people of the nation to learn that the report was handed to the Government in July 1979, some two years ago. That adds weight to what I have said in support of this matter of public importance. There has been failure by the Prime Minister, by the Cabinet and by the Government to do anything about adopting a code of conduct for members and Ministers of this Parliament and for a number of other people.

Let us confine discussion to the area in which we can certainly make our own solutions, namely, this Parliament. As the House knows, of late and in fact throughout the whole period since that report was presented, a number of allegations have been made as to whether certain conduct by members of parliament has been proper. Not the least of these allegations have been those concerning the Prime Minister in what became known as the Facom dispute. The question was raised as to whether there had been an undue influence by a tenderer to contact the Prime Minister to suggest that some patronage may be given. The House will recall the intensity of the debate and the fact that tender arrangements were, in fact, cancelled. Only in recent days has it been questioned whether it was proper for two members of the Parliament to accept trips overseas sponsored by a person who might be interested in satellite communications or related matters. I say without any fear of contradiction that the whole of Australia would agree that members of parliament should not accept gifts or patronage because to do so could affect their judgment. Is it not clearly indicated that in accepting gifts it would appear that they were beholden to some sector of the community or some person who expects to gain an advantage from a Government decision? Once the matter was raised in the Parliament, the two honourable gentlemen quite wisely decided not to avail themselves of the trip.

There are other matters from which patronage can be inferred. For example, it is known that amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act, which will be debated shortly were circulated to a number of select people in the community in recent weeks. That seems to indicate that an unfair advantage was given to certain people in the community. If one is interested in the share market or the stock market it could well be to one's advantage to know the intentions of the Government. Details of the proposed new two-airline agreement also were made known to a certain select few. Obviously those with pecuniary interests would be interested in the profits or otherwise that would result from certain Government decisions. Such decisions may affect the share market and the value of the shares that people hold. All those things create the political climate I am discussing today.

Why is it that we have waited for so many years to get a code of conduct which is very simple to define? The interesting thing about the Prime Minister and his style is that when he is asked questions about this matter in the Parliament he seems to attribute the blame for not doing anything to somebody else, namely, the Parliament. This is a curious way of avoiding the fundamental issue. This is tantamount to what happened at the Federal Council of the Liberal Party last week. Whenever a motion on any contentious matter was moved by the Prime Minister's enemy, Sir Charles Court, the Prime Minister promptly seconded the motion. I can think of no better way to anaesthetise the whole matter than to have the Prime Minister second anything. Nothing will happen. It is a ploy that is adopted to avoid any criticism. I have no doubt that every time Sir Charles Court sneezes the Prime Minister will apologise for him. This seems to be a curious public stance. Applying that sort of posture to the problems we now face let us have a look at what happened when the right honourable gentleman was asked by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) what he was going to do about codes of conduct for members. The matter was raised in the Parliament on 26 May last. The Prime Minister said:

Quite plainly members' travel is a matter that members themselves must decide. I think that this instance and the publicity that has related to it have made it quite plain that the sooner this Parliament discusses in detail the Bowen report and applies it to the members of this Parliament the better it will be. That is under discussion at the moment with members of the Parliament. I draw attention to the fact that the Bowen report has been applied in relation to Ministers and the Commonwealth Public Service. Of course, commercially sponsored trips by Ministers would be outlawed under the Bowen report. But I emphasise again that members of Parliament are in a somewhat different position. I believe that they need to make their own judgments about these matters for themselves against the background of experience in the Parliament generally-

Within a matter of hours of making that statement, and again when he had been pressed by my leader about what he was going to do about the Bowen report, he said that we should get ahead and process the Bowen report in relation to members of this Parliament because only then would we have some adequate form of control. If we must get ahead with processing the report, who is stopping us? It is the Prime Minister who has done nothing about it. We have raised this matter in the Parliament time and time again. For example, I raised it on 22 April 1980. Statements have been made in the Parliament by Ministers that there will be discussions about the matter, that it is of considerable importance. Revelations have been made about the shareholdings of Ministers and their families and about the sponsorship of trips. We want to have the matter finalised and dealt with.

That is the background, but I come now to the present situation. Effectively, nothing has been done, and the Opposition suggests today that some action be taken immediately. We think it could be taken by September this year, when the Parliament will be assembled in the Budget session. Before adverting to that, might I address my remarks to the background of a matter which caused some dissention and discussion, namely, what was known as the Webster case. Honourable members will recall that Senator Webster was deemed under the Constitution to have a pecuniary interest because he was a member of a proprietary company that had a beneficial interest in the supply of equipment to the Postal and Telecommunications Department, I think, and the matter was raised in the Parliament. The Constitution states that anybody who has a pecuniary interest can forfeit his right to be a member of the Parliament. The question arises: What is a pecuniary interest? It is significant that Sir Garfield Barwick decided that no pecuniary interest was involved in the case of Webster because, on the basis of an old English law, there was no suggestion of anybody being inhibited by what Webster had done.

The real issue, the real intention, the real background of that law was that members were not to be intimidated by contractors who had contracts with the Crown. It was rather convoluted reasoning, I thought, because any of us who have had experience in either State parliaments or local government know that if a person dares to take part in a decision in that parliament or council on a matter in which he or his family has any interest he is ousted from office, fined, and dealt with on the basis that he has failed to declare his interest. Standing Order 196 says very much the same thing. It is incredible that the Chief Justice of Australia said that our real worry was that we might be inhibited in our discussions in the Parliament because of a contract in which we might have an interest. Surely the modern concept is that people outside would say that we were a bunch of crooks if we were members of this Parliament and did not disclose the fact that we had an interest in the benefit that would flow to us from a contract that was being entered into.

I took the trouble to look at the ancient law, and it is certainly ancient from the point of view of the basis on which the Chief Justice sought to establish his premise. The relevant questions raised by the Chief Justice were in respect of an ancient law that goes back to the eighteenth century or even earlier. If we look at what it was about, despite the fact that it is in old English, it states quite clearly that any person who wishes to be a member of Parliament and is participating in a contract with the public-the Crown at that time-shall be incapable of being elected. That is the first premise to which I do not think the Chief Justice adverted. The second, and I think it is very clear, is that anybody who gets a benefit from such a contract shall be ousted from office. I fail to see how we could arrive at the reasoning that there was some suggestion in those cases that they were talking only about the freedom of the parliamentarian and not about his benefit.

For all those reasons, we are now in a stupid situation in Australia. We are the most backward of all the Western world countries in the regulation of pecuniary interests. We should have a register of the interests of members, and of their spouses and their dependent children so far as it is within their knowledge. It can be done; it should be done. It is a pity that the Bowen committee did not recommend it because it would overcome a great deal of the problems. The register would disclose matters such as sponsored travel and the question of acting in a professional capacity and being a Minister at the same time. There would also need to be a number of prohibitions, all of which would be dealt with in what would be known as a code of conduct. We have a two-pronged attack-a register of our interests, disclosed annually, and a code of conduct stating that a member shall not accept remuneration from anybody, either in cash or in kind, other than from government sources. We have a duty of trust to the whole Australian nation.

It is a very simple matter which could well have been dealt with in one month from the point of view of the introduction of these sorts of actions in this Parliament.
