There are ample precedents for such action, whether in the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, or anywhere else in the world. All those countries have this sort of concept, and it operates also in Victoria, New South Wales, and other areas. I make the point that we should have such a register, available to the public for inspection and containing updated information on what members are able to disclose about their assets and incomes and those of their spouses and dependent children. Because I would like a guarantee that something will be done, I therefore move:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Deputy Leader of the Opposition from moving: That this House calls upon the Government to introduce into the House before 24 September 1981, a code of conduct governing the conduct of members of parliament and Ministers of the Crown.
I make the point that I will not debate the matter. I simply ask the Parliament to carry the motion in the terms in which I have moved it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—Yes.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hyde Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in opposition to the matter of public importance raised by the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Lionel Bowen). It contains two legs: Firstly, that the Government should adopt a code of conduct for Ministers; and, secondly, that it should adopt a code of conduct for members. The Government has adopted the code of conduct for Ministers recommended by the Bowen Committee of Inquiry Concerning Public Duty and Private Interest. For the life of me, I do not see how the Government can do again what it has already done. I will therefore ignore the first leg of the argument put by the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith as being superfluous and meaningless and concentrate on the second leg, namely, that the Government should adopt a code of conduct for members of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has the matter in hand and, as was stated on 21 May 1980, it will support action by both Houses of Parliament to put the Bowen recommendations into effect. The matter is currently in abeyance because the Minister concerned, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), is overseas attending the International Labour Conference. Since he is handling the matter, it cannot proceed through the Parliament before its rising for the winter recess. However, that is a temporary delay and one recognised by the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith as being necessary, I gather, from the terms of his motion to suspend Standing Orders. In September, or after the House reassembles for the Budget session, I am sure that the matter will come before us. I believe it ought to be attended to very much in the terms outlined by the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith in his matter of public importance; namely, that there be adopted a code of conduct for members of parliament. I believe there should be a code of conduct for members of parliament. I have held that view ever since I first came into contact with the issue back in 1975.

I believe it is reasonable to now consider what can and what cannot be expected to take place as a result of the Bowen recommendations. Private members of parliament do not very often exercise the sort of executive power which brings these sorts of issues into focus. There is just not the opportunity for a private member of parliament to have his judgment swayed or for him to gain an improper pecuniary reward. However, it can occur sometimes, and for that reason I believe we ought to have a code of conduct. We ought to consider some of the matters that will of necessity not be covered in such a code. Much ado is made about the assets and income of a member of parliament. If his judgment is going to be swayed it is far more likely to be swayed because of his debts and other liabilities. There is a much greater risk that a member of parliament, or anyone in society will do something that might be in some way not moral because he is under pressure and not because he can add to what he already has.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you are right; it should include liabilities.

—The honourable member says that liabilities should be included. To achieve the ideal effect, maybe they should. The difficulty occurs in defining liabilities. Some of them are known and some are not. Liabilities tend to come upon one unexpectedly. One cannot account for the unexpected, except by way of a code of conduct so that a member might have some understanding of how he should react if the event occurs. Certainly liabilities cannot be recorded in a register. The type of debts that would be recorded in a register are not the ones that we would be worried about. I go further than that. What about contingent debts-a guarantee given to someone-or contingent assets? What about those things that one might reasonably expect to inherit from an ageing parent? Are they to be included in a register? The Bowen Committee, in my judgment, quite rightly rejected the concept of a register. It did so because it believed it would not help the situation. What is important is that members of parliament make adequate decisions when they are faced with a situation that has in all probability come upon them unexpectedly, hence the value of a code of conduct. It is not that the code of conduct will be valuable for punishing members who have done something that is not of high moral order; rather the code of conduct is there to forewarn them so that they do not do something that they may later regret. For that reason in particular I am all in favour of a code of conduct being adopted. I have no doubt that the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith will see this Parliament adopt a code of conduct. I confidently expect that this will happen in the Budget session.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two sides to this question and two sides to the Bowen Committee's recommendations. Not only do the recommendations provide procedures that will protect the public against members of parliament who may in some circumstances have had their judgment swayed, but also a code of conduct will to some extent protect members of parliament from the regrettable practice of using parliamentary privilege as a licence to slander. Since I have been a member of this Parliament there have been a number of cases-in fact, too many cases-where privilege has been used, in a quite cavalier fashion, to play loose with another man's or lady's reputation. To demonstrate my even-handedness I might say that the first case which offended me concerned Miss Morosi. I believe things were said that ought not to have been said. There have been other occasions since the Government changed hands when Ministers-I think of Messrs Lynch and Sinclair-have had accusations made in this place about them that were unsupported and unsupportable. Because there was the protection of privilege honourable members were able to rise and make all sorts of imputations that would have been the subject of court action had they been made outside of this place.

The Bowen recommendations, if adopted, will provide another vehicle by which a member can raise questions about the integrity of a member of this Parliament. He will not be stopped from doing so; he will be able to raise it on substantive motion. I am sure that the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith will concede that this rarely happens. The matter is normally raised by imputation. If a member presses on with raising a matter by imputation there will still be a lot of difficulty in stopping him from doing so, but at least he will suffer the political odium of not adopting the procedures laid down by the Parliament, these procedures having been recommended by Bowen. He will have an alternative means by which his allegations and fears can be tested. If he does not accept that alternative procedure-that is, raise it with the ethics committee of the House-he will be seen to be the uncharitable individual that he is.

That is merely a political sanction, but nonetheless it is a sanction that I believe will help to ensure that the forms of this House are not abused to treat lightly the characters of its members. To my mind that is as important a function of these recommendations as the function of guiding members in their own conduct. Because I believe in both, I have encouraged the Government and have worked towards the adoption of both. I am fully confident that in the Budget session something very close to the Bowen recommendations will be adopted by this Parliament. Therefore, I think the matter of public importance which has been brought on for discussion does nothing to advance us towards the end that the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith is advocating-an end that both sides share and an end that I believe every member of the House seeks to reach.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: LANDS ACQUISITION (NORTHERN TERRITORY PASTORAL LEASES) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Newman, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill is to set aside any doubt as to the Commonwealth's right to title and possession of the Mudginberri and Munmarlary pastoral leases in the Northern Territory. These properties were acquired by compulsory process under the Lands Acquisition Act 1955 on 23 June 1978. The chief provisions of the Bill are:

(a) Clause 4 is designed to put beyond any legal doubt that the Mudginberri and Munmarlary leases are vested in the Commonwealth and that the Commonwealth is entitled to immediate possession of the lands;
(b) clause 10 preserves the right of the former lessees to claim compensation for interests in the land under the same terms as when land is acquired under the Lands Acquisition Act 1955;
(c) clause 14 is intended to ensure that this Act does not affect the rights of the former lessees to contest the validity of the original acquisition in 1978;
(d) other clauses are of a machinery nature and are generally self-explanatory.

Leasehold interests in the Mudginberri and Munmarlary pastoral leases were, prior to 1978, vested in two companies. In 1977 the Government adopted the recommendation of the Fox Report on the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry that the lands be included in the proposed Kakadu National Park. At that time it was also recognised that the lands could become the subject of Aboriginal land claims. Honourable members will be aware that a claim is, in fact, currently under consideration by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey, in relation to lands in the Alligator Rivers Stage II Region, which incorporates the Mudginberri and Munmarlary leases. The Commonwealth offered in early 1978 to acquire the leases but it was not possible to reach agreement on the amount of compensation. The leases were compulsorily acquired on 23 June 1978. However, the companies holding the leases have contested the validity of that acquisition and further attempts to reach a voluntary settlement have so far failed. So long as these two leases are held, or appear to be held, by the companies, the Government is inhibited in giving effect to policies which relate to future activities in the Alligator Rivers Region.

The former lessees have instituted proceedings in the supreme court in the Northern Territory to challenge the validity of the Commonwealth's acquisition of the leases. The Bill now before honourable members would give the Commonwealth title and right to immediate occupation of the leases, but at the same time ensure that the rights of the former lessees to continue to contest the validity of the original acquisition is in no way affected. The Bill also provides for any compensation to persons who had interests in the acquired land to be paid on just terms. Honourable members will appreciate that the determination of validity of the original acquisition as well as negotiations on compensation could be very protracted issues. It is the view of the Government that these matters should not prejudice or delay the determination of the Aboriginal land claim in the Alligator Rivers Region which is required in order that Government policies relating to establishment of the Kakadu National Park and mineral development can be implemented. The Government has therefore decided that it is appropriate that legislation be passed to ensure the Commonwealth's right to title and immediate possession of the Mudginberri and Munmarlary pastoral leases. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Willis) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr N. A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill 1981 as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these two measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills now before the House are important Bills. The States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill is particularly important. It formally does a couple of things. It brings about a change in the method of allocating funds to the States for general revenue purposes and does the same thing for health purposes. In each case a considerable change is involved, not only in the real level of funding but also in the future form of that funding. So what is being implemented by this legislation has significance, not only for the next financial year, 1981-82, but also for years beyond that. In regard to tax sharing, the main points are: Firstly, the base of the formula by which such grants are determined has been changed from personal income tax receipts to total Commonwealth tax receipts; secondly, a transitional year provision has been introduced, applying to 1981-82 for which year the grant will be determined by increasing the current year grant by 9 per cent; and thirdly, there is a retention of the current means of allocating funds to local government-that is, by allocating to local government 2 per cent of personal income tax revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the health grants, there is an ending of specific purpose payments to the States for the Community Health Program and for the School Dental Program. For New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, and the Northern Territory there is an ending of specific payments for hospital cost sharing. These four States and the Northern Territory are separated from the other two as their hospital cost sharing agreements with the Commonwealth end on 30 June this year, whereas the agreements for South Australia and Tasmania continue until the end of June 1985. The payments for these programs in these four States and the Northern Territory will be made in one health grant which will be a general revenue grant but earmarked for health. South Australia and Tasmania, for which hospital cost sharing agreements will end in 1985, will continue to be funded under their agreements in respect of that hospital cost sharing money. They will be funded from a special health grant for the Community Health Program and School Dental Program. A further factor which stems from this legislation is that the States will be forced to implement some very considerable increases indeed in the charges which they impose in public hospitals, both for in-patient services and for out-patient services.

That is what the Bills do in a formal sense. Practically, however, the legislation gives effect to measures which have created an unprecedented storm of protest from the States, both in respect of the effect that these measures will have on the States and in respect of the method of their implementation. It is no exaggeration to say that by these Bills the Government is asking the Parliament to give legislative approval to the most shameful episode in intergovernmental relations in our history in which the Commonwealth has indulged in deceptive, dictatorial and grossly offensive methods to implement its policy of diminishing the financial viability of the States. The Opposition is disgusted by both the Government's policies as outlined in the main Bill and by the appalling process by which the Government has sought to have them implemented. Accordingly, we completely oppose the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill. We do not oppose the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill as this does no more than retain the present system of determining the allocation of tax funds to local government.

I will be confining my remarks to tax sharing arrangements. The honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), the Opposition spokesman on health, who will be the next Opposition member to follow me in this debate, will deal in more detail with health matters. Before examining more closely what is in the legislation, the circumstances of its determination and the effect it will have, I wish to remind the House of the background to the events which led to the drafting of this legislation now before the House. Tax sharing was brought in by the Fraser Government as a result of so-called new federalism which was proposed by the now Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) when he was in opposition in 1975. The key element was the right of the States to a share of personal income tax receipts of the Federal Government.

I make it clear that, of course, there has always been tax sharing in a sense. This arrangement was formally to allocate general revenue funds to the States as a percentage of personal income tax receipts. This was to replace the formula previously employed by the Labor Government, which make general revenue grants to the States which they could spend on anything. The Labor Government's formula involved movements in average weekly earnings, movements in population and a betterment factor of 3 per cent. Another element of the tax sharing proposal was that a guarantee would be given that for four years the States would receive no less under the tax sharing formula than they would have received under the Labor Government's formula.

Those were the main elements of the so-called new federalism. Of course, great claims were made by the Prime Minister-as the Leader of the Opposition, as he was in 1975, and subsequently as Prime Minister-about the importance of this so-called new federalism. In 1975 the present Prime Minister said:
It is the greatest advance in Federal-State relations since Federation.
That is not a minor claim. In 1976 the Treasurer (Mr Howard) waxed very enthusiastic about new federalism in a speech in this House on 28 April, when he said:

The truth is that the revenue sharing arrangements, the new federalism arrangements, unveiled by the Opposition, as it then was towards the end of last year, are certainly the most dramatic and the most significant development in government relations since Federation.
He was echoing what the Prime Minister had said. He went on:
When implemented these proposals will end for all time the begging bowl of the Premiers Conference.
In the light of recent events, of course, that rings rather hollow. He stated further:
They will end for all time the wrangling that has gone on between Federal and State governments over the years.
Those were the claims made by the Treasurer. I am sure he rather regrets having made them in the light of subsequent events.

The developments in tax sharing after it was implemented were along these lines: Over the first four years the States were forced to rely on the guarantee that they would get no less, by way of general revenue grants, than they would have under the Labor Government's formula. So without that guarantee they would have got less, and this shows what a great reform it was. It was, in fact, the Labor Government's policy that was being implemented rather than the Fraser Government's policy. A further development was that other forms of payment did not increase as fast as general revenue payments. Indeed, some categories fell markedly in real terms. I ask the House to take note of the following figures. Between 1975-76 and 1980-81 in real terms general revenue grants increased by 19.4 per cent, specific purpose recurrent grants increased by 12 1/2 per cent, general purpose capital payments declined by 38.6 per cent, and specific purpose capital payments declined by 54 per cent. So on the capital side there was an enormous fall in real terms in payments to the States. Overall there was a 6 per cent fall in real terms in total payments to the States. In the five full financial years of the Fraser Government the States have received 6 per cent less in real terms than they received in the last year of the Labor Government.

When one adds to that the fact that there has been a 6 per cent rise in the population we see that the payment by the Commonwealth Government to the States in 1980-81 is, in fact, 12 per cent less in real terms per head of population than it was in the last year of the Labor Government. This is a very substantial fall indeed especially as Commonwealth payments to the States account for 70 per cent of total funds available to the States. A 12 per cent fall in 70 per cent of total funds is a very substantial fall indeed.

In 1980-81-the current financial year-the Fraser Government ended the four-year guarantee that the States would get no less in the way of general revenue grants than they would have obtained under the Labor Government's formula and gave a guarantee for that one year, which of course was an election year. This guarantee, which was given in June last year, was to the effect that the States would get no less in real terms in 1980-81 than they had received in the previous year. Of course, this was much less than the Labor formula would have given the States.

For 1981-82 the States were concerned at what was likely to happen. They were concerned because of the substantial overall decline in real funds over the previous five years. It was not clear to them what, if any, guarantee would apply in 1981-82, particularly if the Commonwealth and the Treasurer were talking of the possibility of introducing a broad-based indirect tax and making some offsetting cuts in personal income tax. This greatly concerned the States as their tax sharing formula was based on personal income tax. Any significant decline in personal income tax as a result of the introduction of a broad-based indirect tax would have had obvious implications for the payments to them under the current formula, and they were very concerned about that.

In February this year the States made a combined written submission to the Federal Government seeking various reforms of the tax sharing arrangements. The key elements of that submission by the States were that they were very concerned about the unsatisfactory current situation. It had been satisfactory in the past because of the Labor Government's formula guarantee but that had expired after four years. They were concerned about the base for determination of the States tax sharing grant and said that that should be either personal income tax or total tax depending on what happened to Federal Government tax policy in relation to the broad-based indirect tax. They said that a guarantee should exist which was the same as the Labor Government's formula but with a betterment factor of only 1.8 per cent, which of course had been the betterment factor earlier in the Labor Government's period of office. The States said also that there should be much more consultation between the Federal and State governments in regard to all these matters. As I said, the States made that submission in written form to the Commonwealth in February this year. Clearly, they were very unhappy but were trying to be constructive.

The next development was the Premiers Conference which was held exactly one month ago on 4 May this year. At that time the State Premiers met the Prime Minister and the Treasurer in a Conference which was undoubtedly the greatest setback to the federal system in our history. The Federal Government did various things at that Conference. Firstly, it imposed its proposals on the Premiers, with some minor alterations, in a way which made a mockery of its obligation to consult the Premiers. The Treasurer told the Premiers that the Government had decided to change the base for calculation of tax sharing grants to a total tax-that is, from personal income tax to total tax-and to give only an 8 per cent rise in tax sharing grants in 1981-82. This involved breaking away from the fixed percentage formula of personal income tax of 39.87 per cent of the previous year's revenue as laid down in the States (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act.

Later at that Premiers Conference on 4 May the Commonwealth Government agreed to raise the 8 per cent increase in the grant for 1981-82 to 9 per cent. The States were still very angry that there had been no real consultation especially in regard to the tax base. I will just quote the words of the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, in respect of the discussion that day, he said:

It was characterised by arrogance and domination in the sense that everything was on a take it or leave it basis. And I don't know frankly, of any Premier there who accepted what was offered or what was finally thrust upon them. For my part I rejected the concept of total tax sharing and the percentage which was offered and it's quite laughable for Mr Fraser or for Mr Howard to talk about negotiating.

So there was a lack of real consultation which greatly annoyed the States because of the legal requirement of the Commonwealth to consult, particularly in relation to the base for the establishment of the tax sharing formula. Section 13, sub-section (1) of the States (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act states:

The Government of the Commonwealth shall, before 30 June 1981, consult with the Governments of the States with a view to determining whether any change is desirable in the provisions of this Act and submitting to the Parliament legislation to give effect to any changes that the Government of the Commonwealth considers to be desirable as a result of the consultation.

There is a clear requirement to consult with the States. As I read the dictionary, the word 'consult' means to take counsel or to seek advice. That being the meaning of the word 'consult', it is highly questionable whether the Commonwealth Government, in fact, abided by the Act by properly consulting the States. Even though technically it may have done so by holding the Conference in the first place and simply studying the States' submission, it certainly did not discuss the matter with the States before determining its view as to whether any change in tax sharing provisions was desirable. So much then for co-operative federalism, which was what new federalism was supposed to be all about. The Commonwealth clearly did not consult with the States in any normal meaning of that term before determining its view, and it sought to impose that view on the States.

The second thing that happened at the Premiers Conference was that the Commonwealth deceived the States. The Commonwealth told the States, at first, that in all the economic circumstances, it could not give more than an 8 per cent rise in the general revenue grant for 1981-82. After much protesting from the States it raised that figure to 9 per cent, again saying that it could give no more. Then, in a quite extraordinary episode which I am sure is well in the minds of all honourable members of parliament and most of the public the Prime Minister and the Treasurer deliberately briefed selected journalists to the effect that they would have been prepared to give another one per cent in the general revenue grant to the States for 1981-82, which would have been about another $70m. The States were therefore clearly deceived by the Federal Government, which misrepresented its real position to the States. Clearly the Treasurer and the Prime Minister had Cabinet approval to go to a 10 per cent rise, but they did not do so. I quote from an interview with the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, on AM on 7 May in regard to this matter. He said:

But I do believe that this is most disgusting and despicable. That the Federal Treasurer and Prime Minister have in effect, deceived the Premiers, they informed us that they'd given us all that they could possibly give us. We had a whole day and half a night argument about it and to be told this, to have this admission at this point of time, I think it's just unbelievable almost.

The admission he was talking about was the admission by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer that there was another one per cent to be had. Clearly, Mr Bjelke-Petersen felt as though he had been deceived. I am sure he was speaking on behalf of every Premier. They all felt they had been totally deceived by what the Commonwealth had said to them. It will be argued by the Government that it had a range of increases that it could give under its Cabinet approval and that it is appropriate in the negotiating situation for the Commonwealth to be flexible. That presumes that a Premiers Conference ought to be about negotiating with a view to giving the States as little as possible, which is clearly the way the Commonwealth entered this Conference, rather than in the spirit of co-operative federalism, trying to assess the real needs of the States and to balance those needs against the Commonwealth's own constraints. There is no evidence that the Commonwealth concerned itself at all with the States' needs; it just sought to give them as little as possible. It went in there to give them as little as it possibly could and if it could get away with less than 10 per cent certainly it was happy to do so regardless of the impact on the States. In so doing it told the States things that were not true-that it could not responsibly give more than it finally gave; that is, 9 per cent. That was not its real position at all. The States were undoubtedly deceived and instead of co-operative federalism we now have highly distrustful and resentful federalism.

The third thing that happened at that Premiers Conference was that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer humiliated and grossly offended the Premiers. They did this by leaking to the journalists the one per cent, which I have already mentioned. This humiliated the Premiers because they were made to look like fools who did not get as much out of the Commonwealth as they could have had they been more competent. To compound the felony, after a couple of days of prevarication as to whether or not the Prime Minister and the Treasurer actually leaked this, they finally admitted that they had done so, but they chose to defend that decision in this Parliament rather than apologise for their actions. Thus, in Parliament on 8 May, the Prime Minister said:
It would have been grossly offensive to the Premiers not to go into a conference with a negotiating position.

I have dealt with this nonsense of negotiations being what Premiers Conferences are all about, but the point is that nothing could have been more offensive to the Premiers than what the Prime Minister and the Treasurer did. They publicly humiliated the Premiers and made them look fools. The Prime Minister also said there was nothing wrong with making Cabinet decisions public, as though this was some normal announcement of a Cabinet decision which had to be made public. It was nothing of the kind. It was not a public announcement; it was leaked to journalists. It was not a decision that had to be made public; indeed, it was a decision that, in all the circumstances, should never have been made public. Why did they do it? The Treasurer said that they did it so they would not appear to have been backing down on their own rhetoric about the need to cut government expenditure by giving the States an extra one per cent. This could have been avoided simply by being honest with the States in the first place, by telling the States how much they were really prepared to provide them with. They were not prepared to do that. Instead, they totally misrepresented their position and deceived the States, which therefore led to this appalling situation. I note also that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer apparently made some apology within their own party room. They have made no apology to the Parliament or to the public at large and I believe this debate is a convenient time for the Treasurer and the Prime Minister to make that public apology.

The overall effect of what has been done has been to deal a grievous blow to the federal system in this country by making a complete mockery of new federalism. How hollow-or laughable, now-is the Prime Minister's 1975 claim that it represented the greatest advance in Federal-State relations since Federation. The situation now is that the State Premiers are intensely bitter at what happened and, more important than their wounded pride, is their strong distrust and lack of confidence in this Government. I draw attention in that respect particularly to a statement in a letter by Sir Charles Court to the Prime Minister on 8 May, in which he said:

I must make it clear that if the Commonwealth were to give effect to your proposals, contrary to your earlier assurances and despite the protests of the States, we could no longer feel that we could conclude any agreements with your government with confidence that they would be honoured.

That is a very tough statement indeed. It is very important in this debate, because the proposals about which Sir Charles was talking are the proposals now before this Parliament. The proposals in this legislation are those which Sir Charles said, if implemented by this Government, would cause him to have no confidence or trust in the Fraser Government. We are being asked to vote on that legislation and honourable members on the other side of the House should bear that fact in mind when casting their votes following this debate. The fact is that the Western Australian Government, a Liberal government, now clearly has no confidence or trust in this Government. That is an incredible situation. Sir Charles made another pertinent comment when he said that we had reached the absolute nadir of federation. I think that properly describes the situation that has been reached. Clearly, federalism is a chaos. The Commonwealth is riding completely roughshod over the States. The Commonwealth's behaviour has been arrogant, deceptive, dictatorial and grossly offensive to the States. The States are bitterly resentful at their maltreatment. 'Maltreatment' is a word which has particular poignance in the present situation. Without confidence or trust in the Federal Government our new federalism is completely exposed as a hoax and a fraud.

I turn to the financial impact of the Premiers Conference decisions being imposed on the States. Firstly, there is a substantial cutback for 1981-82 in the real level of general revenue funds to the States. As I have mentioned, there is a 9 per cent rise. That is clearly less than the rate of inflation. The consumer price index rose during the last 12 months by 9.5 per cent. However, a more relevant inflation rate is the implicit deflator of government consumption expenditure because most of this money is spent on recurrent expenditures, consumption expenditures, by the States and the inflation rate, as published by the Commonwealth Government in the National Accounts for government consumption expenditure, is 13.3 per cent over the last 12 months. That is by far the most relevant figure.

TALK.START.PARA: —That includes defence.

—The Treasurer says that includes defence. That is a point he made in a previous debate. It is totally irrelevant. He said there had been a 7 per cent increase in real growth of defence expenditures and that had something to do with this figure. It has nothing whatever to do with it. We are talking about the Government's own calculation of the price index which applies to government expenditures. It has nothing to do with real increases; it is the Government's own calculation of the inflation rate which is properly applied to government consumption expenditures and which is published in the National Accounts. So, on top of the 13.3 per cent increase, which I say is the appropriate figure, there has been a 1 1/2 per cent increase in population, so the States needed 14 1/2 per cent to stay at the same real level per head of population as last year. In fact, the States got 9 per cent, or $375m less than was required. As a percentage of income tax, which is the previous way it was calculated, the 1981-82 grant will fall from 39.87 per cent of personal income tax in the previous year to 38.32 per cent, which is a loss of some $260m. Again, that is what honourable members are being asked to vote for today.

SPEECH.PARA: The second element which comes from the Premiers Conference is that this cutback will continue into future years. It is not just a cutback for 1981-82, but it is built into all future years for as long as the new formula lasts. This is because for 1982-83 we take the 1981-82 grant as a percentage of the previous year's total tax then apply that to the 1981-82 total tax receipts. This percentage, which will be about 20 per cent, will then be applied in future years. Thus, the 1981-82 cutback is reflected in reduced funding for all future years while this legislation remains on the books.

The House should note also that the use of 1981-82 as a transition year was just a device to reduce payments. There is no real need for a transition year. If we want to move from an income tax base to a total tax base we can simply take the 1980-81 grant as a percentage of the previous year's total tax and apply that percentage to the 1980-81 total tax receipts to obtain the grant for 1981-82. But the Government has not done that. It has introduced this transition year as a means of reducing the amount not only for that year but also for all future years.

Thirdly, there has been an abolition of any meaningful guarantee. There is to be no future guarantee along the lines of the Labor Government's formula, nor even any guarantee that the real level of the grant will not decline. The only guarantee is that there will be no fall in the money amount of grants in any year below the level in the previous year. At a time of substantial inflation that, of course, is a totally useless guarantee.

Fourthly, the Government will be able to reduce grants to the States in future below the level given by the formula by declaring an increase in any Commonwealth tax to be a special surcharge and to be excluded from the total tax sharing base. This leaves the States in a totally precarious position because the Treasurer can increase some tax and so say: 'I declare this to be some special surcharge'. As a result it is not included in the total tax base and therefore he does not have to share one cent of it with the States. The States having no guarantee now, apart from the useless one about no reduction in the money amount, are therefore left in a precarious position. From now on the Commonwealth can quite clearly manipulate the system to give the States what it likes. If it so wishes it can force the States to share in any tax reductions and deny them any benefit from any tax increases.

A further point I wish to make relates to the falsity of the Government's arguments for the cutback. The Government has sought to justify its harsh treatment of the States by the measures incorporated in this legislation by stating, as the Treasurer did in his opening address to the Premiers Conference, that there had been a 3 per cent real per capita increase in the States' recurrent expenditure on goods and services between 1975-76 and 1980-81. The Treasurer said that there had been a rapid improvement in the levels of service provided by the States in recent years. It is true that there has been an increase in the real level of recurrent expenditure per head of some 3 per cent by the States over that period. But that is because the States' recurrent funding has been increased mainly because of the application of the Labor Government formula as a guarantee underlying general revenue payments to the States over most of that period. But that is not total spending by States on services. State services are also affected by capital expenditures and, as I mentioned previously, they have fallen disastrously. They have fallen by some 5.7 per cent in real terms per head over that period. This affects services in such important areas as education, public housing, roads, transport, aged persons, accommodation and so on. Many State services are badly affected by cutbacks in capital works or capital expenditures.

Total State expenditure has increased by only one per cent per annum in real terms per capita over 1975-76 to 1980-81. One per cent per annum has been the increase in total State expenditure, and that one per cent is exactly the same as the rate of growth in the Commonwealth Government's expenditures. All attempts by the Government to portray itself as the collector of revenue and the States as the big spenders is absolute nonsense. The fact is that the States' expenditure has increased at the same rate in real terms per head over the last five years as the Commonwealth's expenditure. It is absurd to talk in terms of the States being the big spenders as against the Commonwealth and the need for the States to be cut back to bear their share of the burden. They have borne their share. They have increased their expenditure no faster than has the Commonwealth over this period. There is no doubt that the Premiers Conference was disastrous for Australia in the context of federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Curtin I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech in this House. I ask honourable members to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As is the custom on such occasions, I seek the indulgence of the House to make some brief acknowledgements. I am acutely aware of the stature and achievement of the man who gave his name to my electorate. They speak for themselves, along with the accolades of historians who have recorded them far more eloquently than I could ever hope to. It may be sufficient to say that John Curtin was a respected leader of his party and Government. While Prime Minister he was charged with conducting the affairs of his country in the most dire period of its history. He did so with skill and determination and, towards the end especially with courage. John Curtin was a truly great Australian.

SPEECH.PARA: The first member for Curtin, elected in 1949 is also a great Australian. However, probably because he is still alive his contributions have yet to be fully recorded. Sir Paul Hasluck was a journalist who lamented in his first autobiography called Knocking About the passing of an age where the journalist's primary task was reporting events factually without interpretation. After distinguished public service, he was elected to this Parliament where his abilities and experience were soon put to good use in the Menzies Ministry. His retirement from Parliament was followed by service to his country as Governor-General of Australia where he further distinguished himself in that high office. I understand he is maintaining his writing and scholarly pursuits in retirement and I sincerely hope he will continue to enjoy the fruits of his public service for many years to come.

Sir Paul's successor and my immediate predecessor was the Honourable Vic Garland. His achievements in representing the electorate are fresh in the minds of most honourable members. It was his good fortune to be elected as a young man, to serve with distinction in both opposition and government, to become a respected Minister and eventually to leave this place still a comparatively young man. Whilst his experience and undoubted ability will be missed by honourable members on this side of the House, they will be invaluable in the task ahead of him. I wish him and his wife and family well, both for his term as High Commissioner in London and thereafter.

It remains for me to thank, however inadequately, the members of the Curtin division of the Liberal Party for their expressions of confidence in me, which took many forms both before and since my election. The same may be said generally about Liberals throughout Western Australia and all those with whom I was privileged to associate during my term as a senator for Western Australia. I acknowledge also the support of voters in the by-election of 21 February who accorded me the great privilege of representing them in this Federal Parliament. To you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to your fellow deputies and in particular to Mr Speaker, I extend my thanks for the courtesies and considerations that have already been extended to me. I hope that they continue and that I may earn them. The same may be said for the staff of the House of Representatives.

The following comments are relevant to the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill which is being discussed in this cognate debate. As the economic strength of Australia becomes even more dependent on activity in Western Australia and Queensland, the benefits will be more and more apparent in those areas of Australia where there are heavy concentrations of manufacturing industry. In particular, the States of Victoria and New South Wales will derive economic benefits from increased production of manufactured goods following rising orders generated from expanding resource industries. Because of its unique contribution to the development of the Australian nation, as well as geographical factors and at times a fierce confidence in the individual and collective abilities of Western Australians, my State is well equipped to continue to play a significant role in advancing the interests and well-being of all Australians.

In the context of this debate on the legislation before us, it is important to remind the House of some facts and figures. All States except Queensland have enjoyed benefits superior to those bestowed on Western Australia arising out of Commonwealth Government assistance to industry. Of those, the States with the greatest concentration of population have enjoyed the greatest advantage. Assistance to Victorian industry in 1977-78 amounted to $1,871m, $15m more than was involved in the entire consolidated revenue fund for Western Australia in 1980-81. By comparison, Western Australian industry in 1977-78 was subsidised by $284m. If, as has been argued elsewhere as being equitable for tax sharing purposes, all subsidy of industry had been distributed on a per capita basis, the Western Australian economy would have benefited by a further $133.3m. Victoria would have received $561.2m less.

The figures I have cited and the ones I will proceed to cite are taken from a study based on the material compiled by the Industries Assistance Commission, it being the principal adviser to the Commonwealth on policies affecting industry. It should be noted that the greater part of subsidisation of industry took the form of tariff protection. Estimates of the totals for each State in 1977-78 are: Victoria $1,871m, as I have already mentioned; New South Wales, $1,759m; South Australia, $444m; Queensland, $400m; Western Australia, $284m and Tasmania, $113m. Expressing those figures on a per capita basis: Victoria received $492 per head of population; New South Wales, $353; South Australia, $346; Tasmania, $274; Western Australia, $235, and Queensland, $186. One of the effects of legislation on tariffs and quotas is a deficit in trade between the States and Western Australia of $1,400m.

If the more populous States have benefited to the extent I have just outlined, it is equally evident that the more sparsely populated States have been disadvantaged. The system of economic subsidy has been enduringly to the benefit of the more populous States of Victoria and New South Wales, as I have already mentioned. It has made inevitable the concentration of population and industry in those States. It has given them a stronger base for Commonwealth, State and local government taxes and charges. It has afforded economies of scale in the provision of services, uncomplicated by the need to service a small population scattered over a huge area. It has made it difficult for manufacturers to operate close to small domestic markets, in competition with subsidised industries in those States with big markets in their own back yards.

If ever we must adopt a per capita basis to determine the competing claims of the States for shares of tax revenues-there is some good argument for doing so-account must be taken of other factors such as those just canvassed, if economic justice is to be seen to be done. It cannot be left to the Commonwealth Grants Commission to provide the remedy for the ills of protectionism and its effects on State finances and economies. Clearly, if tax sharing and financial arrangements with the States cannot allow for the insidious, invisible impositions of the tariff, steps should be taken to offset the costs of tariff protection. The obvious answer, and one which I personally advocate, is to cut and phase out the cause of the problem, which is to be found in tariff policy and legislation itself.

It is simply not good business to disregard the past and potential contribution of Western Australia to the wealth creating process. However these remarks may seem to smack of parochialism, real wealth enables the provision of help for those demonstrably in need throughout the country. The State which produced $3,854m of export income in 1979-80, 20.4 per cent of the national total incidentally, cannot be doing too much that is wrong. What is more, its achievements and initiatives do not benefit Western Australians alone. For example, about one half of Australians engaged in work on the North West Shelf gas project are employed in other States. That number is currently 2,000 out of an estimated 4,000.

The purchasing power of a population of 1.5 million people is important to Australian manufacturing industry. The development of vast resources is also important. Resources development itself, often undertaken in remote areas, requires the provision of services and the creation of assets which have come, rightly or wrongly, to be expected of State governments. Services of which I speak involve schooling, domestic power, transport, health care and other basic needs. Assets include roads, ports, industrial power stations, aerodromes and the like. Traditionally, these are financed out of State general revenues, tax sharing entitlements-such as those we are discussing today-Loan Council funds and, latterly, special borrowing rights. All these sources of funds are substantially or entirely directly controlled or influenced by the Commonwealth Government. Given the potential returns to all the people of Australia in the form of employment, company and personal taxation and royalties, it would be short sighted not to invest now in public services and assets essential to expanding exploitation of natural resources. The lesson of the past decade, when our primary industries enabled Australia's economy to weather the international recession, should not be forgotten.

It is in the light of these realities that I address my remarks today. The reduction of all Commonwealth expenditures remains a priority of the Fraser Government, and rightly so. The containment of inflation, management of the money supply, elimination of Budget deficits and reduction of taxation, all depend on the ability of government to tackle its expenditure. It is to be acknowledged, of course, that one of the most difficult tasks is to establish spending priorities within overall economic strategy. If these tax sharing arrangements, in combination with Loan Council deliberations and Grants Commission findings, lead to a situation whereby clearly beneficial developments cannot proceed for want of public services and assets, there should be the flexibility to undertake a review whenever those circumstances become apparent. In that regard, it should be acknowledged that all wisdom does not reside in Canberra. The need for a truly consultative process with the States already exists. One should be developed without delay and I am heartened by announcements as recent as last weekend that indicate that improvement in that process is underway.

It is essential also that the disciplines the States are being asked to exercise are reflected in the coming Federal Budget. Commonwealth expenditure is rarely wealth-creating, whereas some State spending on capital works is. Excluding defence expenditure-I do so if only because there is no comparable item in State Budgets-the limit of 9 per cent on the increase of tax shares to be distributed to the States, should logically be the maximum growth in Commonwealth expenditure in 1981-82. If it is not, our stance may be fairly questioned. We may well be asked: 'Why the difference?' I hope the question will not arise and that we will accept our own medicine in the same dosage determined for the States. In these tax sharing arrangements the Government reaffirms its commitment to budgetary restraint. I think I have already indicated that I wholeheartedly agree with that. It does so against the background of rapid expansion of the relative size of the public sector that first occurred in the mid 1970s, and which expansion has not since been reduced. Reductions in public sector growth must now take place to allow for expansion in the private sector, and I acknowledge the stated intentions of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in that regard. Further inroads by the public sector into the already stretched capital market involve the risk of forgoing tremendous development opportunities which are central to the States' and the nation's economic interests.

Insofar as the legislation meets the desirable objective of budgetary restraint, it is welcome. Future decisions arising out of Loan Council deliberations, and Commonwealth grants commission findings, may well determine whether income earning developments-at present on the drawing board-may proceed. As I have already said, in the area of Commonwealth expenditure, the same disciplines asked of the States should logically be reflected in the August Budget. Until these last mentioned matters are decided and announced, the total public sector scene for 1981-82 remains clouded. However, the course has been set and it behoves us of the Government parties to continue to observe policies that reflect concern for all Australians, while ensuring we retain the economic capacity to meet those needs-not just next year but throughout the 1980s and beyond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) on his maiden speech. To begin with, I thought that it was rather ironic that he should choose for the occasion to speak on a Bill to which the man to whom he owes so much, the Premier of Western Australia, is so implacably opposed. But as the honourable member continued I began to think it was perhaps appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to concentrate primarily on Part III of the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill. These are the clauses relating to the health grant provisions which is the first and integral step in the reactionary health package foreshadowed in the statement of 29 April by the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar). The Bill provides a health grant to the States of New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia to replace the funds under the hospital cost sharing agreement plus the specific purpose grants for community health, women's refuges and school dental programs. These funds will be replaced by a single block grant untied to any of these services.

The Bill provides the method for calculating these grants for these States for 1981-82 and 1982-83 and generally for further years. For 1981-82 the calculation has three components. The first one is a base, the second is an allowance for inflation and the third is a Commonwealth clawback of 60 per cent of posited additional revenues raised by the States in the health sector. I will examine each of these parts. Firstly, there is a base calculated on equivalent funds to those for 1980-81. This seems a fairly inadequate base, given that every State for 1980-81 has a hospital shortfall. In a sense by using that base the hospitals begin behind scratch. For example, New South Wales has a shortfall of about $14m to $15m, Victoria has a shortfall of between $17m and $20m. All the States have a shortfall. Thus there are problems with the base to start with. Secondly, the allowance for inflation is 10 per cent, which seems on mounting evidence to be a rather conservative basis for inflationary expectations in the coming year. Finally, from this base and this allowance for inflation is subtracted a sum which is 60 per cent of the Commonwealth's assessment of the capacity of each State and the Northern Territory to raise additional hospital revenue. The basis for this additional hospital revenue is, first of all, charges of $80 a day for shared ward accommodation, $110 a day for private ward accommodation and $15 a day for, in the words of the Treasurer (Mr Howard), 'an outpatient's occasion of service'. I would like the Treasurer to clarify what those words mean.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those are my advisers' words.
—Those are words the Minister uttered in the House.
—Well, I took my advisers' words.

—I have no doubt that the Treasurer did. I would like to know what the Treasurer, or whoever he got the words from, means by an out-patient occasion of service. Does it mean that a single visit to a hospital out-patient department whatever the number of services would attract a charge of $15? Or does it mean that if on a single visit one has, say, three services delivered a $15 charge will be made for each service? I think it is important to clarify that point. There is no clear evidence provided by the Commonwealth as to the basis of the calculations for the additional revenue raising capacity of the States in the health sector. Certainly they provide figures for increased hospital charges and the return from an anticipated insurance cover and for charges for out-patient and compensable charges. But no evidence has been presented either to this House or to the States as to the basis of those calculations-what kinds of assumptions and expectations underlie the various calculations which relate to the additional hospital revenue that the Commonwealth is claiming the States can raise.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, for the States of Tasmania and South Australia, which were wise enough under Labor governments to sign a 10-year cost sharing agreement with the Commonwealth, hospital funding and a health grant covering community health, women's refuges and the school dental program will at least remain distinct. That is, hospital funding will continue under the cost sharing arrangement and a single health grant will cover community health, women's refuges and the school dental program. At least in those two States there will be a distinction. Of course the Minister for Health made it quite clear that despite the hospital cost sharing agreements hospital funds for Tasmania and South Australia will be squeezed in exactly the same way as funds for other States.

Overall the States and the Northern Territory will receive some $253m less. That figure is correct as long as I am up with all the latest changes. We have had the Queensland change, an adjustment for Victoria and there may be others in the pipeline at the moment. As far as I can calculate, some $253m less will be received by the States than they would have received had the existing arrangements continued. That represents an overall cut in Commonwealth funding of about 16 per cent. Of course, the States are expected to recoup the money by the increased hospital in-patient and out-patient charges and by the application of a rigorous means test to all their public health services.

I think, first of all, it is important to recognise the centrality of this measure to the whole reactionary health package of the fifth Fraser health scheme. While the Government is abdicating all responsibility for public hospitals in this country and is washing its hands of the very real problems in the hospital sector, it aims by these provisions to compel the States to raise charges for in-patient and out-patient services in their public hospitals, to the levels I have already specified, and to impose a strict means test so as to widen the scope of those compelled to meet the charges. Of course-this relates to the whole package-the purpose of these changes is to compel Australians back into flat rate contributions to private health insurance funds.

I say just in passing-I will deal with this matter at much greater length at another stage-the only significant difference between a near-compulsory private health insurance system and an income related health levy is that the flat rate contributions of the private insurance system are inequitable and regressive and advantage the better off as against the less well off. On the other hand, an income related health levy is fairer and more equitable in that it places the heavier burdens on the broader shoulders. For all practical purposes both are taxes, but in terms of equity and fairness and, as well, efficiency and simplicity, the health levy is clearly preferable. But no doubt we will argue that proposition for the next two years. There is no doubt about the purposes of these changes. This is the chief weapon in this Government's armoury to force Australians into the private tax system of health insurance.

How does the Treasurer defend this abdication of Federal responsibility for the hospitals of this country? Given the unfortunate company which the Treasurer keeps, I have frequently admired the fact that, unlike the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), he does participate in debates. Unlike so many of his colleagues, including the Minister for Health, he does respond to the arguments of his opponents, usually in logical and lucid ways. However, I fear that when the Treasurer gets into the health area he takes on some of the characteristics of his colleague, the Minister for Health, that is, double-talk, evasions and vacuous cliches. Look at the major arguments he advanced for the health grant proposals. He stated:

The new health grants arrangements reflect the Government's consideration of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals, discussions with State Health Ministers and the outcome of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. This Bill, in short, reflects detailed consideration of the wide range of views that has been expressed on these matters.

The only possibly perfectly correct statement there is that it may represent the view of the razor gang. I would not put anything beyond that lot. It may reflect their view. It is certainly not the result of discussions with State Health Ministers. I quote from the joint statement of the State Health Ministers on 8 May. They stated:
We observe that we have never been consulted in the real sense of the word and at no time prior to its recent decision has the Commonwealth indicated any clear intention to the States.

There is no evidence of real discussions with State Ministers. The Jamison Commission opposed the proposals embodied in this Bill. It recommended against the proposal to absorb hospital funds into general revenue funds. The Commission was supported by nearly every major health care organisation in this country. Even the Australian Medical Association, before it was bought off with the goodies in the fifth Fraser health scheme, opposed absorption of hospital funds into the general revenue grants to the States. The health care organisations all have very good reasons for opposing absorption.

The Jamison Commission believes, and most of those health organisations believe, there should remain a distinct national provision, a participation by national governments in setting national priorities for hospitals across this country. The Jamison report specifically argued, despite what the Treasurer implies and despite what the Minister for Health has constantly implied, that it was necessary that the Commonwealth retain this contribution to hospital priorities in order to maintain a rough equality of hospital services across this country. Again, to divide the system of health funding from any responsibilities for hospitals is a recipe for inefficiency. If the Federal Government just passes the whole responsibility of public hospitals back to the States but continues to control the national insurance system then that division of responsibility is a recipe for inefficiency. I fear, as do many others, that there would be a decline in the resources allocated to health as a long run result of these proposals because of many other powerful pressures on State Budgets. For all these reasons, the groups that I have talked about, including the Jamison Commission, opposed what is now being done in this Bill.
Let me take a second major argument advanced by the Treasurer. He stated:

The Government sees this change as a move towards ending divided control over the provision of health care services in the States and the Northern Territory and thus eliminating potential costs and inefficiencies that can be involved in such duplication.

That is mostly, I think, gobbledegook. At the very same time that the Government was giving away a role in relation to public hospitals it was increasing its support for private hospitals and it was accepting responsibility for total funding of nursing home benefits. As a result of these shifts and changes a whole host of problems of duplication, overlap, and lack of integration either remain or are made worse. For instance, there will be an increasing problem in relation to the proper provision of nursing home beds. There are two chief sources of new nursing home beds. One is a conversion of surplus acute-patient beds in public hospitals and the other is the provision of new private nursing home beds. Nursing homes remain very much in the Commonwealth sphere; the public hospital sphere has been given back to the States. Indeed, I can see active efforts by the States as they try to evade some of the financial difficulties they are now encountering by converting excess acute beds to beds for nursing home type patients. Instead of that kind of competition what we want in this matter is effective co-operation. These health decisions have made that effective co-operation between States and Federal Government more difficult. Again, every report has talked about the need to rationalise acute bed provision across the whole hospital sector-public and private. This has been rendered more difficult by taking the Commonwealth out of the area of determining priorities in the public hospital field while adding to its funding responsibilities in relation to the private sector.

Then there are the Department of Veterans' Affairs hospitals which are hospitals run by the Commonwealth Government but which are increasingly playing a bigger role in general community health provision. Co-operation between Veterans' Affairs hospitals and State public hospitals will be made more difficult by the Commonwealth's abdication of any responsibility for public hospitals. Again the possibility of building a national policy of support services for the frail aged has been rendered more difficult by giving community health care back to the States but by retaining home care services mainly as a federal responsibility.

These decisions are no answer to most of the problems we have in this field. They create new forms of duplication, new forms of overlap, new forms of competition. This system does not end divided control; it simply complicates it.

Despite the repeated utterances of the Health Minister, now echoed by the Treasurer in the quote from his speech I have previously given, the divided responsibility between the Commonwealth and the States is not the major factor in any inefficiencies in the public hospital sector. There is not very much hard evidence about specific inefficiencies in that sector. The evidence we have suggests that the problems lie in the impact on the costs of hospitals of fee for service procedures, the lack of positive incentives for efficiency, the lack of cost control and utilisation reviews and the inadequacy of budget reviews in hospitals. Certainly there is a need for better budgeting procedures. But none of these issues are tackled by the proposals outlined in the Minister's statement. They have been put into the too-hard basket and shoved back to the States. The Commonwealth Government virtually wipes its hands of all these problems. This is a totally negative contribution to the problems of hospital efficiency.

The only other contribution the Bill provides is the cutback in State funds. Again that is pretty negative. The cutbacks do not relate to efficiency. No effort has been made to penalise the more expensive or less efficient State hospital systems. There has been no effort to base funding on any per capita basis. The per capita health grants to the States range from $68 in Queensland to $168 in the Northern Territory and $118 in Western Australia. I am not saying that we will ever get perfect per capita allocation of grants, or that such would be desirable. But no effort was made in these arrangements to tackle that issue. One and only one criterion was behind the calculation and that was, the more developed the public sector in the public hospital the greater the cutback. Thus, the three States which received the largest cuts in their allocations-Queensland, Tasmania and the Northern Territory-were the three that had most fully developed the public sectors in their public hospitals. All three had 80 per cent or over of hospital or public patients in their public hospitals. Such a cutback plus the increased charges and means tests may reduce the health burden to the Commonwealth Government but it would not reduce the health burden to the community as a whole and it would be counter-productive in terms of efficiency. The last comment on this illogic is the kind of Bjelke-Petersen provident fund giving Queensland a $16m a cushion-to use the Treasurer's words. It is quite ironical that this money has been provided to Queensland to help it defeat the very objective which lies behind this set of health grant proposals. Finally, I quote again from the Treasurer-another major part of his argument, I suppose. He said that it was intended:

. . . to restrain the growth of public sector expenditure so as to make room for productive growth in the private sector without giving rise to inflationary pressures that could only damage the economic prospects for Australia.

In the short run that is quite untrue, at least in relation to the cost to the Commonwealth Government of the total health package. I refer to the whole health package because the Treasurer tells us that 'these proposals must be considered in the context of the overall revision of health care arrangements'. In 1981-82 expenditure in the Commonwealth health sector will be greater by about $400m as a result of the total impact of these changes on the Commonwealth public sector. That is because the $600m rebate and the $120m assumption of nursing home benefit by the Commonwealth funding far outweigh the gains on the hospital front. There are a few minor balancing items but the above three items are the major factors.

In the long run, although the expenditure figures will be hidden by absorption in general revenue grants to the States, the total effect of this package of health care changes will lead to an escalation in health care expenditure in the public sector; that is, taking the Commonwealth and States together. I think there is nothing in this package to prevent the whole community's total health expenditure passing $10,000m in 1982-83. In essence the source of the problem is that the underwriting of private fee for service medicine and the private hospital system by a massive expansion of the private health insurance system is a recipe which will lead to an acceleration of health costs. It will certainly give rise to inflationary pressures, despite what the Treasurer has said. Health insurance contributions must rise this year as a result of increased bed charges for inpatients in public hospitals, as a result of increased payments for expensive medical procedures formerly performed in public hospitals by salaried staff, as a result of the rise in benefit refunds from 75 per cent to 85 per cent of the scheduled fee, as a result of a $25m reduction in the Commonwealth's subsidy to the reinsurance pool, and as a result of the rise in medical fees expected at the end of the year. All of those will push up the contribution rates for health insurance. There will be an offsetting factor in the assumption by the Commonwealth Government of all nursing home benefits. However, the General Manager of the Hospital Benefits Association has already suggested a possible rise of 47 per cent in the combined medical and hospital basic contribution rate. His expectations are that the rise will be around 47 per cent. The impact on the consumer price index of an increase of this order, or even one of a somewhat lesser magnitude, would be around one per cent. Clearly, we cannot accept the Treasurer's anticipation that these proposals will not give rise to inflationary pressures.

Finally, let me simply congratulate the Treasurer that in all his arguments he never advanced the cliche that somehow these proposals will improve health care in this country. At least he had the honesty never to mention that any of these proposals was likely to improve the health care delivered to ordinary Australians in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill now before the House, particularly as it relates to the implications for my electorate, the Northern Territory. As a member of the majority party in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly which began the negotiation of the financial agreement between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory governments in 1977, I have a personal interest in and knowledge of the events leading up to the special provisions now incorporated in this financial Bill, specifically in respect of the Northern Territory. Initially, 24 local and State government type functions were transferred from the Commonwealth to the Northern Territory on 1 January 1977. The next important step was the 1977 Brisbane meeting between the Commonwealth and Territory Ministers. As I remember it, the Commonwealth party comprised Ministers Adermann, Carrick, Ellicott, Robinson and Viner. The Territory was represented by the then majority leader, Dr Goff Letts, and myself as the Deputy Leader with responsibilities for finance.

SPEECH.PARA: At that initial meeting it was established that one of the fundamental views and principles so far as the Commonwealth was concerned was that the special circumstances and the particular difficulties of the Northern Territory would be fully recognised and provided for in the funding arrangements and in establishing a sound financial basis for self-government in the Northern Territory. After many months of detailed negotiations and ministerial meetings, a Memorandum of Understanding became the formal document which was signed by Prime Minister Fraser and Northern Territory Chief Minister Everingham in June 1978. The agreement came into effect on Self-Government Day, 1 July 1978, and, inter alia, established a fiscus in the Northern Territory. Honourable members will recognise the importance of the agreement. It was fundamental to the Territory Government's agreeing to accept the Commonwealth's offer to move to self-government. At the time of the early negotiations in 1977 many Territorians were understandably apprehensive about the likely cost to them in runnink a self-governing territory, given its small revenue base and the prospect that at any time the Commonwealth may withdraw its financial support or fail to adhere to its agreement. Thus, the Memorandum of Understanding and the prospects of a sound financial future which we believe were set down in the Memorandum were critical to the whole success of the Northern Territory move into self-government.

Some of the key provisions in this important document, the Memorandum of Understanding, so far as it concerns this Bill, are set out in fine detail in paragraphs 1, 7, 8, 15, 19, 22 and 23. Honourable members will note in those details that particular reference is made to a formula for the calculation of the Territory's general revenue assistance grant. This formula sets out the Northern Territory's entitlement each year as the percentage increase in personal income tax collections multiplied by the percentage increase in the Northern Territory population. Under the new State tax reimbursement arrangements the words 'total tax collections' now apply in lieu of the previous reference to 'personal income tax collections'. I understand that the Territory has agreed to amend the corresponding reference in the Memorandum of Understanding so that 'total tax collections' is now to be read in place of 'net personal income tax collections'.

This amendment would leave unchanged the reference in the formula and in the other parts of the Memorandum to the population of the Northern Territory as an additional factor in the entitlement calculations. It will be noted that the reasons for this population factor in the funding arrangements which led to self-government were, I believe, in recognition of the tremendous backlog in the provision of adequate services in the Territory and the near impossibility facing the Territory Government in providing a reasonable standard of services to a rapidly growing population in the absence of the depth of infrastructure support that exists in the now-established States of our Commonwealth. In particular, given the very low revenue capacity of the Northern Territory and the very high percentage of its inhabitants who have little capacity to contribute towards State-type taxes, there was little prospect for the Territory being able within the foreseeable future to cope with a growing population and the realities of neglect by successive Federal governments. For that reason, the population factor under the Memorandum of Understanding was a fundamental provision which formed the basis for self-government of the Territory.

The proposal now before the House recognises and maintains this principle and ensures the integrity of the arrangements.
