TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the Australian Labor Party has suddenly discovered the tenants of the Belconnen Mall. It is a pity it did not discover them about six months ago. At that time those people went to the newly elected member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) and asked her to help them to get justice against their landlord, the Commonwealth Government. They told her the reasons why they wanted ownership of the Mall. One reason was that they were being killed by the rents which they had to pay. If they increased their turnover their rent went up. There was no possibility of their giving their customers, the people of Canberra, a fair deal. They went to her and asked her whether she thought the Government would sell it to them. She told them that it was not a good idea but that it would be a great idea if the Woden Plaza were sold because those nasty free enterprise individuals owned the Woden Plaza.

SPEECH.PARA: Those people had a bit of faith. They had just elected a golden girl. Some of the people who approached her happened to run small businesses, but they were not to be considered. Do not say that this did not happen because it did. We know that it happened in her office. The Labor Party has now decided that it can give a bit of thought to the tenants of the Belconnen Mall. The tenants of that Mall want the Government to sell them that building. My understanding is that they will get it. When the Labor Party gets around to repossessing it, as is its style, I will bet it can get it off those people. I will listen to anybody who can say in this place that that building will be sold to anybody but those tenants. I talked to the tenants and showed an interest in them. I come from the other side of Australia, but somebody had to look after them. The people they have elected to this place prefer the situation as it exists at the moment. If they had their way they would repossess all the houses and rent them back to their occupants. Let us get something straight. The elected representatives from the Australian Capital Territory on the Opposition benches do not talk on behalf of the poor residents of Canberra. At the first opportunity they had to do something for them and give them a bit of identity they did nothing. It is small businesssmen who create local government. I know what makes local government as I was in it for 16 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to support us on the deregulation of shopping hours?

—No. I am not. I do not think it is necessary. I was a small shopkeeper, too. I know all about regulation. I know all about nasty little men who come around and tell me what I will do about selling a can of beans to somebody who is hungry. I have seen that sort of regulation. I have been part of it. I never wanted it when I was in that sort of business. I do not think many people want it now. I do not think the buying public want it either. There is plenty of room for small business people in Canberra. When there is a heap of them they will ask for local government. They will be the people who will make a contribution to local government. The honourable member for Canberra should not laugh. She has never been in local government and would not know how it worked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Instead of speaking in an emotional fashion, as did the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), I will outline my reasons for opposing these clauses. There is the obvious one. The honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) has outlined the reasons for our opposition to the takeover of the Belconnen Mall and the Canberra Retail Markets. The point I raise is that honourable members who have come here from all over Australia have a right to sit here in this Parliament and make decisions that affect the Australian Capital Territory. I know the legislation as it stands today gives them that right. I believe members of this Parliament should, in fact, be spending their time debating national issues. They should not be spending their time discussing issues that are involved in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at specific issues. For example, let us look at Division 13 which relates to rabbit destruction. Do honourable members know what we are debating here tonight? We are debating a Bill which will, in fact, abolish the position of Receiver of Scalps in the Australian Capital Territory. That is what we are debating in this Parliament tonight. Have honourable members been elected to debate whether the Australian Capital Territory should have a Receiver of Scalps, or a lake superintendent, or an approver of licences or a receiver of money for sewerage and rates? That is what honourable members are debating tonight. I believe the Federal Parliament should not spend its time debating issues that have a specific reference to the Australian Capital Territory.

We are debating these issues tonight because the Government knows that it cannot amend the Ordinance by the normal processes because it does not have the time. It will lose control of the Senate and, as a result, it has to race this Bill through Parliament. The Government cannot go through the procedure of consulting the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly or of consulting the community in order to amend the Ordinance. It cannot let it lie in both houses of Parliament for 15 days because it knows that it would be defeated on this issue and that disallowance would be agreed to by the Senate. Therefore, it is not prepared to let the democratic processes take their course. Instead, we have this ludicrous situation tonight when, at the same time as we are debating the razor gang cuts and income tax legislation, we are debating whether the Australian Capital Territory should have a Receiver of Scalps. How ludicrous can the Parliament be when we have that situation?

This highlights another point that I want to make tonight. The abolition of the positions of lake superintendent and receiver of moneys for rates and sewerage shows just how ludicrous the recommendations of the Lynch committee are. It is the titles of these positions that are being abolished, not the functions. The positions are being abolished so that it will look better on paper, but the functions are not being abolished. Is not that a ludicrous situation? How petty it is to be spending this amount of time not only debating an issue that should be related specifically to the Australian Capital Territory and, therefore, amended by ordinance but also debating an issue which will have very little practical effect. This illustrates that the Government is using the Australian Capital Territory to demonstrate its philosophy. This is the only area in Australia where it can put its philosophies into action, and it sure is doing it here. It is not prepared to listen to the advice of any of the residents of the Australian Capital Territory, or the advice of the elected representatives of the House of Assembly because the Government knows it would be opposed and defeated.

There has been some discussion from my colleagues in the Opposition about shopping hours. This again illustrates many of the points that I have been making. The Lynch razor gang recommendations were made without consulting the community. There is outright opposition to the deregulation of shopping hours by the Australian Association of Independent Businesses, outright opposition from the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association and no strong demand by the consumers. I know because for five years I was a member of the Legislative Assembly in this Territory. During that time several investigations were conducted into the issue of deregulation of shopping hours. On all those occasions deregulation was decided against. Yet the Lynch committee in its wisdom-I do not know from where it received that wisdom-decided in a few words to deregulate shopping hours without any consideration for the effect that that would have on the economy of Canberra and on the small businesses in Canberra. So what we are seeing is government decisions being made in relation to the Australian Capital Territory, not because they will save money or because they will rationalise functions, but because the Government can demonstrate its great commitment in transferring everything to the private sector regardless of whether the private sector wants it and regardless of whether it will be beneficial to the private sector in Canberra.

The other points which have been made in relation to deregulation illustrate exactly the point I am trying to make. This Government has decided also to deregulate, along with shopping hours, architects, agents and surveyors. Who wanted this deregulation? I do not understand from where the Government got that advice. As far as I can work it out the surveyors have already formally notified the Minister for the Australian Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) that that was not what they wanted. Because the Federal Government has control of the Australian Capital Territory it suddenly decides to wipe out regulation in these areas not because the people of Canberra want it, not because the interest groups want it, but because the Federal Government in its wisdom decides that it wants it. At the same time it is not prepared to discuss the matter with the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly or the community. It wants to race through this change in an Act of Parliament.

So what we see tonight is the government of Canberra being run by honourable members from Western Australia, Tasmania, South Australia and New South Wales but not by the people of Canberra. The people of Canbera have not had the opportunity to voice their objection to this move. We have not gone through the normal channels of communication with the people. We have not opted for the ordinances and all the procedures that that entails. Instead, these matters which specifically affect the Australian Capital Territory are now put in a Bill which will become an Act of Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I can dispose of the question asked by the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly). She asked why the Parliament is debating these issues when they relate to the Australian Capital Territory. There are two major reasons for that. Firstly, there was a referendum, and the result of that referendum clearly indicated that the people of the Australian Capital Territory wanted this Parliament and the people we represent in this Parliament to remain responsible for the overall conduct of the Australian Capital Territory. Secondly-this is the obvious historical point-the Australian Capital Territory happens to be the national capital. It was established initially as the seat of government of this country. Therefore, all of the people we represent, including the people who happen to live on the north-west coast of Tasmania, have an interest in the Australian Capital Territory. I hope that they will continue to have an interest in the Australian Capital Territory. The reason the people who live in the Australian Capital Territory want the whole of Australia to remain responsible is so that those people who live in places such as the electorate which I represent will pay taxes to help support the Australian Capital Territory. The people who live in Canberra cannot have it both ways. They cannot receive the benefits that come from this Parliament being responsible for Canberra and have the total independence that some people, such as the honourable member for Canberra, want to have.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to speak generally to this piece of legislation. I relate my comments to the title and the purpose of the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill. This Bill seeks to implement certain changes in Commonwealth functions. I indicate briefly that I support the spirit and the purpose of this important legislation. That is not to say that I agree with everything that is proposed in this Bill. Obviously there would be some parts of the Bill with which I might disagree. I might have done things in a slightly different way had I been responsible for preparing the legislation and making these decisions. Overall, I believe it is a sensible package and that is why I support it.

It represents a genuine attempt by the Government to reduce the size of federal bureaucracy. I believe the majority of people in Australia realise at this point in our history that government is too big, that bureaucracy is too big-especially the bureaucracy attached to the Federal Government and to this Parliament-and that it is costly. As a result people are paying too much tax, and that is taking away incentive. So we have this general feeling that people in the community want to get the size of government down and that they want to get their taxes down. They want to pay less tax and have a little more in their pockets. Individuals can usually spend money more wisely than governments can spend it.

Of course, this Bill involves a very fundamental difference between the people who sit on this side of this Parliament and those who sit on the other side. If we look at the history of the Liberal Party, in 1944 Robert Menzies, as he then was, was concerned-as was the community-about the threat of centralised government in Canberra. The then Labor Government proposed a referendum to give the government in Canberra a whole range of additional powers. The Liberal Party wants to distribute the power of government around Australia fairly among the Commonwealth and the States. That is a fundamental purpose of the Liberal Party. On the other hand, the Labor Party believes in a very strong central government in Canberra. It wants to reduce the power and the influence of the State governments. Therefore, I can understand why people on the opposite side of the House tend to get upset when we are debating this kind of issue.

The Bill results from the examination of Commonwealth functions undertaken by a committee of the Cabinet under the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch), which is sometimes known as the razor gang. I believe that exercise had two major purposes: Firstly, to transfer functions from the government sector to the private sector and, secondly, to transfer functions from the Commonwealth to the States. If I have time to do so, I will comment briefly on the second purpose of that exercise. I want to dismiss one point that was made by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) earlier when he said that this legislation showed concern only for those people who have money. He said that there was a need to protect the less fortunate people in the community with a larger public sector.

I want to make it clear that I do not support the notion that we should reduce the size of every one of our programs and cut cloth for the sake of cutting cloth. We must maintain the important programs we have as a Commonwealth Government, especially those programs that assist the people in genuine need in the community. Of course, we recognise that there are people in genuine need who must be supported by the overall population, and that is why we have the programs we do. We recognise that people such as the handicapped, especially in the International Year of Disabled Persons-I refer to orphans, Aboriginal communities and the aged-must be protected.
Honourable members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask honourable members opposite to wait for just a moment. If we can do away with the wasteful areas of Government expenditure and the useless programs we will have more money available for those people in genuine need. One of the reasons I support the measures contained in this Bill is that they will give the Commonwealth Government a greater capacity to help those people in the community in genuine need. I believe we will see as an end result greater assistance provided for those sections of the community that need help from the government.

SPEECH.PARA: Also, as a result of these decisions we will find that the Government will have a greater capacity to reduce the tax burden borne by taxpayers around Australia. This legislation gives the Government the chance to do both of those things. I certainly hope that the Government very soon will consider family allowances or increasing the rebate for dependent wives. Also I hope it will consider reducing the size of the income tax bill paid by the taxpayers of Australia. I ask the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman)-who is at the table and who I know has great understanding of these matters-the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and his colleagues to look very carefully at the issues of family allowances and personal income tax. I believe there will be, as a result of this legislation, an opportunity to do something positive in those fields. I hope that we do not wait for two or three years to do those things; I hope we do them very soon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member that he is straying from the content of clauses 1 to 89. I invite him to get back to them.

—As I said, Mr Chairman, I was directing my comments to the title and purpose of the Bill, which is contained in clause 1. It is concerned with functions. I believe it is very relevant to consider the end result of the legislation. It gives me an opportunity to talk generally. At the moment Commonwealth-State relations are a problem in this country. I believe it is important for the Commonwealth to get out of those areas in which it should not be involved and to let the States conduct the business that they should conduct under our constitutional system of government. Since Federation in 1901 the size of the Commonwealth Government has continued to grow. We are now seeing, probably for the first time, a change in direction which gives us the chance to reduce the size of the Commonwealth Government. It is important that we get out of the areas of government we are involved in but should not be involved in. Our involvement interferes with the proper functions of the States and creates friction between the Commonwealth and the States. That is very debilitating for government in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in supporting these clauses which relate to the Australian Postal Commission. They give effect to a very important part of the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions which was presented to this chamber recently. These clauses abolish the Australia Post Courier Service. The abolition of the Australia Post Courier Service is an important reaffirmation of the basic philosophy of the Liberal Party. It is based on the precept that the people ought to be free to choose how they live, work, vote and spend their disposable income. Obviously, a result of this belief is the fact that the Liberal Party must be consistent in supporting and aiding as much as possible an economy where freedom of choice is the norm. That receives application in these clauses.

SPEECH.PARA: The reductions in and rationalisation of Government spending given effect by this legislation positively demonstrate that small, less interventionist government is the foundation stone of the Liberal-National Country parties. The Federal Government will continue to implement policies that acknowledge that philosophy. I welcome the assurance that the Committee under the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Philip Lynch) will continue its review of Commonwealth functions. I hope that the current initiatives are just the beginning. Much more remains to be done to achieve a more market oriented economy and a freer society in Australia. It is important that the philosophical basis of these decisions should be fully understood not only by Liberals but also by those in the community whom the Liberals represent and on whose behalf the elected government bases its decisions and policies.

Suffice to say that a single thread must run through any successful government-a pre-eminent idea or concept which unites, but does not totally bind, that party and unites it with the people it has been elected to govern. For the Liberal Party that thread, of course, is its philosophy of liberalism. That is the concept which unites the party. But the party is not irrevocably bound by a doctrine which forces it to make decisions which are not in accord with the welfare of the people it is governing. It is a basic thread and a basic philosophy upon which all the decisions of the Government are based. It is on that basis that this particular decision to abolish the Australia Post Courier Service is based.

It is not appropriate that a government should fulfil all the demands and wants of a community. People should have those demands fulfilled in the market-place, either by combining voluntarily as a group or working on an individual basis. Over and above that it is the role of government to fulfil those needs which people are unable to fulfil for themselves. The Australia Post Courier Service does not come within the ambit of that proposition. Therefore, I support these clauses which will abolish the Service's activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is opposed to Part IV of the Bill comprising clauses 114 to 121. Part IV relates to the Government's decision with respect to the change of status of the Australian Wool Testing Authority and the necessary changes to the Wool Industry Act. The Opposition is opposed to that part of the omnibus Bill because it has become clear that the Government has backtracked so much on its original proposition that there is no need to continue with the cosmetic farce that it is now engaged in. It has adopted more changes of position in this matter than appear in the Kamasutra. This Part of the Bill is nothing more than a contrivance to save face. The only upshot of the move will be an increase in wool test charges to the industry as the Hill Samuel independent report has clearly said. The Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation has said so, as has every objective independent observer.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government believed all along that the wool industry was getting something on the cheap and that it was this and only this that offended its ideology it should have said so honestly to the industry, instead of engaging in the farce it has and inflicting confusion on the industry. The best thing the Government could do, if this Bill is passed, would be not to proclaim it. When I last spoke on this matter in the House on 14 May I said that it was abundantly clear that the Government had bungled and that it did not understand the role and functions of the AWTA because that body was an independent, official, impartial and highly efficient body and that its sale to the private sector was not only wrong but also dangerous to the wool industry. I pointed out the way in which the AWTA had saved the industry money, how low its costs were and that all that the Government could or would do would be to raise costs and throw the wool industry into chaos.

It has since been reported to me by a wool broker of impeccable reputation that since I made the speech the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) instituted a witch hunt in his Department to find out who I had been talking to. In case some poor person is going to be erroneously subjected to the wrath of the Minister and victimised I wish to state before the House that before that speech I spoke to no one in the Department of Primary Industry, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, any wool broker, any one from the Australian Wool Corporation or any person in the commercial wool trade. I spoke with two people in the AWTA after a statement had been issued on their behalf, and I was told exactly what any member of the public would be told. I insisted that that was all I was to be told. Of course, it is ridiculous for the Minister to institute a witch hunt.

In 1971-72 I worked in the Bureau of Agricultural Economics in the wool marketing section when it was principally engaged in the Australian objective measurement project. I know what has happened in the Australian wool industry since 1971. Of course, there was no need for me to have known anything about the wool industry at all. All I would have had to do would be to read the cascade of material opposing the Government's move, which material has come from absolutely every organisation within the wool industry.

Even the wool broker mates of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) who put him up to the crazy idea to sell AWTA were not supported by the National Council of Wool Selling Brokers. There is no need for me to ring David Asimus or Ian McLachlan or any wool industry leader. Their attitude is on the public record. The latest example is a telegram to all New South Wales and Australian Capital Territory senators from the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales, which reads:

The Livestock and Grain Producers Association of NSW totally oppose the Federal Government's proposal that the Australian Wool Testing Authority (AWTA) be divorced from its relationship with the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC).
The Governments justification for the 'razor gang' cuts appear to be based on the premise that the user must pay. In the case of AWTA this premise is not valid as the user does pay.

In fact, the Government does not provide one cent in direct cash handouts to AWTA. At the same time, AWTA has been able to make profits over the last five years of about $1million per annum and hold its charges at about the 1970 level.
The reason for disposing of AWTA had to change and Mr Nixon has said that 'there is no longer a requirement for the Authority to have a link with the Government'.

This 'link' provides the very basis of the wool industry's marketing system. All sectors of the industry have very strongly opposed the Government's present proposal. These objections are best summarised by the International Wool Textile Organisation:
'Members of IWTO are strongly of the view that in its unique function between sellers and buyers, AWTA must be, and be seen to be, an official, independent and impartial body.'

Mr Nixon has further stated 'that the fundamental aim is to ensure that AWTA continues in precisely the same way as it does already.' 'We will establish a foundation' says Mr Nixon 'which will be designed by the industry itself.'
One thinks that the industry has already designed its own 'foundation' and that it already exists-namely, AWTA.

No real argument has been put up by the Government as to why it is necessary to dispose of AWTA. This is particularly disturbing when there is the slightest possibility of doing damage to Australia's wool marketing system.

As woolgrowers, we are extremely concerned with the Government's proposal to dispose of AWTA: This concern has been conveyed to the Prime Minister by a large number of our members, apparently to no avail.
The only course of action left is to seek your support to have the 'razor gang' legislation either amended-to remove references to AWTA, or defeated.'

The word 'link' is of prime importance because it is now quite clear the link between AWTA and the AWC and the Government will not be severed. If anything, the AWC will be closer to the AWTA. We still do not know what status or structure the new organisation will have, but it is quite apparent from all the confusing answers to questions in this House that the Government does not intend carrying out its original announced purpose. We are not even sure who is being consulted in the industry other than the AWC. I will read once again the Prime Minister's bald announcement of 30 April 1981 in the Review of Commonwealth Functions under the heading 'Transfer of Functions to Private Sector'. He stated:
We propose to offer for sale as a going concern . . . the Wool Testing Laboratory-

There is nothing ambiguous in that. It is a clear statement leaving no room for misinterpretation. We now have before us a Bill which is very short on detail and does not definitely state that the AWTA is to be sold to Mr Fraser's holier than holy private sector. Just about everything is subject to the consent of the Minister. Even the sale of the wool stores is subject to the consent of the Minister. In other words, in an exercise which is entirely about saving face the Minister is going to go behind closed doors with the AWC and others, first to be educated by the wool industry about the stupidity of the Government's action and then to reach a compromise which is not too ridiculous, which does not cost the industry too much and which does not destroy the effectiveness of the AWTA too much. All that will be done is that the Wool Testing Authority will be given a new name with a new board which may or may not have voting rights. We have not been told. There is little ever to vote on. The Government has discovered that there is a part of the Department of Primary Industry which can pass judgment on the standards. It has always been there. I better tell the Minister that it is called the Australian Wool Measurement Standards Authority. I guess the CSIRO representative will be taken off. We have not been told. Perhaps I should inform the Minister the reasons for CSIRO being on the Wool Testing Authority. It is there because of its active professional involvement in wool technology, technological innovation and measurement standards.

This Bill creates a legal device whereby the Australian Wool Corporation, which is a statutory corporation, may first set up a body corporate, which can be a statutory corporation, to acquire the testing facilities operated by the AWTA, which is a statutory authority but which is at present legally owned by the AWC. There are provisions in the Bill which permit this company to be sold to a second company which will in future undertake the operations which are at present performed by the AWTA. Apart from referring to the abundant ridiculousness of this there are two things to ask: Firstly, if the AWC clearly owns the AWTA why is there a need to set up a legal intermediate body to buy the assets of AWTA? Secondly, why is the intermediate body corporate suddenly called a company and the possible final owner also to be called a company? It is just ridiculous. If it is to be called a company and to meet some of the descriptions given by the Minister and Acting Minister it will have to be a company limited by guarantee. So far we have heard of a private company, then a foundation, then a statutory corporation and now the body is to be perhaps a company limited by guarantee.

If the AWTA is to be taken over by such a company it may not have to pay tax. But who will own the company and where will the proceeds go? The Wool Corporation will sell the assets to, say, a company or a body corporate which will last for an instant if the second company comes along. The Wool Corporation will get the proceeds. But then someone has to pay for the second company-if it comes along. If the Wool Corporation is to have a share-the Minister virtually said that it will-it then has to buy the thing it has just sold. If other people are expected to be co-buyers-let us say the wool council, wool brokers or fellmongers-where will they get the money from and why would they put the money in if they will not get a return on their money? We do not even know whether they are being consulted. The whole thing is ridiculous. The Government cannot have it both ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the views of the honourble member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin). I am pleased that he is supporting my views. I was proposing to oppose the clauses mentioned. I circulated my notice of this much earlier in the day than did the honourable member. I oppose this part of the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill for several reasons. It has been put to me on several occasions that the 350 decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions are one parcel. I do not agree with that. I do not agree that if one buys 350 eggs and one of them is bad one has to consume the whole 350 eggs. This is one bad decision amongst those 350 decisions. Let me emphasise in speaking against this decision that I support the rest of the package. But I maintain that this is a bad decision in that package of 350 decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: I disagree with Part IV on several basic grounds. It has always been a policy of the coalition parties as far as I am concerned that in dealings with industry, particularly primary industry, there is consultation before decision. There was not adequate consultation before decision or before the announcement of the decision to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority or the Australian wool stores. We have always maintained this policy. Generally, within the platform of the Liberal Party, there is a provision that we have to meet two basic criteria when looking at rural marketing and statutory and orderly marketing organisations. Firstly, we should look to see that the interests of consumers and producers are protected and, secondly, we have to see that we have full consultation and co-operation with the industry involved. In both ways this decision abrogates those basic criteria that are written into our platform. I understand that the platform of our partners in the coalition has similar provisions with regard to the consultation, discussion and agreement with industry before a decision is made. I think we have only to look at some of the provisions of this legislation to realise the way in which consultation was effected. At least three times in the clauses that we are now opposing it is stated 'and shall, if so directed by the Minister'. That is far from consultation in any way with the industry.

I can assure honourable members that there was no consultation-I have checked on this very closely-with the Australian Wool Council, which has followed on from the Australian Wool Industry Conference. There was very little, if any, discussion with the Australian Wool Corporation. There may have been some perfunctory discussion with the chairman of that Corporation but certainly not with the Corporation itself. Any discussion that has taken place with these two bodies has been in the light of the decision-not by way of reaching the decision. For that reason I cannot condone the way in which this procedure has been conducted.

An amendment has changed the way in which the decision has been promulgated. Firstly we had a decision to sell to private enterprise; now it is to be transferred in some way or another to some foundation or the like. The matter is still very unclear indeed. There is very great opposition from a number of sectors in the industry. In a previous speech I referred to opposition from the International Wool Textile Organisation. I pointed to objections from the Government in India. I pointed to the objection from the Australian Wool Testing Authority. That Authority represents all sections of the industry at the moment. Those bodies genuinely agreed that the move was not desirable or necessary. I refer to a recent Press release issued by the Australian Wool Corporation on 22 May. I quote one section of the statement. It reads:
'At this stage of the examination I can say that all alternatives would result in an increase in costs to the industry with no discernable benefit to it,' . . .
That statement was made by the Chairman of the Corporation, Mr David Asimus. I seek leave of the Committee to incorporate in Hansard the Press release of 22 May of the Australian Wool Corporation.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Press statement
Wool Corporation opposes decision to sell AWTA.

At its first meeting since the announcement of the Government's decision to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority, the Australian Wool Corporation today declared its opposition to the Government proposal.

The Chairman of the Corporation, Mr David Asimus, said after the meeting that, as a result of the Government decision, Corporation management and consultants had been working since early this month on alternatives concerning the sale of AWTA and establishment of a successor.
'At this stage of the examination I can say that all alternatives would result in an increase in costs to the industry with no discernible benefit to it,' Mr Asimus said.
'Even a structure similar to that of the existing AWTA, with similar industry representation, could well involve significant additional cost.

'For a new organisation to fund such extra costs as well as instalments of asset transfer payments to the corporation, wool testing charges would have to be increased annually to a much greater extent than would otherwise be the case.'
Mr Asimus said that as soon as the corporation studies were sufficiently detailed they would be discussed with the wool industry and the Government.

Request you to correct serious Government error by razor gang in proposing sale of grower owned assets in AWTA and Wool Stores by appropriate amendments to the forthcoming legislation. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. In a number of questions put before the House and in telegrams to the Minister for Primary Industry and the Acting Minister for Primary Industry I have been attempting to find out what costs will result to the wool industry and wool users from this decision and what benefits will accrue. In the replies that I have received-where I have received replies-I have found nothing to convince me that there will be savings in any way to wool growers or to the Government. In fact, it is quite clear-it was referred to by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Werriwa-that the Hill Samuel independent report commissioned by the Australian Wool Corporation indicated that the costs of the operations of the Testing Authority will increase by at least 15 per cent by virtue of this change. That is undesirable. We can compare it with the fact that charges for services rendered by the Australian Wool Testing Authority, which have been its sole method of financing, have not increased by more than 3 per cent over the past 10 years. Admittedly, I believe that some increase, divorced from this decision, brought about by cost and wage increases is in train at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me emphasise clearly that there is no cost to the Government in any way, and there will be no saving on the current operation of the Authority. There will be no saving in capital or operating costs in any way by effecting a sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority. No public servants are involved and there is no cost to the Commonwealth in capital or operating costs. As I see it, this is an unnecessary dictation to the wool growers, who have taken a very realistic and proper attitude to many other aspects of their industry. For instance, they contribute quite significantly to promotion of the industry, both within Australia and overseas. They contribute to research within their industry and for their industry, both at the producer level and in the textile industry. They also make a significant contribution towards the market support policies and practices within the wool industry. The wool growers have already been called upon and have met the challenge to service their industry without recourse to Government aid. It seems to me an unnecessary dictation to require the sale of the functions which have been provided, serviced and paid for by the wool growers. I can in no way support the sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority or a direction to the Australian Wool Corporation to dispose of certain assets in the way of wool stores.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief remarks. We face a serious situation in what is happening to the Australian Wool Testing Authority. It will be the thin edge of the wedge for primary industry in this country if the kinds of principles which are being ruthlessly applied throughout this nation, led by the so-called small government lobby, are allowed to continue. I can imagine what will happen if all this deregulation is applied in the primary industry area. TALK.START.PARA: -Part V of the Bill deals with bankruptcy. I want to make a few brief comments putting the Opposition's case. We are very much opposed to this Part because we feel the Government is introducing some retrograde steps by encouraging the private sector to take over this area of investigation. A member of the accounting firm of Hungerford, Hancock and Offner has been appointed a member of a joint management review team to review the operations of the Official Receiver section of the Corporate Affairs Division of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. This Part of the Bill implements the findings of that review team in as much as it facilitates the appointment of public accountants to do insolvency work. The Opposition is aware-I presume the Government is, although it has not made it very public knowledge-that the proposals which the Government is now suggesting are almost identical to those outlined in a Green Paper introduced by the United Kingdom Government in June 1980. This United Kingdom Green Paper invited comments from the legal, accounting and commercial interests to the proposition that what the Government is doing here should also be done in England. I can tell honourable members that that paper attracted trenchant criticism from all those professional areas-from the accounting profession and the legal profession in Britain. They saw the pitfalls that that would have introduced in Britain. This is the same type of legislation the Government is trying to introduce here.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government introduced these amendments without any reference to the community interests at all. There was no reference of the matter to the accountancy profession or the legal profession to seek opinions of their members as to what they would do. The only information that these sections of interest might have had would have been in the form of two Press releases, one on 31 December 1980 which made some reference to outside trustees and the other on 30 April 1981 which concerned the razor gang statement. That Press release made a reference to the Government's intention to contract out the Government's bankruptcy work. Neither of those could be described as giving the legal profession, the accountancy profession or the business community full information or an opportunity to comment on the Government's proposals.

I will not take up any more of the time of the House. I merely tell the Government that we on this side of the House do not accept these proposals. We will be opposing this Part of the Bill. This Bill when introduced into the House included recommendations by the Committee, one of the members of which was a member of the accounting firm of Hungerford, Hancock and Offner. The object of the proposals was to get the Government out of bankruptcy work and to get private enterprise into bankruptcy work. On the very day the Bill was introduced, lo and behold, an advertisement appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald. It was an advertisement on behalf of Hungerford, Hancock and Offner seeking a person to join that company's Sydney insolvency section. It stated that the applicant should ideally have had one to three years' experience in a professional office. Insolvency experience was not a firm prerequisite. It continued that the main areas of activity would include receiverships, liquidations, schemes of arrangements and financial investigations, et cetera. It seems to me an incredible coincidence that the company which recommended these changes that the Government should be contracting this work out to private enterprise should, on the day the Bill was introduced, be advertising for more staff. I do not think I am particularly suspicious, but I point out what a rare coincidence that is. Can we be blamed for thinking that that firm might have had some inside information on what the Government proposed to do?

This legislation is a retrograde step. This Government has a responsibility to the business community and to help the people who have suffered desperately as a result of bankruptcies. I think it is fair to say that the only industry in Australia that has grown under this Government has been the bankruptcy industry. The number of bankruptcies has increased unbelievably. It seems to be a very retrograde step for the Government to be abrogating its responsibility to protect the business community and those people who have suffered desperately because of bankruptcies by handing this sector over to private enterprise. We firmly oppose these amendments. To facilitate the passage of this legislation we will not seek to divide the Committee.

Part VI of the Bill deals with the Commonwealth Employees (Compensation) Act. The Bill seeks to amend over 24 Acts. It is no wonder that the Committee is in confusion and there is delay in relation to this legislation. There are more clauses of the Bill to be considered. The amendments moved by the Opposition are intended to improve the legislation. Reports have been given to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) which clearly indicate that in the area of workers compensation there are inordinate delays in dealing with people who are injured at work. Honourable members will appreciate that those people are entitled to receive speedy compensation. I am advised that death claims at the present time take from 18 months to two years to be dealt with. Rather simple claims, such as a loss of hearing, can take from six months to 12 months to be dealt with. The report that was prepared by the Administrative Review Council states that 50 per cent of cases are taking in excess of five months to be dealt with and some are taking up to two years. My second amendment states:
The Commissioner shall determine a claim for compensation as soon as practicable but in any case within 120 days of lodgement of the claim.

Another amendment to the present Act will allow for appeals to be made to what are called prescribed courts as an alternative to what is now proposed, which is that appeals will have to be heard by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Those practising in the profession and those who are well aware of the difficulties are anxious to retain the present position whereby an appeal can be made to a prescribed court. In New South Wales, for example, appeals can be heard by the Workers' Compensation Commission of New South Wales. In support of that proposal I point out that one can see that the litigants will have much more confidence if they know their case is to be heard by a judge who has the experience of dealing with matters of that type. I see no reason why-it would be regressive to do so-we should remove the right of Commonwealth employees to have their appeals heard in this manner. In a nutshell those are the reasons why we think it is important to retain existing rights, and amendments have been moved accordingly. The amendments that have been moved are also designed to speed up the procedure and to make it mandatory that the decisions be given by the Commissioner within a period of 120 days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I can briefly indicate to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) why the Government feels unable to support the amendments that he has moved. I appreciate that they have been moved by the Opposition out of a concern to maintain certain principles. The first amendment would have the effect, as I understand it, of setting up separate divisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Administrative Review Council report which was tabled on 2 June opposed that approach. I gather that the main reason for that opposition was that it would, if implemented, limit the flexibility of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in assigning judges between panels. The whole purpose of a number of these amendments is to increase the level of flexibility.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst on the surface an amendment putting a time limit on the Compensation Commissioner determining claims is attractive-I can understand why the Deputy Leader of the Opposition suggests that-I point out that medical reports often take a good deal of time to be obtained. It is often in the interests of an appellant, quite apart from any question of administrative delay, that those reports are available. They will often strengthen his or her case. I am not immediately aware that such an amendment is necessarily in the interests of social security and compensation of appellants. Incidently, the transfer of appeals to the AAT does bring it under the Ombudsman who can investigate delays. I think that provides for a more flexible approach.

The third amendment, which is to allow appeals to the courts as well as to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, goes against the direction of the Bill, which is to have one avenue of appeal. Once again, this is not just something that was divined by the Government. It follows the recommendation of the Administrative Review Council. We think it is desirable and in the interests of the achievement of a speedy resolution of the appeals, and the avoiding of the confusion of conflicting judgments and jurisdictions, to adopt this approach. As I have said, whilst I understand completely the motives of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in moving these amendments and respect the views he has put, for the reasons I have outlined the Government is not able to accede to them.
Amendments negatived.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX (ASSESSMENT AND RATES) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst not opposing the second reading of this Bill, the House notes that:

(a) because a tax indexation factor of only 3.8 per cent has been applied, all taxpayers whose incomes in 1981-82 will be more than 3.8 per cent above their 1980-81 incomes and whose circumstances do not otherwise alter, will be paying a higher proportion of that income in income tax in 1981-82 than in 1980-81;
(b) such an increase in the burden of income tax continues the pattern of an increasing income tax burden during the Fraser Government's term of office, and
(c) such developments are in stark contrast to the Government's continual attempts to portray itself as a low tax party,
and accordingly deplores the Government's action in abolishing tax indexation altogether for future years, which indicates its clear intention to make full use of the secret tax of inflation'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hurford

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

INTERJECT.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 27-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 28 (Indexation).

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 28 deals with the abolition of indexation from the tax system. Because of the time factor I do not wish to repeat the arguments that I made in my speech in the second reading debate. The indexation which is being abolished by clause 28 relates to dependants allowances and allowances for a sole parent and for a housekeeper. Indexation for these allowances is, of course, part of the overall process of indexation. It is important not only that the Schedule be indexed but also that the allowances be indexed. I rise simply to register our protest at the abolition of indexation in respect of dependants allowances and the other allowances dealt with in this clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the context of the consideration of this clause I would like to emphasise two things. Firstly, the election promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in his last policy speech has been implemented in full by this Government so far as half indexation of tax is concerned. It is important when we are talking about commitments to indexation to state the very obvious proposition that if the Government is elected on a particular program and a particular commitment in this area it is relevant to accept that when the commitments made in the policy speech that have led up to that election have been discharged claims of broken promises and broken undertakings in the general area to which those commitments relate are without foundation. The commitment on which this Government was re-elected, so far as half indexation is concerned, was to have a $500m tax deduction on 1 July. The very Bill we are debating-the Income Tax (Assessment and Rates) Amendment Bill-gives effect to that. I make it quite clear that any suggestions that commitments in the last policy speech on this subject have been breached are without any foundation.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, there are arguments for and against tax indexation which I, and the Government, acknowledge. There are advantages in tax indexation, but the Government has come to the conclusion, after balancing the arguments for and against, that a system of discretionary tax reductions is preferable. Obviously the honourable member for Gellibrand is right in saying we can have half or full indexation and also discretionary tax cuts but I think he would agree that if we have a system of automatic indexation the capacity for discretionary tax cuts is reduced. I think that is elementary. It does not follow that through the abolition of automatic tax indexation, or half indexation, the quantum of tax cuts will be the less. Indeed, some people have argued that the abolition of tax indexation implies that in the future governments of either pursuasion will be under greater pressure than they have been in the past to give a greater degree of discretionary tax reductions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments on the abolition of tax indexation. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) has sought to justify the Government's decision on the ground that because the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made a promise the Government will continue with indexation this year and it will then be abolished. In 1975, the Prime minister promised:

SPEECH.PARA: We will reduce the tax burden, we will put an end to Labor's tax rip off.
We will fully index personal income tax for inflation over three years . . . It will make Government more honest with your money. They will no longer be able to rely on the secret tax of inflation.

However, here we are in 1981 debating the Income Tax (Assessment and Rates) Amendment Bill, which is designed to eliminate tax indexation. The Treasurer did say that the Prime Minister had promised full indexation and had honoured that promise to the extent that half indexation had been reached. After six years he nearly got there but now we are heading fast back to where we started. All that huff and puff we have had for six years has amounted to nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was relevant to reduce inflation.

—I think it can be clearly indicated that inflation is on the rise again. There is no doubt about that. Under the old 1977 policies we would be going to full tax indexation to arrest the situation, but we are going the opposite way. So much for the Prime Minister's promise. It is just like the one we finished with a while ago. Today's Sydney Morning Herald had an interesting table headed 'Poor Man's Guide to Higher Taxes'. Mr David Collins, a lecturer in economics at Macquarie University, clearly indicated in that table where tax indexation has been going under the Fraser Government. The $1.50 a week tax cut proposed in this Bill will be more like a 95c tax cut for most people. The table shows that the single taxpayer who begins the new financial year on the average earnings of $15,000 will actually pay $480 more than in the previous year. The proportion of his income lost in tax will rise from 23.3 per cent to 23.9 per cent. So, the Government's promise of half tax indexation, about which the Treasurer spoke before, has become effectively only 35 per cent indexation. The promise of half indexation actually turns out to be a promise of 35 per cent indexation, which turns out to be a promise that it will last for 12 months, which in turn turns out to be a promise that the Government did not intend to keep indexation going anyway. So much for this Government's approach to taxation and tax concessions.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Bill, in the next 12 months, those people in the higher brackets of income no doubt will be better off than those on lower incomes. The figures for assessable incomes show that between 1976-77 and 1981-82 the average tax for those on the lower incomes increased. For those on $9,000 a year it increased by 1.2 per cent but for those in the higher brackets of $30,000 a year and upwards it declined by from 1.6 per cent to 3 per cent. Everything this Government seems to do in taxation is designed to shift the wealth from the poor to the very wealthy. Of course, that is very much in tune with what the Fraser Government has been about for the last five or six years. This Bill, along with many others, provides another opportunity for the Fraser Government to shift the wealth of the country from those who can least afford to pay to those who can afford to pay greater taxation. The excuse for that is that if people are given the opportunity to spend their own money then it will be spent more wisely than if the Government collects the just tax that these people should be paying. The Opposition disagrees with that philosophy. This Government has backed off from tax indexation. It has been promising lower taxes and lower Government spending, but we all know that this year Government revenue is up 16.2 per cent on last year. All the spending cuts appear to be in rhetoric more than anything else, yet this Government is only too efficient at giving tax concessions to those who need them least. From the evidence of this week, some of the promises which the Prime Minister has made and which the Treasurer has defended have been honoured and some people are very lucky in that they will get rather large tax concessions whilst other people will miss out; they will get 95c a week, under 35 per cent tax indexation. Eventually, at the end of the 12 months, the promises will disappear altogether and people can expect to be paying increased taxes. What were the words used? The Prime Minister said that, after 12 months, indexation would make this Government more honest with the people's money and the people would be able to rely on the Government having no secret tax increases because of inflation.

Clauses 29 to 34-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 35 (Indexation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -There is no way at all in which the Opposition would be prepared to join the conspiracy of deceit on the part of the Government in connection with the abolition of tax indexation at the end of the coming financial year. This clause would be the most important clause in the Bill as far as the great mass of Australian people are concerned. In view of the type of deceit that is and has been associated with the application of tax indexation in Australia, we should look at the unhappy history of this concept. The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) referred to the fact that undertakings were given prior to the election in 1975. I would accept that during the period which has elapsed, particularly in view of the fact that two elections have taken place, it would be unreasonable to hold a government to promises which were made at that time. Promises have been made subsequently and I would like to deal with them. In the first instance, the undertaking made prior to the election in 1975 was based on terms of this kind:

SPEECH.PARA: Tax indexation is not only a social reform of immense importance but is also designed to encourage consumer spending. It will also make governments more honest with taxpayers' money.
We have become increasingly aware of statements of that kind since 1975; particularly, we have become aware of statements of that kind immediately prior to elections.

It has been said that without tax indexation taxation then becomes tax by stealth as a result of inflation forcing income earners into higher taxation brackets. The people of Australia were left with the impression following an undertaking made prior to the election of 1975 that full tax indexation would be applied. The deceit started then. In fact, it was not full indexation. The actual index adopted was one which was discounted for indirect taxes. The deceit grew as the concept was referred to on subsequent occasions. During 1977-78 supposed full tax indexation was continued. The consumer price index was again discounted for indirect tax. However, added to the list were the effects of devaluation and changes in the health insurance arrangements. So the discounting component of the index was gradually increased and the value of the index was continually reduced. So the undertaking given prior to the election in 1975 was increasingly dishonoured, even during the first two years of the application of that undertaking.

Indexation was abandoned in 1978-79. During that year, of course, tax scales were increased as well. Indexation was resumed in 1979-80. Again deceit was associated with this measure. Discounting not only took into account indirect taxes, which were part of the Government's policy, but also things such as devaluation and the effect of import parity pricing. An index of only 6.5 per cent was applied at a time when the CPI for the March to March year was 7.9 per cent. Half tax indexation with discounting was applied again in 1980-81. This year half tax indexation will apply. I think it is reasonable for the electorate to expect that when a clear undertaking is given, as quite clearly an undertaking was given, to apply half indexation from 1 July 1981 that that is what would be applied. In fact discounting has been introduced again. The CPI increase for the March to March year was 9.9 per cent. After discounting the figure becomes 7.6 per cent and the index applied is 3.8 per cent.

Tax indexation is to be abandoned altogether at the end of this financial year. I think it is very interesting to look at the precise words that are being used in connection with this decision. I would suggest to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) that he not allow himself to be influenced by the sort of mental mechanics that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is engaged in because the statement that the Treasurer made immediately following the announcement of changes in the health insurance scheme indicates that in fact he is being affected by the same mental mechanics that have afflicted the Prime Minister. Prior to the last election the Prime Minister said that from 1 July half tax indexation would apply which would cost the Government during the first year something like $500m. It is reasonable for the Australian people to expect, as they did expect, that as a result of that statement made prior to an election the undertaking would not apply just for 12 months-the Treasurer knows that-but would apply for the term of the Parliament. At the time that statement was made the Treasurer came into this chamber and used certain terms quite deliberately. He knows that the undertaking was deliberate and he knows that he was part of that deceit. He tried to justify that decision. I genuinely appeal to the Treasurer not to participate in that sort of chicanery because the Prime Minister-I am not going to use the term-is becoming increasingly referred to by millions of Australians as compounding lie after lie after lie. If I were permitted to use blunt and accurate terms of that kind in this chamber I would do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member might moderate his language a bit, otherwise he would reflect on a member of this place and his remarks would be out of order.
—I certainly will. I would like to read to the Committee the terms used by the Treasurer. The Treasurer will recall what he said. The Treasurer stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has now decided that discretionary adjustments to taxation scales and allowances are preferable to tax indexation.
That is okay so far. He went on:
However, the Government is conscious of the precise terms-
Let me emphasise that. The Treasurer stated:

However, the Government is conscious of the precise terms of what was said in the Prime Minister's policy speech and accordingly I will confirm that half-tax indexation will apply from 1 July next, thus providing in full the benefit of some $500m foreshadowed in that speech.

The Treasurer in effect went on: 'However, after 1 July-after we have honoured that commitment made prior to the election which gave the electorate the impression that it would continue for the term of the Parliament; after we have honoured the words used in the statement, at the end of that 12 months-the taxpayer will cop it in the neck'. The Treasurer went on:
However, that tax indexation adjustment will be the last indexation adjustment.

So we have had a continuation of the deceit which has been practised by the Prime Minister in connection with so many of the undertakings that have been given. The Prime Minister, of course, was quite blunt about the reason why tax indexation was going to be abandoned. The Prime Minister is on record as having said that the reason why tax indexation was going to be abandoned was that it was not obvious to the electorate, that the taxpayers did not understand it, that a government got no credit or kudos for it. It is quite obvious that as far as this Government is concerned taxation policy will not be determined on the basis of rational economic policy and management. As far as the Prime Minister and this Government are concerned, taxation policy, as all the other areas of economic policy, will be used for cheap politicking, for meeting electoral bribes and will not be used to achieve the type of purposes that we should expect economic policy and sane and rational economic management to achieve.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Remainder of the Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
