PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Howard)-by leave-read a third time.
Second Reading
Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Mr Moore:
The the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is ridiculous that at this late hour-after 11 o'clock-we are commencing debate on a most important Bill. It is just another example of how the business of this House is being mismanaged and how inadequate attention is being given to important legislation. I repeat that debate on the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill is commencing after 11 o'clock with the expectation that we will be here until at least 1 o'clock in the morning. We were here until 2 o'clock this morning and 3 o'clock the morning before. This Bill now before the House bears all the characteristics of the Government-ad hoc decision making, inconsistent attitudes and the projection of a facade of concern, while proceeding unashamedly to abdicate its responsibility to govern.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill is to establish an authority to monitor petroleum products prices but the authority will have virtually no independence, low status and limited powers and resources. As long as this Government remains in office, and unless the amendment I shall move, is passed, the authority will be subject to interference by a Minister who has no commitment to its existence or fundamental purpose. The authority is to replace the functions in respect of the petroleum products industry previously conferred on the Prices Justification Tribunal. This Government has abolished the Tribunal. The Opposition is totally opposed to the abolition of the PJT. We regard the Bill before the House as a lame attempt to placate legitimate public concern about petroleum prices and concern among service station proprietors in Australia regarding the pricing practices of the major oil companies. We in the Labor Opposition believe, having been convinced by the recommendations of the Collins royal commission into the petroleum industry, that the authority should go further than is envisaged in this Bill. The amendment to the second reading which I shall move on behalf of the Opposition sets out our attitude succinctly. I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a veiw to substituting the following words:
'the House is of the opinion that-

(1) the Bill should be withdrawn and redrafted to extend the role of the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority to that of an independent regulatory agency for the petroleum and petroleum products industries as recommended by the 4th Report of the Royal Commission on Petroleum (the Collins Report), with functions to include:
(a) restructuring, monitoring and regulating the pricing system;
(b) the rationalisation, where necessary, of retail outlets;
(c) the regulation of dealer-company relationships, and
(d) the development of a conservation program, and

(2) the Government should be condemned for its decision to abolish the Prices Justification Tribunal which was carrying out the functions of the proposed Petroleum Products Pricing Authority and calls upon it to retain a reformed Tribunal for such purposes as the provision of effective powers to monitor and inquire into the justification of prices in all oil products and other goods exempted by this Bill'.

The concept of prices justification was introduced in Australia by the Labor Government in 1973. It involved the establishment of an independent body which could inquire into prices and report whether they were justified. There was no compulsion on the companies to accept the findings of the Tribunal. We did not have those powers under the Constitution. It was not a price control system. However, the Tribunal found that many industries set prices in ways which do not follow the orthodox model of free market competition. On many occasions the Tribunal's members found that prices were not justified. Within the limited scope of the Tribunal's power its work proved to be effective in providing important information on many industries relevant to Government policy and in limiting the extent of price increases. In 1979-80 the PJT's rejection of 230 price increase applications led to a saving of $160m.

The last inquiry into the prices of petroleum products, dated 31 March this year, found that an increase in the wholesale price of motor spirit of 0.25c per litre was justified whereas the companies sought increases of between 0.9 and 3.25c per litre. What the Tribunal allowed was an enormous saving over what the companies wanted. The Tribunal also found that an amount is included in the list price of motor spirit which provides a return on investment in retail outlets. The Tribunal asserted that this should be removed. The Goverment decided on the basis of that recommendation from the Tribunal, that this would occur in January 1982. It is this intention, together with the intention to inquire into other areas in the petroleum products industry, which has led the Government to make an exception in this case and to provide a continuing legislative framework for inquiries into the justification of prices.

The fact that the Government has provided for this exception is open acknowledgement of the validity of the prices justification concept. The petroleum products industry has certain characteristics which suggest that fully competitive behaviour is unlikely. The petroleum industry is heavily concentrated. Through a variety of refinery exchange agreements, substantial integration of the operations of the companies and, hence, co-operative price setting is normal in the industry. It will become even more concentrated following the recent takeover of Golden Fleece Petroleum by the Caltex company. Although I take this opportunity of welcoming the fact that Caltex has taken Australian shareholders into its shareholding, the majority of firms are multinational corporations which have about 83 per cent of the market. The industry has become highly vertically integrated so that systems of transfer pricing are available to enable companies to take their profits at any point that suits their interests, for example, oil production, or transportation, refining, wholesaling or retailing. For example, in 1974 the PJT adjusted the price increase claimed by the Shell Co of Australia Ltd taking into account doubts which surrounded the reasonableness of the price charged by its overseas affiliate companies.

It is a well-established fact that oil companies have adjusted their main points of profit taking over time, demonstrating clearly that discretionary action rather than market forces can have a major impact on prices. These characteristics of oligopoly-that is, just a few firms dominating the market-market power and multinational domination are by no means exclusive to the petroleum industry. The Government, however reluctantly and half-heartedly, has acknowledged the validity of prices justification requirements in the case of the oil industry. Why has it not done so in the other industries which are oligopolistic-dominated by just a few firms? It is utterly inconsistent that this Government does not similarly recognise the need in other industries.

Let us look at the prima facie evidence in some of these other industries. I will mention just a couple of them. On the London Metal Exchange aluminium is selling at about $1,140 per tonne. In Australia the Camalco Ltd price-which is the same as with Alcan Australia Ltd and other companies in that field-is $1,545 per tonne. That is no less than 405 more than the London Metal Exchange price. It is 35 per cent higher in Australia for a product for which Australians should have a decided comparative advantage. We do have that advantage as long as we are not dominated by overseas companies which take their profits with a lame government, such as the one we have now, not putting up any opposition to the companies doing so.

Another example is that of coffee. The 40 per cent reduction in the price of raw coffee, which forms the bulk of the value of processed coffee, has not been passed on to the Australian consumer in lower prices. I could cite many other examples apart from those two. Over the past two or three years the Prices Justification Tribunal has gathered substantial evidence to show, firstly, that in Australia there is an increasing trend among firms to base their prices on a cost estimate which incorporates their expectations of inflation and what they believe the price increase will be. This is a prescription for inflation itself. It is a guarantee for inflation when the expectation of price increases is added an input to the price of the product. Secondly, many firms are also pricing their products in order to finance rapid expansion into export markets. The aluminium industry, which I have just mentioned, is a case in point. Again, this means that inflation is inevitable.

Clearly, free market competition is not succeeding in containing inflation. There is no true competition. Profits are up; prices are up and inflation is set to rebound again, yet the Government is reducing the means available to put some brake on that inflation. The poor old ordinary Australian consumer is taken to the cleaners. He is treated as a sucker by this Government which provides no means by which the consumer's interest can be examined and prices monitored on his behalf. It is utterly inconsistent that this Government does not similarly recognise the need for prices justification in other sectors as it does in the sector of the petroleum industry which we are looking at now. I will say more about the rationale for prices justification. I believe the reasons are quite clear but I will set them out again. Firstly, effective prices justification procedures are an essential ingredient in any wages-prices package of anti-inflationary policies. Acceptance by workers and their organisations of wage restraint must be premised on the understanding that price increases-which after all have the effect of reducing real wages-are subject to a degree of public accountability. After all the trade unions must justify their claims before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Why should there not be some justification so that on the other side of the ledger people who have control over prices have to justify their price increases? Of course there should be justification. The alternative, apparently favoured by this Government, is Rafferty's rules. That can lead only to leapfrogging inflation.

Secondly, prices justification is needed to counter the undoubted increasing market power of major corporations. Trade practices legislation cannot do this job in a small market such as Australia's because monopoly and oligopoly is inevitable. This is all the more so in our six major sub-markets, the capital cities, which are so widely dispersed. We need an economic watchdog to protect the public interest. The evidence that the market will not achieve the required control is overwhelming.

Thirdly, we need a system which not only works fairly and efficiently but also which is seen to work fairly and efficiently. Social cohesion is a prerequisite for economic success and social cohesion is dependent on greater public awareness of the workings of the economic system. There must be respect for that system. There must be fairness and more than that there must be evidence of fairness. Justice must be seen to be done. A prices justification system is a vital component of that social cohesion. These overwhelming arguments have been ignored by this Government. It has already moved to abolish the Prices Justification Tribunal in the last Bill before the Parliament. Of course, the Government is now setting up a so-called authority which in practice will be subject to the dictates of the Minister. The Government deserves to be condemned for irresponsibily doing this.

I turn to some of the specific feature of the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill now before the House. If the second reading amendment is defeated the Opposition intends to move amendments at the Committee stage to improve the Bill. I hear some moaning from the Government side. Why do honourable members opposite not sort out their own house and make sure they are not putting legislation through at this hour? I am prepared to come back next Thursday if need be. I am prepared to debate this sort of measure in the proper time-not after 11 o'clock at night. But I am not going to allow legislation of this sort to go through the Parliament in the dying hours of the sitting without having a say on it on behalf of hundreds of thousands of Australians who agree with the sort of points I am making.

TALK.START.PARA: —They couldn't run a toffee apple store.

—As the honourable member for Hunter said, Government members could not run a toffee apple store. I believe that the Bill is a pale shadow of the legislation which we need. The discretionary power given to the Minister is virtually absolute. I believe that a Minister of the complexion of the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick), of the same complexion as the Government we have, will not exercise any discretion in favour of this Authority looking at the prices of petroleum products in the interests of ordinary Australians. The Minister may decide which goods are to be considered under the Act. Without giving any reasons he can exempt any goods, even petrol itself. How can we trust a Liberal or a National Country Party Minister with this sort of power? That is why I will move the amendments at the Committee stage to seek to correct that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may direct the Commissioner on how he is to conduct an inquiry and what he is to take into account. The Minister may appoint anyone he desires to conduct inquiries. There is no requirement that such persons have no conflicting pecuniary interest. If he wants he can appoint the general managers or chairmen of the oil companies themselves to do this task. He can refuse to allow the Authority to conduct an inquiry and he does not need to give any reasons for so doing. The sort of powers given to this Minister are a farce. There are no criteria laid down for determining whether an inquiry is appropriate. That is, the Minister can decide what is done, how it is done, whether it is done and by whom it is done. This inevitably undermines the status and authority of the Commissioner. The oil companies can simply apply political pressure whenever the going gets tough. The public will not have confidence that findings do not reflect bias and political pressure.

I repeat that should the Opposition's amendment not succeed at the second reading-we have not the numbers to make sure that it does succeed-I will seek in the Committee stage to rectify many of the tremendous errors in the legislation. The second major weakness of the Bill is in its limited scope. In the time that I intend to take tonight-which is a limited time, in spite of the noises from the other side-the Opposition has not prepared amendments in this respect. However, we have moved that the Bill be withdrawn and redrafted to achieve this examination of its scope. So the Opposition puts its feelings on this matter on record. The scope of the Bill needs to be extended both in terms of the products under consideration and in terms of the functions of the Authority. The Opposition believes that petroleum and petrol products should all be considered by the Authority. The Collins Royal Commission on Petroleum noted that the industry is integrated and that all aspects must be considered. It said:
Almost every country in the world has some agency, or Department of State designed specifically to deal with this industry in the areas of distribution, marketing and pricing.

It recommended that such an agency be established for Australia. That was stated by the Collins Royal Commission which examined aspects of the petroleum industry for many months. The need for an agency remains. The Government brought in this legislation last year to regulate franchises and the number of company-owned retail sites. As the Opposition pointed out, this legislation has not resolved all of the problems-we pointed out that this would be so-in the petrol reselling industry. We said then, and we repeat now, that an agency with these wider powers is needed. We have indicated our attitude in the amendment that I moved at the second reading stage. The Government is apparently already considering watering down the legislation passed last year for the small business people in the retail sector of this industry. The Bill before us clearly demonstrates that the Government has no real commitment to the regulation of the industry. We regard that as an abdication of responsibility which will adversely affect the consuming public and small business petrol resellers alike.

In summary, the Opposition considers that this is a totally inadequate Bill. It has inadequate scope and fails to provide an essential measure of independence to the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. Moreover, it is a Bill which is cast within the context of the abolition of the PJT. This action of the Government is an abdication of its responsibilities and represents a major retreat from policies needed to restrain the rate of inflation and to promote the social cohesion necessary to economic growth. We believe that the Government should reverse its decision on the PJT. We believe that it should also withdraw this Bill in order that it can be redrafted along the lines that I have stated.

TALK.START.PARA: — Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Petroleum Products Pricing Bill is very important. It provides for a body to take the place of the Prices Justification Tribunal. It provides for the establishment of a Petroleum Products Pricing Authoity with the power to inquire into prices and price increases for petroleum products. Of course, the abolition of the PJT is provided for in the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill 1981, which was introduced on 27 May last. One function of the PJT which will remain is the power of surveillance over prices charged by the petroleum products industry. These powers will be given to the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority established under this Bill. The pricing of petroleum products has been a very controversial issue over the past few years. It covers a very wide field of activity. Wholesale and retail outlets, bulk distributors, primary producers and transport operators all have to be covered under a price structure. This Authority has indeed a very wide range in which to examine prices.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill provides for the establishment of a Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. This legislation provides for prices of petroleum products only. It is very important legislation. It is felt that dealing with only petroleum products could provide and enable a more thorough and efficient investigation to be made. The Bill is dealing only with the petroleum industry. As mentioned, the Authority should be more efficient than if it were an authority looking into a whole range of products. Every Australian is interested in the pricing of petrol, distillate, heating oil and associated products because they have an everyday usage. Liquid fuels are the basis for much of the national way of life and standard of living. We are fortunate in Australia to produce 65 per cent of our petroleum requirements. We import 35 per cent of requirements from overseas, mainly from the Persian Gulf and particularly from Saudi Arabia. With a mixture of local product and imports it can easily be ascertained that pricing is a complicated matter and requires close surveillance. It means much to the economy of Australia. It is sad to say that we have great problems with delays with tankers coming from overseas and with tankers coming from Bass Strait to the refineries on the eastern seaboard. Every time there is a hold-up caused by a strike in Bass Strait it adds considerably to the cost of petroleum products being delivered to the eastern seaboard or to other parts of Australia.

This Government, by its world parity pricing policy, has made it attractive for overseas companies with the necessary know-how and expertise to provide capital for petroleum exploration in Australia, both on-shore and off-shore. The policy has also attracted locally established companies to explore and, indeed, to develop pockets of known petroleum that hitherto were not economic. We have an instance of this in Bass Strait, where Esso-BHP, owing to our pricing policy, found it economic to tap a lake of fuel in the Kingfisher field. Possibly this field will be in production by 1982 to help us to maintain a stable pricing policy. To do so we must keep up our oil exploration policy. This is extremely important. It has been good to read recently of possible petroleum finds in other parts of Australia. Energy pricing, in particular the pricing of petroleum products, is of fundamental importance. Realistic pricing will influence consumption of petroleum products and, as I stated previously, will encourage exploration for and development of additional petroleum resources.

Under this legislation the Authority will conduct inquiries and determine whether prices for the supply of petroleum products or other services are justified. As mentioned previously, what a complicated setup it is with all these fields of petroleum demand. The surveillance of the prices will extend only to defined petroleum products and to services related to the production or supply of such products. Companies will be required to notify the Authority of any proposed increases in the prices at which they supply petroleum products or associated services in a particular locality. Of course, provision exists for the Authority to withhold increases or to allow interim price increases pending the outcome of an inquiry. This is, indeed, a very fair part of the legislation which we are debating here tonight. The Minister has power to direct the Authority on matters to which special consideration is to be given. Under the legislation provision is made for strict confidentiality of certain material. This is an important provision and appears in clauses 26 and 37 of the Bill.

It was interesting to hear from the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) that Caltex Oil (Australia) Pty Ltd has made a share offering to the Australian public to take part in the activities of that company in Australia. This is good news. The costs of the distribution of petroleum by companies are related to their refineries, to the location of their seaboard terminals and to their overall costs. Bulk installations and methods of distribution play a very important part in the costing of petroleum products. Those companies that have come into the petroleum market in this country in recent years are at a disadvantage compared with those that have been set up here for many years. With the increase in costs they cannot be expected to compete with major companies that have been established for many years. This must give them great problems. It must also give the Authority problems in establishing a fair price setup.

I will be as brief as possible, but it might be just as well to refer to some of the main provisions of the Bill. Clause 5 establishes the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority, which will be headed by the Commissioner for Petroleum Products Pricing which is a new position. This person is to be appointed by the Governor-General and may be the person who holds the office of full time member of the Temporary Assistance Authority. The appointment will be for a period of five years. Clause 11 allows the Minister to appoint one or more associate commissioners for particular inquiries. It must be understood that such appointments are necessary because a single commissioners would need help. Provision is made for the disclosure of financial interests, and for the resignation or termination of appointments of the Commissioner and associate commissioners. The Commissioner is empowered to convene meetings of the Authority at such times and places as he thinks necessary. Certain other provisions relate to the holding of meetings.

Clause 17, which is another important clause, empowers the Minister to require the Authority to conduct an inquiry, specifying the product and/or company to be investigated. In other than a prices justification inquiry, the Minister may also give directions for the conduct of an inquiry. He may specify a time limit for inquiries and he may also direct the Authority to give special consideration to a specific matter or matters. I believe this is an adequate Bill. The honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) who led for the Opposition, was of the opinion that the Bill was not adequate. I think it covers every facet of the industry and 'in our opinion' it is an adequate Bill and has our full support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence, I should explain that we did not divide the House so that there would be more time for debate. However, I trust that the Government Whip will allow the honourable member for Burke to say a few words in the Committee stage.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 2, lines 33-35, omit paragraph (c) of the definition of 'petroleum product'.
Clause 4, page 3, line 4, at the end of sub-clause (1) add or by a trading entity in which a company has a beneficial financial interest'.
Clause 12, page 6, lines 9 and 10, omit 'being an interest that could conflict with the proper performance of his functions in relation to that inquiry,'.

Clause 12, page 6, lines 14 and 15, omit 'unless his interest is disclosed in any report in which he participates', substitute 'being an interest that could conflict with the proper performance of his functions in relation to this Act'.
Clause 16, page 8, line 12, omit ', with the approval of the Minister,'.
Clause 16, page 8, lines 17-21, omit sub-clause (5), substitute the following sub-clauses:

'(5) In performance of its functions, the Authority shall have regard not only to the need for the company or companies concerned to achieve a level of profitability that is sufficient to enable the company or companies to maintain an adequate level of investment and employment but also to the desire of the Government of the Commonwealth, in pursuing the general objectives of national economic and social policy, to implement an equitable anti-inflation policy, and in particular, the desire of the Government of the Commonwealth to subject prices to public scrutiny so as to ensure-

(a) that companies are in a position of public accountability which parallels that of unions' requirements to justify their members' wage levels before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission; and

(b) that unreasonably high profits are not being made at the expense of consumers and that unnecessarily high costs, either as the result of inefficiency or other unjustified reasons, are not being passed into prices.
(6) In sub-section (5)-
''unnecessarily high costs'' includes such items as costs arising from-
(a) excessive transfer prices between related companies;
(b) excessive royalty payments and the like to overseas parent companies;
(c) exceptional wages and salary increases;
(d) unnecessarily high interest payments and rents;
(e) unnecessary advertising and packaging expenses;
(f) inefficient operations, and
(g) the refusal to make proper allowances for productivity improvements; and

'unreasonably high profits' includes levels of profitability, resulting from the abuse of a strong market position, that are more than sufficient to enable the company or companies to maintain an adequate level of investment and employment.'.
Clause 20, page 14, line 19, omit ''$10,000'', substitute '$100,000'.

I thank those who gave me leave, but I would have been surprised if they had not done so. In fact, I am doing the Government a good turn by moving the amendments in this way rather than moving each of the eight amendments separately. I wish that we had here the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore), who is responsible for the Bill. I made the eight amendments available to his office some hours ago and I hoped that in some cases he could have accepted one or two of them. That would have meant that we would have had to move them separately. However, it means that they are given some attention, and the next time a similar Bill is before the chamber I hope it will be amended in the way I have suggested.

Before dealing with the amendments, I point out that generaly they have two features. One is to make the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority independent of the Minister. There are so many cases in this Bill where the Minister's discretion is involved, and without independence, the Authority will have no power but will be merely a cipher of the Government. The Minister, of course, is a sycophant of the oil industry, and the people's interests would be neglected. The first amendment relates to clause 3. The power provided in this clause for the Minister to exempt any product for the purposes of the Act is one of the many discretionary powers conferred on the Minister. That would be removed by this amendment. The second amendment relates to clause 4. It is important that no scope is available for the purposes of the Act to be hindered by the use of non-corporate entities such as trusts or partnerships. Our amendment would mean that such non-corporate entities, where they were subsidiary to a company, would have the same effect as if they were a company. The Prices Justification Tribunal had some problems with these non-corporate forms. Whilst the Constitution limits the powers of the Commonwealth in these cases, the provisions of this amendment would be unlikely to offend in that regard because they are concerned with circumstances where a company is an ultimate beneficiary to a trading entity.

The third and fourth amendments relate to clause 12 of the Bill. The Prices Justification Tribunal Act provides that no member of the PJT shall have any direct or indirect pecuniary interest in relation to a matter subject to an inquiry. The Opposition sees no reason to water down that provision of the Act and cannot imagine any reason why a commissioner or associate commissioner should be allowed to have such an interest. We can only imagine that the Government is considering appointing someone from the industry as a commissioner or associate commissioners. Of course, that would be utterly objectionable to us and it should be to everyone. We have moved the third amendment to make it quite clear that that could not happen. The fifth amendment deals with clause 16 (3). We believe the Authority must have a reputation which commands the respect of the industry with which it deals. It will be a toothless tiger if its operations are subject to the whims, biases and weaknesses of the Minister and his Government. In other words, this is another amendment which comes under the feature of making the Authority more independent than this Bill allows.

The sixth amendment relates to clause 16 (5) of the Bill. A major criticism of the PJT has been the inadequate guidelines in the legislation as to the meaning to be attached to a justified price. The existing provision in the Bill is inadequate and biased, and it is for that reason that we seek to delete that provision and suggest a new one. To reduce the extent of inconsistent interpretation, to define more clearly the functions of the Bill, and to ensure that the Minister's actions are not without guidance, we have moved this amendment. Of particular importance is our view that the Authority has a role in the fight against inflation, and in providing a check on prices which parallels the accountability of trade unions before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

Coming to the seventh amendment, clause 18 gives another broad discretion to the Minister which we oppose and which this amendment would delete. If the clause were allowed to stay as it is, it would enable the Minister to prejudice an inquiry by limiting its criteria for assessment. Clause 17 (4) already gives adequate power to the Minister in respect of inquiries other than prices justification inquiries to 'give such directions as he thinks fit as to the conduct of the inquiry or the matters to be taken into consideration'. We believe there is no need for the words that are included and which our amendment seeks to delete.

Finally, the eighth amendment relates to prices. The penalty for increasing prices after the Authority serves notice on a company should reflect the seriousness of the offence. The penalty in the 1973 Prices Justification Tribunal Act was $10,000. Inflation has made a tremendous erosion in the value of $10,000, yet that is the figure placed in the Bill. Of course, it makes a nonsense of the offence. Inflation, and the fact that the Bill relates only to the petroleum products industry, implies that a stronger penalty should be applied. We say that that penalty should be $100,000. In the Trade Practices Act the penalty is $250,000, and the profits that could be made by a company if it sells petroleum products at a few cents a litre above the justified price would be enormous. A penalty of $100,000 instead of a measly $10,000 would be much more appropriate. I commend the eight amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only two minutes in which to speak, so I had better race on. I ask honourable members not to interrupt me because they will waste my time. I support the Government in the all important area of petrol pricing. For many years I was involved in the petroleum industry. For years I thought that the Prices Justification Tribunal was unable to fix a fair and just price for all the consumers of petrol and the motorists of Australia. We saw a stupid situation where the PJT fixed a maximum wholesale price for petrol in every capital city. Yet in fact, some oil companies were able to sell below that wholesale price to the disadvantage of many motorists in this country. We allowed this to go on year after year without raising an eyebrow.

SPEECH.PARA: When I first became a member of parliament I made the point that in Tasmania, for example, we were paying 30c a gallon more for petrol than were the motorists in Victoria. The stupid situation exists in South Australia where the price is 7c a litre-I think it is around that figure-more than any other capital city. Petrol is a very precious commodity. Today we all depend and rely on petrol. In the cities and country areas of Australia there should be a fair and just price for everybody. I issue a warning to the Government that I will be watching the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority very closely. If I feel that one party is being disadvantaged by decision making that could be said to be to the detriment of motorists, I will be watching the situation. The honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) suggested that the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs should not have an overriding authority over the Authority. Of course, the Government needs to monitor to a degree that decision making if it is not in the interests of the motorists of Australia. We are dealing with a very precious commodity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the amendments which have been moved by the Opposition to the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill. I commend the Bill to honourable members opposite, the Committee, and especially those who live in country areas. Unless these amendments are carried the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority, which is proposed to be established in place of the Prices Justification Tribunal to exercise control over the price of petrol and other oil products, will not be able to exercise proper control. One can see this if one looks at the main and central clause of the Bill-clause 18-which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may, by notice in writing under his hand delivered to the Commissioner, direct the Authority to give special consideration, in exercising its functions and powers under this Act, to the matter or matters specified in the notice and the Authority shall comply with any such direction.

This clause is so broad that it means that all the other factors which prices justification tribunals are normally required to take into account need not be taken into account if the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs so directs. We have a situation where under this clause, for example, if the Authority makes a judgment that in the opinion of the Authority the profitability of the oil companies has been taken into account but in the opinion of the Minister the Authority should have made a determination for much higher profitability for those oil companies, then the Minister is able to direct the oil companies to accept his view and take notice of his opinion to such a degree that the Authority would have to overturn its original view. Under those circumstances, what kind of protection will be given to the motorists of Australia? It gives the total discretion, the total power, to the Minister. If the Authority does not take notice of the Minister's message it will be contravening the Act itself.

In what way then will we have an independent tribunal? In what way will we have a tribunal that is supposed to take into account the various factors which are involved in the complex task of determining the price of petrol? These parts of the Bill are complex. It is not just a matter of determining what is in the interests of the profitability of oil companies. It is also a matter of determining what is in the public interest and, in particular, of determining whether, for example, an analysis has been made as to whether those kinds of prices are unnecessarily burdening the community in this day and age. The Authority needs also to take into account other factors such as the distribution of petrol and petrol pricing. The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) mentioned this point in his remarks. I notice, however, that he did not vote for the Opposition's overall amendment which was moved to the second reading and which would have guaranteed and protected the point which he made earlier.

We recommend to honourable members opposite the amendments we have moved. They are not radical or outrageous. They are there to protect the consumer. We call upon honourable members opposite to support them if they are genuinely concerned to ensure that petrol pricing is maintained at a reasonable level. We are aware of the reasons that this Bill has been introduced. It has been introduced because of the fact that the Government wanted to wipe out price control in virtually every other major area of the economy. The Government is aware that there are certain members of the oil industry, especially those who belong to the National Country Party, who would be very upset if a decontrolling of the price of petrol were introduced because this would affect people living in remote country areas.

Therefore, the Government has agreed to replace the Prices Justification Tribunal with an authority concerned with a very limited task regarding the price of petrol. This suggests that somehow oil companies are the only bodies that need to be controlled in the matter of pricing and in the matter of protecting the consumer against conspiracy. I am referring to the conspiracy of the oil companies and other companies in presenting their cases to such an authority. People who have worked on the PJT have told me about the fact that companies do engage in conspiracy in terms of their representations to the Tribunal. There is no protection against this sort of thing in the present law. We commend the Opposition's amendments. They will protect the consumer and we ask that all honourable members support them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a few minutes to respond to the points made by the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford). I realise that it is late but I think when amendments are put forward it is appropriate that there be a response, albeit brief. With regard to the first amendment, petroleum products cover a very wide range of refinery goods and it is not possible to delineate them in the Schedule to the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill. In the normal course of events the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority will deal with those products of significance to the community and the economy as, in fact, the Prices Justification Tribunal does now. The existing provision allows a desirable flexibility in the event that for particular reasons it becomes necessary to specify additional products outside the jurisdiction of the Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the second amendment proposed by the honourable member for Adelaide, I inform the Committee that it is not acceptable to the Government. The additional words are not necessary. I draw attention to the fact that provision exists in clause 4 (3) for the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to declare any other companies which might become involved in the refining or in the production of petroleum products. In the meantime, the relevant companies will be covered by the Act. As the honourable member for Adelaide would know the Commonwealth has limited powers over the non-corporate sector. This Bill, therefore, focuses its attention on the corporate sector.

The third amendment, like the first two, is not acceptable to the Government. It goes further than the self-discipline concept of the Bowen report and would put an unreasonable stricture upon an associate commissioner who, by definition, would only be appointed from outside the Authority for particular inquiries. The existing words are consistent with other legislation. The fourth amendment is not acceptable as the existing words provide for proper disclosure of any relevant interest and they are consistent with other legislation. With regard to the fifth amendment, it is the policy and intention that the authority will conduct inquiries only with the approval of the Minister, as is the case with inquiries presently carried out by the PJT. The authority will in no other way be constrained in its normal price monitoring functions.

The sixth amendment is not acceptable to the Government as the Authority is not an appropriate body for reporting on broad economic and social policy issues. These functions rest with other bodies and with the Government directly. The Authority is concerned with the petroleum products only and will have the powers necessary to determine whether prices are justified on the basis of reasonable costs. In relation to the seventh amendment, the policy intention is that the Minister will have a power of direction to ensure that the Authority has regard to the particular matters where necessary in the carrying out of functions and powers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should you?

—The honourable member for Burke asks why he should. The justification is that a similar provision exists in the Industries Assistance Commission and the Prices Justification Tribunal legislation. In relation to the eighth amendment I point out that the existing penalty is consistent with penalties for similar breaches. There is no demonstrated need for a higher penalty. In conclusion I make reference to the points raised by the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck). I am sure that he will watch this Authority carefully, as he said he would. If he is concerned, I am absolutely certain that we will hear from him in the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY GAMING AND LIQUOR AUTHORITY BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Mr Hodgman:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose this Bill. However we believe that the distribution of funds and functions which should properly be the responsibility of a local government body should be declared and, where it is practicable, inserted in the Bill. It is our intention to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading which indicates our attitude to the manner of decision making on the distribution of funds from these bodies to the community and welfare funds. It is also our intention to move an amendment in the Committee stage relating to the makeup of the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority. In the first instance it has not been possible for us to draft amendments to the Bill which would have been practical in order to meet what we see as being a desirable end. Therefore, we believe that our objective can be satisfactorily achieved only by the Bill being redrafted. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

the Bill be withdrawn and re-drafted to provide that the dispersal of funds raised by the Authority, other than those committed to the racing industry, will be in accordance with determinations of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly but limited to purposes associated with sport, recreation, culture, welfare and community related activities in the Australian Capital Territory.

The purpose of the amendment is to make it quite clear that the distribution of those funds which are paid to the community welfare fund-an amount of about $2m a year in the Australian Capital Territory-are allocated in accordance with decisions which are made by the people who are elected by the residents of the Territory to carry out those functions which would normally be associated with local government and, to a limited extent, a State government or a territorial government. At this stage, given the nature of legislation which controls the making of laws in the Australian Capital Territory, the amendment would have to be made by ordinance which we believe should be disallowed only by this Parliament and not subject to alteration by the Minister for the Capital Territory.

It is appropriate, I think, that funds in an area should be allocated by the people closest to the needs and concerns of that area-the elected representatives. They should make the decisions. They are the elected members and the people of the Territory have the opportunity to deal with them if they do not properly do the job that is expected of them. The people of the Australian Capital Territory have no opportunity of affecting the numbers in this place except on a fairly marginal basis-

TALK.START.PARA: —They are supposed to be getting self-government.

—That matter has been up several times tonight. The honourable gentleman does himself no service by parroting that phrase. Self-government is an obligation in a democracy; it is not something one can opt out of. There is only one other place in Australia which is treated in the same way as the Australian Capital Territory is treated and that is the City of Melbourne where the council has been dismissed because it would not treat certain developers and large business organisations well in giving them building permits. The organisations are very substantial donors to a party with which the honourble member has some association. The council has now been replaced so that the centre of the city can be raped. That is not necessary in this city. If a Minister or a government-
—What do you mean by that?

—It is not necessary. The power already exists for any government that wishes to take such action to do anything it so desires outside the Parliamentary Triangle. It is an area where one person, the Minister is responsible to a government charged with national responsibilities and not seriously concerned with these matters, makes decisions on behalf of, in a completely paternal manner, a substantive section of the Australian community. The Department of the Capital Territory is not elected for or answerable to the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate relating to this Bill is not appropriate for a discussion of the constitutional requirements of the Australian Capital Territory. The Government has chosen that the Australian Capital Territory will not have self-government on the basis of a referendum. We will not discuss the merits or otherwise of that result. The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) said earlier that he is prepared to go some way towards self-government provided a formula can be arrived at. If the functions within the Minister's responsibility were taken away from the responsible governments in any of our electorates or States, there would be an uproar from honourable members who sit opposite. It would interfere with the rights of those people who govern those areas. Those rights are denied in the Australian Capital Territory. By moving this amendment we seek to give those rights in respect of the distribution of funds which come from taxes levied on gambling and racing in this area to the people of this Territory. It is a right to which they are entitled, and it is an obligation that they are entitled to be expected to undertake on their own behalf.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). The Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority Bill is acceptable. It is one of the few things in the razor gang recommendations for Canberra with which I found I could agree. It amalgamates a number of authorities which is a sensible thing to do. It should work out in theory and I hope it works out in practice. The way in which this Bill has been drawn up provides a need for the amendment which the honourable member for Corio has moved. The need for that amendment reflects the general contempt which the Government has for the views of the locally elected representatives of the people in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) said, in his second reading speech, that he proposes that the Authority should include a member of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly and a legal practitioner. I do not think that is good enough. I think provisions should be written into the Bill in the terms that have been suggested by the honourable member for Corio to ensure that there is adequate representation from locally elected people. Of course, it is terribly important that the locally elected Assembly should make the decisions about where the money is disbursed. They are familiar with the needs of the community. They are the people who should make the judgments. They do it conscientiously. Last year they spent a lot of time considering how the money should be allotted. Then we had the disgusting situation of the Minister quite arbitrarily overruling the recommendations of a committee of locally elected people who know what are the needs of the community.

Last year the former Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Ellicott, quite arbitrarily reduced the sums recommended by the Assembly and awarded significant amounts to other organisations which were not recommended by the Assembly. Recommendations were introduced for organisations such as the Handicapped Citizens Association, the Canberra Community Legal Service, the Asthma Association, the Epilepsy Association and the Specific Learning Difficulties Association. These were organisations seen as having real needs in the community. The Minister saw fit arbitrarily to reduce the recommendations by the locally elected people and, in their place, he gave significant sums, for example, to the Duke of Edinburgh Awards Scheme and the Canberra Horticultural Society, which were not included in the recommendations. These are laudable organisations and I do not begrudge them getting some money, but I resent the Minister making arbitrary decisions and reducing recommendations made by locally elected people.

The fact that we are here after midnight debating a Bill concerning domestic matters in the Australian Capital Territory points up the absurdity of the arrangement that this Government has for the administration of Canberra. People from all over Australia are sitting here after midnight considering legislation which sets out the way in which the people of Canberra may disburse funds raised within their own jurisdiction from poker machines, from the Totalisator Agency Board and from the administration of liquor licensing laws. I think it is an absurd situation. We do not need people from Tasmania, Victoria, Queensland or anywhere else to tell us what to do with the funds that we raise in Canberra. We are quite capable of doing the job. How would honourable members opposite feel if a group of people from all over Australia started telling the people of Tasmania or Queensland how they should disburse the funds that they have raised? We do not need hill-billies from Hobart telling us how to disburse our funds. We can do it ourselves. This debate points up the absurdity of the arrangements in this city.

It is all right for the Minister to make big noises about being a democrat and about supporting self-government. Why does he not write that into the Bill? Why is he not fair dinkum about this self-government question? Earlier today he said that he had offered self-government to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly. I did not know about it and I am sure that the House of Assembly does not know about it. Let us stop the talk and allow the people of Canberra to make decisions about their domestic concerns. We do not need other people to tell us. We need to accept that responsibility and, if we are given the opportunity, we will.

I hope the Minister will consider these representations. I hope he will see that the locally elected people are represented on these organisations and that their voices are listened to. We do not want just token representation; we want real representation by people who are elected in Canberra, who have the right of recall if they do not perform as well as we think they should. The people of Canberra do not have this representation now. The Minister can do what he likes and make all sorts of arbitrary decisions and the people of Canberra can do nothing about it. I repeat: How would the people of Hobart feel if we made those sorts of decisions for them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

Apparently he does not know that a commitment was given last year, to which he has not made any reference, for one per cent to be put aside as additional revenue to the racing clubs. Apparently he does not know that there is a further proposal for a racecourse development fund. Last, but not least neither the honourable member for Fraser nor the honourable member for Corio appear to know that this Bill does nothing to vary the current disbursal of funds.

Of the amendment that has been moved and the amendment that has been foreshadowed, one is a legal impossibility and the other is absolute nonsense. I do not mind being accused of being a dictator and I do not mind being accused of being an autocrat, but I suggest, with the greatest of respect to both my honourable friends on the other side of the chamber, that next time they move amendments relating to the Australian Capital Territory they should look at the Bill and make sure their amendments are in order before they bring them into the House so that they do not waste the time of the national Parliament.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is: 'That the Bill be now read a second time'.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) has misunderstood completely the second reading amendment I moved to the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority Bill and the amendment I will move during this Committee stage. I cannot understand how he found any suggestion of changes in the disbursal of funds in the previous amendment or in the amendment I will move. It was not drafted because-I would have thought the Minister could at least have understood this-ten pages of amendments would have been necessary to achieve the real purpose of my second reading amendment. That would at least have meant I had looked at the Bill. He may be able to have had drafted that sort of amendment without looking at the Bill, but then he has someone to do it for him. I do have to look at the Bills handled in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the amendment I propose to move is to guarantee that members of the House of Assembly will be appointed to the Authority. The Opposition has proposed that two members of the Assembly should be automatically members of the Authority, and that those members should be determined by the Assembly. I am aware that the Minister feels that would inhibit his opportunity to spread the membership of this Authority as widely as possible. I do not think it would be objectionable if an additional member were appointed because this amendment entrenches in the Bill the one member of the Assembly that the Minister said in his second reading speech he would be appointing and adds one additional member. That could be easily accommodated, if the Minister were of that mind, by merely changing the number of members from five to six members.

The reason the amendment suggests two members from the House of Assembly is that it gives a better opportunity to provide a balanced representation of the Assembly on the Authority. I am fully aware that the member currently appointed is not of either major political party in the Assembly. That is the current situation and we would not expect to amend legislation of this nature every time there is an election for the Assembly. I think, wherever possible and practical, without interfering with administration and other things, it is desirable, where representatives of parliaments are involved, to have both sides of the political equation represented. It is the usual practice in this Parliament that where appointments of members of Parliament are made to various bodies, members from both sides are appointed. Usually that involves two members, although at the moment the Assembly is a multi-sided body. That is because of the nature of the elections.

I believe this amendment does not detract from the Bill. It entrenches a right. The Minister may have all the goodwill in the world, but one day he may be elevated or demoted, or he may depart this place because of old age or for some other reason and another Minister will be appointed. That follows as sure as day follows night. He may not have the same views. The Minister twice removed was very much in favour of self-government in the Territory. Subsequently, the following Minister was not. We could argue all night about the effect that the attitude of that Minister to self-government had on the referendum. I believe the people of Canberra, given the sorts of financial assurances which they are entitled to expect if they were offered an obligation, would accept self-government and the responsibility of choosing the people who will make decisions on their behalf. In this chamber tonight matters relating to the Australian Capital Territory which we feel are of substance are being decided by a majority of people, none of whom have any electoral responsibility-putting aside national responsibility-to the people of Canberra or are in any way answerable to them. I move:
Clause 5, page 2, omit sub-clause (1), substitute the following sub-clause:

'(1) The Authority shall consist of 3 members appointed by the Minister and 2 members who are members of, and nominated by, the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly constituted by the House of Assembly Ordinance 1936 of the Australian Capital Territory as amended.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) for the spirit in which he has moved his amendment, but it is not acceptable. The first matter of concern to me and the Government is that if the honourable member thought about it he would realise there are very strong grounds for objecting to an authority constituting an even number of members. To create an authority of six members is to invite the situation of a 3-3 vote, with all the problems that that places upon the chairman of a small body. The Government concluded that five was the appropriate number. Whilst I recognise the spirit of the honourable member's amendment to give increased representation to the House of Assembly, without any disrespect to the House of Assembly, I draw to the honourable member's attention that we are amalgamating into one authority the Totalisator Agency Board, the Poker Machine Licensing Board and the Liquor Licensing Board. We have had representations from groups in the Australian Capital Territory wanting to be included on the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority. I mention some of them: Galloping, trotting and greyhound interests, licensed clubs, retailers of alcohol, wholesalers, poker machine licensees, consumers and a miscellany of government officials who also want to be seated on the Authority. The Government took the view-I think it is a proper view-that it should maintain the one person representation from the House of Assembly which currently exists on the three boards. I do not say that the House of Assembly does not want more representation, but I do say it has not asked for it. I appreciate the spirit of the honourable member's amendment, but I am not prepared to accept-nor is the Government-that of a board of five, two should be members of the House of Assembly.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to the first point raised by the honourable member for Corio in respect of his earlier amendment, which is in some way related to the amendment before the Committee-indeed, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry) spoke to this amendment when we were dealing with the first amendment-I suggest that one could look through the Bill 150 times without finding anything about the disbursal of funds. It is not a question of 10 pages of amendments; it just could not be done.

Last but not least, in relation to the question of self-government I am sorry to have to inform the honourable member, because apparently he is not aware of it, that I met with the House of Assembly within one week of my appointment as Minister. I told it-it was publicly reported-that I welcomed its suggestions about moving towards self-government. I would be delighted if the people of Canberra would take up some of the responsibilities which flow over my desk every day and accept for themselves the responsibility to do things which I am convinced the most highly educated, articulate and intelligent community in Australia is quite capable of doing for itself. The House of Assembly has less legislative or governmental power than the National Aboriginal Conference. I simply draw to the attention of all honourable members that I welcome thoughtful and well-prepared submissions on self-government. Unfortunately, I have heard nothing of substance except from a citizen's group being led by Mrs Craven, and certainly nothing from the House of Assembly.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

(2) Clause 11, page 6, after sub-clause (1), insert the following sub-clause:

'(1A) Where the Authority is considering, or is about to consider, a matter relating to a body, whether corporate or unincorporate, that is the holder of, or that has applied for, a licence under the Liquor Ordinance 1975 of the Australian Capital Territory as amended and in force at any time (whether or not that matter arises under or in relation to that Ordinance), a member-
(a) who is the secretary of that body; or
