SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is almost exactly 12 hours since I last addressed the House and in almost exactly another 12 hours I will be addressing it again. I am beginning to feel a little bit like a chiming clock. Because the hour is late I do not intend to delay the House. However, there are a few things which one should say on the Australian National University Amendment Bill. The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian National University Act as it relates to the activities of student organisations on campus. This is the second attempt that the Government has made to stifle student organisation at the Australian National University. This attempt demonstrates two very endearing qualities about this Government. Firstly, this Government is not only silly but it is persistently silly; and, secondly, it has an almost infinite capacity to bungle its enactments. In 1979 the Government introduced a Bill to amend the Australian National University Act, which was described by the Minister at the time in a passage of Hansard which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard. Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The document reads as follows-

The sections of the Bill dealing with student organisations will provide that: Membership of a student organisation will be voluntary; fees payable in respect of membership of a student organisation will be voluntary; compulsory fees can only be used for the provision of amenities or services; where the Council of the University makes compulsory fees moneys available to a student organisation for the provision by that organisation of approved amenities or services, the Council must first be satisfied that the governing body of that organisation is representative of its members; in addition, where the Council of the University makes compulsory fees moneys available to a student organisation for the provision by that organisation of amenities or services, then it is the duty of the Council to ensure that the moneys are applied only in respect of the provision of amenities or services that are not of an academic nature, that are of direct benefit to the University, and that have been declared in university statutes to be amenities or services in respect of that organisation; compulsory fees moneys are not to be paid to a national organisation which represents students but they may be paid to a national student organisation whose principal function has to do with sporting or recreational activities, or with a particular education, social or cultural field, or with the interests of post-graduate students; financial statements are to be prepared and audited each year showing details of the manner in which compulsory fees have been expended.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main target of the provision was the ANU Students Association and that explanation, which I will not read, was a long winded way of saying that membership of the Association was to be voluntary and that funds collected via the compulsory services and amenities fee were not to be used for political activities and most importantly these funds were not to be expended on the affiliation to the Australian Union of Students. Regrettably for the Government, that law did not work. The main problem was that the ANU Students Association had other forms of income which the Australian National University Council, following legal advice, decided was not subject to the constraints imposed by the 1979 amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the Council's May 1981 meeting, the Association transmitted to AUS its affiliation fee from funds it had derived from sources other than the compulsory fee. Just before the May meeting the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) wrote to the Council advising it to decide otherwise and threatened that this legislation would follow if it did not. Retribution was swift and that is why we are now debating this legislation, the purpose of which is to attempt to ensure that all the income that the Association receives, however derived, will be subject to the same constraints as the income from fees. The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) has alerted me to one point and that is, however the income is derived by application of the income from the fees, the income will be subject to the same restrictions as those imposed by the 1979 amendment.

This Bill is necessary only because the Government bungled its earlier attempts, and one wonders whether this attempt will be any more successful. As I said before, this amendment is also silly. It reveals that this Government is still imprisoned by the Australian Student Liberal Federation. The members of this Government are hostages of members of the kindergarten Liberal Party who, like mollycoddled children, have forced their big brothers and sisters in the Government to achieve the purposes which they have so patently failed to achieve through the democratic processes of the ANU Students Association. The ANU Students Association is a very democratic association and makes its decisions by way of regular general meetings. The Association has decided that it wants to remain affiliated to the Australian Union of Students and continues to reaffirm that decision. The kindly Liberals have never been able to get a majority of students to agree with them that the Association should leave AUS. One would think that this Government and this horse-riding, fast-car-driving Prime Minister would have more important things to do than be brow beaten by a pack of spoiled brats. But then, as Senator Chipp has said, he is really only a kid at heart and cannot resist playing little games like dropping ice cubes into people's pockets and then squealing with delight at the reaction of his victims.

But there is a much more serious side to this matter. Firstly, the Association should be able to make its own decisions about how it spends its funds. After all, it is not compulsory for students to belong, even though it is compulsory for students to pay the services and amenities fee. The Council of the University decides what proportion of income from that fee will go to the Association. In my very firm view it should be up to the democratic processes of the Association to decide how that fee income is to be applied. In support of that argument I want to quote briefly from a letter dated 30 April 1979 from Sir John Crawford, the Chancellor of the Australian National University. He says:

The Council has long believed that in a modern university it is very desirable that, so far as it is at all possible, students themselves should manage their own student organisations. Whether the ANU Students' Association should, in the ordinary manner, be affiliated to the AUS or not is, in the Council's view, for the ANU's students themselves to decide. Referenda on this question have lately been held on other campuses.
At ANU simple procedures exist to determine the question.

I could not agree more with Sir John Crawford on that matter. It should be up to the democratic processes of the ANU Students Association to work out the way in which the funds which they receive are applied. It is not up to governments. It is not even up to university councils to use draconian methods to determine or constrain the way in which those funds will be applied.

It is a fact that the statutes which set up all the universities throughout Australia provide for students' associations in some form or another. They exist to organise the student body and to represent it to the university, the Government and the community. All these associations obtain funds from fees which are paid by students. In most cases they are part of compulsory fees. It is my strong opinion that these separate associations need to have a national organisation to encourage debate on educational and other issues and, importantly, to represent the collective student view to the Government. After all, the Commonwealth is now responsible for the almost total funding of tertiary education. The students need to have a say before government as government makes decisions about important matters. The Commonwealth also makes decisions about the level of assistance which is provided to students going through universities and colleges. Again, it is important that there be a national organisation to represent the views of students on these important matters.

It is perfectly legitimate for student bodies on all the campuses to affiliate with AUS and to pay fees to it in order to support its activities. It is not only important it is also vital that they do so. A well run and well representative AUS is not only good for students in Australia but it is also good for Australia. The contribution of AUS to the education debate in the late 1960s and early 1970s was invaluable. It led to a number of changes of policy which came about at the time of the election of a Labor government. The AUS or its predecessor has been responsible for a number of important initiatives. I mention just one, the Aboriginal scholarship scheme, which AUS introduced at a time when there was little or no support for Aboriginal students. Consequently, very few Aboriginal students were involved even in secondary education, let alone tertiary education. It has to be remembered that the Abschol scheme became redundant only when an alternative scheme was instituted by the then Minister, W. C. Wentworth. As a result the need for Abschol was virtually removed. The AUS has done great work. It is now emerging once more as a powerful force in Australia, especially in the education debate.

It is not surprising that this Government does not like the AUS. It is not surprising that the Government's juvenile foot soldiers in the Liberal Students Federation do not like it either. As long as this Government and the Liberal Party are wedded to an education policy which is based on privilege the AUS will always criticise them and their policy. The Government must realise that it is always inconvenient to have critics but in a country which is supposed to be a democracy criticism is an essential part of the democratic process. There is an even more obnoxious aspect to this legislation and the way in which the Government has pursued its mindless obsession with the AUS. It concerns the way the Government has stood over the University in a most grotesque way. The Government refused to discuss the amendments to the Australian National University Act in 1979. It has refused to discuss these amendments in 1981. It is true that there has been some communication between the University and the Government but it has always been on the basis that unless the University accepts the Government's view the Government will legislate to ensure that it does not have any choice. It is intriguing in this context to point out a reference by Sir John Crawford in his letter of April 1979. He said:

May I add that, as you will know, it has nowhere proved easy to legislate satisfactorily on these issues. Council has accordingly stated that it will review within two years the operation of its Statute. It believes that this is the better way to proceed at this time rather than by amendment of the principal Act by way of an addition to section 29.

Sir John Crawford was indeed prophetic when he made that remark. Here we are less than two years later amending the bungled legislation which the Government introduced against the wishes of the University in 1979. The Government was simply concerned to stand over the University. This constitutes a very grave interference in its affairs. It goes further than that. The Australian National University Act provides that the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition should each nominate two members of the Parliament to the Council. They are not there as representatives of the Government and the Opposition but as representatives of the Australian community to act as they see fit as representatives of the Australian community on the governing body of Australia's national university. One of the Prime Minister's representatives is the honourable member for Dundas. He has behaved in a totally unprincipled way in his membership of the Council. He has used his position simply to be a toady for the Government. He has threatened the Council that unless it follows the Government's directives or the intentions of its legislation dire consequences will follow. At the May meeting he said that by not agreeing with the Government the University had earned itself a bad reputation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get that information?
—It is contained in a forthcoming article in Woroni which I am sure the honourable member will be pleased to read.
—I would be interested to know who the author is.
—The people who were on the Council are entitled to report to the people who elect them on what goes on in the Council.
—If it is reported accurately, and you are supposed to vouch for the accuracy of statements you quote in this House.
—I have not quoted anything.
—The honourable member for Fremantle should continue. The honourable member for Dundas should remain silent.

—He will have his opportunity to speak. So much for his views on academic freedom and the autonomy of universities. He was not content with that and went further. He said that serious consequences would follow if the University did not comply with the Government's directives. He pointed out that the University was seeking co-operation in respect of, amongst other things, superannuation supplementation. This was an outrageous abuse of the honourable member's position on the Council. It led the Chancellor of the University to describe his threats as subtle blackmail. It is quite unprincipled for the honourable member for Dundas to behave in that way as a representative of the Parliament and the Australian people on the Council of the Australian National University. It typifies the arrogant approach which this Government has taken in trying to control student organisations at the ANU and, for that matter, at the Canberra College of Advanced Education. It is for that reason that the Opposition strenuously opposes this legislation. It should not proceed; it should be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian National University Amendment Bill is to put beyond doubt certain questions that have been raised in relation to the operation of the Australian National University Act as it applies to the funding of student organisations at the University. When the legislation to amend the ANU Act was introduced, I and numbers of my colleagues were certainly of the view that the funds made available to the student organisations were to be properly applied to the activities that the amendments to the Act envisaged the students' association might carry on. A question was raised at that time as to whether there was any possibility of funds made available for a particular purpose being laundered by the students' association in such a way as to relieve them of their special character as funds that could not be remitted to the Australian Union of Students and for that body to obtain them by subterfuge. The fear that some of us had at that time but which we were assured that the Act would deal with was realised when the University Council and the students' association sought legal advice.

SPEECH.PARA: We became aware when reading the accounts of the students' association that certain moneys were being paid to subsidise certain legitimate student activities. But it was claimed that revenue earned from those activities was being set aside by the students as though it was revenue of their own that they had earned by legitimate activities. I think that it is fair to the House that I, as one of the Parliament's representatives on the Council of the Australian National University, should indicate the nature of the deception involved. Deception is exactly what it was. I had no hesitation in telling my colleagues on the Council that that is what I though it to be. I have no shame at all in having done that. I have no shame in responsibly reporting to that body my view of the determination of my colleagues to ensure that the intention of the Government, expressed in statements in this place and expressed in an Act of Parliament, be carried into effect. I certainly told the Council of that determination. That view was already before the Council because it had the letter from the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) before it. I think that I have a responsibility not only to tell the Parliament of views of the University, as I do from time to time, and my colleagues in our party councils, from which I was appointed and the views the people within the University hold, but also to tell those on the Council of the attitudes of the Government. Council members are free to vote as they see fit, as they did on that occasion.

I will explain the nature of the deception involved in this exercise, A place called Childers Street Hall received a subsidy of some $1,031, yet revenue of $635 was claimed to be earned from that hall. In other words, the subsidy was greatly in excess of the revenue. Lennox House, for its operations, received $6,539 in subsidies, and the revenue derived was $1,905. In Orientation Week there was an element of revenue earned from activities as well as a subsidy. A Rank Xerox photostating machine was subsidised by some $2,198 and students were charged $963 for using the machine for copying. Telephone accounts came to $5,710 but $710 was collected from the students using the phone. The magazine was subsidised to the extent of $14,802. It received advertisements to the value of $2,162. Very little money was not the subject of a direct subsidy from the general services fee. In my view all of the revenue had that character. The University in looking at that-whether it was legally right or not I regard as irrelevant-morally was involved in a deception in approving, as it did by resolution, of students taking that subsidy and claiming that they had somehow earned income from their own activities. That was the most blatent laundering exercise that I can imagine. I have pleasure in reporting to the Parliament and to my colleagues the activity in which I believe my colleagues on the Council were involved.

Certainly I told my colleagues on the Council that I would inform the Parliament and honourable members of what I thought of that activity in which the University Council was about to indulge. This legislation is merely to put beyond doubt that which we believed we were implementing in the legislation in the first place. I very much regret the news made known to me tonight-not as a member of the Council-that the students' association, in the knowledge that this legislation was to be proceeded with, has paid those moneys which quite improperly, in my view, came into its hands to the Australian Union of Students. I certainly support this legislation very strongly. I have no shame whatever for the action I have taken on the University Council. I will continue honestly to inform the Council of the views I believe are held not only in this Parliament but also amongst my colleagues that I represent on the Council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying at the second reading stage before I was rudely interrupted, the internal affairs of the students of the Australian National University are being grossly interfered with by this Government. The Australian National University Amendment Bill is another attempt to stifle further the students' activities. This highly immoral Government has only one purpose, as is clearly expressed in the legislation, and that is to prevent the students at the Australian National University from engaging in political activities relating to education. The Bill is particularly aimed at ensuring that students, both in Canberra and in the rest of Australia, take no part in political activities which indicate their strong opposition to the policies of the Government. It is sheer hypocrisy to argue that the membership of student organisations should be voluntary when the Government itself was voted into office by a compulsory vote. Government members like to ignore the fact that more than half of the Australian voting population did not vote for the present Government. Yet, these people are forced to pay taxes to fund Government policies and are forced to abide by the laws promulgated by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: What difference is there between being a member of the Australian community, an Australian citizen, and the membership by students of the university student community? The principles of universal sufferage and democratic rights are as characteristic of student bodies as they are of the Australian community as a whole. The Federal Government is not prepared to allow individual citizens to opt out of their responsibilities to the community. Why then does the Government make legislation which permits individual students to opt out of their responsibility to the university student community? Obviously the Government is not concerned that students who refuse to join a student organisation will be able to enjoy the benefits which their fellow students have won on their behalf. But the Government is concerned when individual citizens refuse to pay their taxes. Furthermore, it will prosecute them to ensure that those taxes are paid.

Double standards are the stock in trade of this Government. I suppose that Opposition members should not be surprised at this hypocritical attitude. Of course we all know that once this Bill has been passed pressure will be brought to bear on those State governments whose university Acts are not as regressive against the students of their universities as are the provisions contained in the present Bill. We also know that the Federal Government will not hesitate to use its funding powers to bludgeon those State governments which may resist making a similar attack on the independence of the university students in their States.

There is a strong degree of paternalism about the interference of the Government in student matters which in this more enlightened age is evidence of the conservative philosophy of Government members. Students are quite capable of handling their own business, as university councils all over Australia have accepted for many years. As mentioned previously, the Government has made quite clear that it is taking the present action because it is not prepared to tolerate student political action. It is part of the democratic process that groups in the community should be able to organise and make representations to the Government. The plain fact is that the student unions have, over the years, become autonomous bodies which exist to provide services, representation and resources for the benefit of the student body. In carrying out such functions they are of necessity involved in political activities. In this sense they are analagous to trade unions. It is this similarity which draws unto them the hate of Government members.

The Federal Government, by restricting the means by which the student body and the Australian National University can gain essential funding for such organising purposes, is denying a basic democratic right of our society to the students. The truth of the matter is that the Federal Government fears the powers of the student body to bring home to the Australian people the danger of their living standards which the present educational policy of the Government represents. Restrictions in the Tertiary Education Assistance System allowance, the introduction of fees for second and post-graduate degrees, the forced amalgamation and closures of colleges of advanced education and the cut in the facilities of the Australian Schools Commission are all reductions in educational services which will greatly restrict the opportunities of Australians to improve their educational skills for the benefit of Australians as a whole. It is not too late for the Federal Government to reverse this trend.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fair go.

—I have nearly finished. Be patient. It is not too late for the Federal Government to move away from its confrontationist attitude to students in tertiary educational institutions. I say just one thing before I close my remarks. Listening to the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) confirmed the impression which I gained when I was a member of the Council of the University of Melbourne that the nominees of Liberal governments on university councils are there just to act as stooges for the Government. They have no true understanding of university traditions and no sympathy for the students. I believe this Government should withdraw this iniquitous Bill and accept that the fundamental right of the student bodies is to engage in political activities and that it is a normal, necessary ingredient of tertiary education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Student unions have over the years played a constructive role in Australian political debate. The Australian Union of Students is included among them. In the major political issues in which Australia and its predecessors have engaged in recent years-the question of the Vietnam war and conscription and the needs of education-their views have been justified by experience. The political positions adopted by those organisations were at variance with the views of honourable members opposite. Quite unimpeachably the student unions and Australian sponsored campaigns were supported by the bulk of their members, as they continue to be supported. Those campaigns were in the direct interests of and of direct concern to those members. It never pays one to be right in politics; it only pays to win. If one is right and loses one is doubly damned. One's opponents' efforts to exculpate their own moral inferiority will make them doubly vicious. Behind the pompous asininities of honourable members opposite about compulsory unionism and the importance of prohibiting the use of service funds for political purposes of direct interest to students lies a steely determination to render the organisations ineffective.

SPEECH.PARA: Like the Australian Broadcasting Commission cuts, like the cuts in expenditure in the area of Aboriginal affairs, in this issue there is a liberal dosage of naked and unloved revenge. It is not surprising that the Government has trouble makeing its legislation stick. When one gets down to it, it is impossible to implement unless one puts an officer of the Auditor-General's Department in every student union office. One gets to the obvious situation where there are buildings provided by amenity funds in which political meetings for AUS purposes or other purposes are held. Are the students to be charged every time they walk into those buildings for an AUS meeting? There are typing services available in the student union organisations and printing machines. They are useful for handing out notices that are related to amenities. Will an officer of the Auditor-General's Department determine when it is an amenity-related notice or an AUS-related notice. It is nonsense. This piece of legislation, like the previous piece of legislation, will not resolve that problem. The Liberal Party will keep poking a stick at it. The great Liberal Government will offend every liberal principle on academic freedom when that suits its purpose, but this ought not to cause us to be surprised as there is no other liberal principle that the Liberal Party is not prepared to jettison when it so suits it.

This Government in its various metamorphoses over the last couple of decades has been extraordinarily hard on the younger generation. It has rendered them jobless, restricted their access to educational possibilities and marched them off to fight in disastrous wars. This Bill is merely a minor part of a general trend of youth bashing by a government whose leading members were born mummified. It is not surprising, therefore, that about 66 per cent of the young population in the last election voted against this Government. They will continue to do so. At the next election they will defeat the Government. The people will be convinced that they ought to defeat the Government because of the stupid sorts of actions that the Government has undertaken.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
